headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome and thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. And I would like to introduce Mr. Martin Mucci, President and Chief Executive Officer. Sir, you may
componenttext:
Welcome and thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
And I would like to introduce Mr. Martin Mucci, President and Chief Executive Officer. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter fiscal 2016 earnings release call and webcast. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial resu
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter fiscal 2016 earnings release call and webcast. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. 
This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results for the third quarter ended February 29, 2016. Our Form 10-Q, which provides additional discussions and analysis for the results, will be available later today. Our earnings release and Form 10-Q will be available on our Investor Relations web page. This teleconference is being webcast over the Internet and will be archived and available on our website for about 1 month.
On today's call, I'll review the highlights of the third quarter related to sales and operations and product development. Efrain will review our third quarter financial results in more detail and discuss our full year guidance, and then we'll open it up for any questions.
Once again, we've experienced growth across our major human capital management solutions during the third quarter. Our third quarter financial results reflected total service revenue growth of 7%, including 4% in payroll service revenue and continued double-digit growth in our HRS revenue. We experienced positive sales growth for the first 9 months, including a strong selling season. We were particularly pleased with our results in the mid-market space. Our HR outsourcing services also continued to reflect strong growth. 
Mark Bottinicome, our head of sales, and his organization has done a terrific job working as a team to demonstrate to new clients the value of our full suite of products that are -- the full -- the value of our full suite of products that they offer. Our sales force turnovers are at its lowest level in years and we are already ramping up for additional reps to be fully staffed for the start of fiscal 2017. 
Our service execution continues to excel, demonstrated by continuing high levels of client satisfaction and retention. We completed a successful calendar year-end and our employees continue providing great service as we have moved to an even more flexible service options. Year-to-date, we are experiencing the best net client gains since the recession as a result of both positive and effective selling and solid retention results. 
In terms of product development, we continue to focus on enhancing the user experience and flexibility with Paychex Flex, our cloud-based human capital management platform. Paychex Flex delivers access to payroll, human resources and benefits information, creating a streamlined and integrated approach to workforce management. 
Earlier this fiscal year, we launched new and integrated modules within the Flex platform. This included the addition of Paychex Flex Time, Paychex Flex Benefits Administration and Paychex Flex Hiring, which includes paperless recruiting, screening and on boarding. This integrated suite allows for a simpler user interface that is supported by an industry-leading service model. We are very proud of our Paychex Flex platform and we're pleased to be recognized for the value our technology brings to our clients. In addition to the recognition from the Brandon Hall Group and Gartner increasing our position in the Magic Quadrant earlier this year, PC Magazine recently recognized Paychex Flex as one of the best cloud-based payroll services for 2016. We are very proud of the increased recognition that Paychex Software-as-a-Service based products and service are experiencing and we see this played out with solid sales and retention performance. 
Last fiscal year, we launched our Paychex Employer Shared Responsibility Service, which is our full service Affordable Care Act, more commonly know as ACA solution. Our ESR product includes a multi-monitoring service with automatic alerts as well as year-end reporting. Our revenue from this ACA solution has increased as we assist clients with their monitoring and year-end reporting requirements. As a result of the demand for this service, we have increased our implementation and support spending. 
On December 22, we completed the acquisition of Advance Partners. Advance Partners offers customizable solutions to the temporary staffing industry, including payroll funding and outsourcing services. We are excited about the opportunity this acquisition provides and believe it's a great fit. The temporary staffing industry has experienced expanded growth in clients are within our target market of small and midsized businesses. Our consolidated financial results include Advance Partners from the date of the acquisition in late December. 
We remain committed to adding value to our shareholders. Last July, we increased our dividend by 11% to $0.42 per share and have maintained a strong dividend yield of over 3%, one of the highest in our industry. Our stock repurchase program remains in place and we have required 2.2 million shares of common stock during the first 9 months of fiscal '16. 
I would like to take a moment to mention something else we're very proud of. On March 10, we were recognized by Institute as a 2016 World's Most Ethical Company. As an 8-year [indiscernible], we believe this award underscores our commitment to leading ethical business practices and standards and practices, ensuring long-term value to key stakeholders, including our customers, our investors and employees. We are 1 of only 2 companies in the outsourcing services category honored this year. 
In summary, we saw continued strong execution from our sales and service teams, our product and financial performance remains strong and I appreciate the great work of our Paychex employee team. We are focused on a strong finish to fiscal 2016 in a few months here. And I will now turn the call over to Efrain to review our financial results in more detail. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's -- during today's conference call, we'll make some forward-looking statements that refer to future events and thus involve risks. refer to the usual disclosures.As Marty indicated, ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's -- during today's conference call, we'll make some forward-looking statements that refer to future events and thus involve risks. refer to the usual disclosures.
As Marty indicated, our third quarter financial results for this fiscal year reflect continued progress across major product lines. I'll cover the highlights and provide greater detail on certain areas then wrap wit a review of the 2016 outlook. 
Total revenues, as you saw, grew 7% for the third quarter and 9 months to $753 million and $2.2 billion, respectively. Total service revenue also grew 7% for the third quarter and 9 months to $741 million and $2.2 billion, respectively. Interest on funds held for clients increased 11% for the third quarter and 8% for the 9 months to $12 million and $34 million, respectively. We are beginning to see some positive impact from recent increases in interest rates, average invested balances for clients funds were basically flat year-over-year as positive impact from client growth was roughly offset by lower stake unemployment insurance rates. 
Total expenses increased 7% for both the third quarter and 9 months. Compensation related costs were the largest contributor to this growth, driven by higher wages and performance-based comp. In addition, strong growth in the PEO and the additional cost for Advance Partners in this quarter were factors in expense growth. Operating income net of certain items increased 6% for the third quarter and 9% for the 9 months to $268 million and $837 million, respectively. We've maintained strong operating margins of 36% for the third quarter and 39% for the 9 months, but anticipate that our full year will remain within our guidance of approximately 38%. As a reminder, we typically experience lower operating margins in the back half of the fiscal year. 
Net income was up 7% to $180 million for the third quarter and 13% to $579 million for the 9 months. Diluted earnings per share increased 9% to $0.50 per share for the third quarter and 13% to $1.60 per share for the 9 months. The 9-month period was positively impacted by the net tax benefit related to prior year revenues that were recognized in the first quarter. Excluding this impact, net income and diluted earnings per share would have risen 9% and 10%, respectively, and what you see in EPS is a functional so of the effect of buybacks that we've done over the past year.
Payroll service revenue increased 4% for both the third quarter and 9 months to $440 million and $1.3 billion, respectively. We benefited from increases in client base and revenue per check. Revenue per check grew as a result of price increases net of discounting. Advance Partners considered slightly less than 1% to payroll service for the third quarter. Let me repeat that, slightly less than 1% to payroll service revenue growth for the quarter. And I would say one other thing. Checks per client in the quarter moderated. This was partly a result of 2 things. One is in the third quarter benefit, I should say, bonus checks are typically we assume they're going to be a little bit higher than the year before. They didn't end up being the case this year. Although it's difficult to quantify. And we had a little bit of impact that was a result of client mix in the quarter. So Q3 is a little bit tough to predict in that respect. We ended up a little lighter than we had projected.
HRS revenue increased 12% to $301 million for the third quarter and 13% to $865 million for the 9 months. We are pleased with the growth for the quarter. Through call last quarter, we indicated that we anticipated Q3 HRS revenue growth to be below the low end of the range for annual guidance. This was due to a comparison to a stronger quarter in the prior year. We exceeded expectations, landing in the middle of the range. The increase reflected strong growth in both clients and worksite employees of Paychex HR Services, our largest HRS revenue stream, which includes ASO and PEO products. And we had -- continued to have strong growth in PEO revenue in the quarter. Insurance services benefited from continued growth of our ACA product that assist clients with health care reform and an increase in health and benefits [indiscernible] . Together with higher average premiums and clients in our workers' comp insurance programs. 
One other note, and we call this out in our Investor Day, I want to just highlight this. HCM module revenues that assist clients in HR administration and time and attendance also were strong in the quarter. You don't see that in the payroll service revenue because of the way we account for it, but as we discussed during -- we will discuss during the call, when we get questions on sales, we had a strong performance in mid-market. And you see that reflected in HRS, not in payroll. Advance Partners contributed slightly more than 1% to HRS revenue growth for the quarter.
Now turning to our investment portfolio. Our goal continues to be the protection of principle and optimization of liquidity. On a short-term site, our primary short-term interest vehicles were banked and deposit accounts, U.S. Treasury securities and high-quality commercial paper appeared. In our longer term portfolio, we best primarily in high credit quality and municipal bonds, corporate bonds and U.S. government securities. Long-term portfolio had an average yield to maturity currently of 1.7% and an average duration of 3.2 years. Combined portfolios have earned an average rate of return of 1% for the third quarter and 1.1% for the 9 months.
In December, the Fed raised federal funds rates by 25 basis points. It's the first interest rate hike in a decade, as you know. With this, we have raised our guidance and our interest on funds held for clients to high single digits where we had previously indicated it will be relatively flat, but simply reflects what you're already seeing in the numbers. So it's really not a significant change in guidance.
I'll now walk you through the highlights of our financial position. It remains strong. We had cash and total investments of $756 million as of the end of the quarter. Note that funds held for clients as of February 29 were $4.7 billion compared to $4.3 billion as of May 31, 2015. As you know, funds held for clients vary widely on a day-to-day basis, and averaged $4.5 billion for the quarter and $4 billion for the 9 months.
Total available for sale investments included corporate investments and funds held for clients, reflected net capitalized gains -- unrealized, I should say, gains of $61 million as of February 29th compared with net unrealized gains of $40 million as of May 31, 2015. Total stockholder's equity was 1.9 million as of February 29, reflecting $455 million in dividends paid during the 9 months and 108 million of common shares repurchased or return on equity for the past 12 months with a sterling 39%.
Our cash flows from operations were also strong this quarter and I want to call that out. They totaled $791 million for the first 9 months and again, a very, very strong 14% increase from the prior year. The chance change was a result of higher net income, higher noncash adjusted net income fluctuations and working capital. So from a financial metrics perspective, very pleased with where we ended.
Now onto the 2016 guidance. I'd like to remind you that it's based on current view of economic and industry conditions. Guidance for the full year is unchanged from previous quarter, except as I mentioned for interest on funds held for clients. I'll reiterate some of our full year ranges and then give some concluding color. Payroll service revenue anticipated to be in the range of 4% to 5%. That obviously also includes the addition of advanced payroll in that number. HRS revenue growth is anticipated to be in the range of 10% to 13%. Again, Advance is in that number and obviously expected will be at the high end of that number. Total service revenue is anticipated to be in the range of 7% to 8%. Again, towards the high end of that number. And net income growth is anticipated to be in the range of 8% to 9%. Please note that the range excludes the benefit of the net tax benefit to be recorded in the first quarter. 
Effective tax rate for the year, also excluding the impact of the net tax benefit recorded in the first quarter, will be approximately 36%. Our interest on funds held for clients are now expected to grow in the high single digits, as I said, as a result of recently increases in interest rates, current guidance, we do not anticipate any additional increases in the Fed funds rate for the remainder of the fiscal year. And if someone can decide for what the Fed is saying, I will -- I would be interested in getting schooled on the subject. But finally, we anticipate the contribution of Advance Partners is going to add somewhere between 1% and 1.5% to total service revenue in the fourth quarter. So that's a bit of color on what's happening there. Finally, we anticipate higher selling expense in the last quarter of the year. We had strong sales and comp will be up as a result of that. And higher ops expense due to stronger sales also. And also, client on boarding for ACA compliance solution. We anticipate, with all this, that our operating margins in the fourth quarter will be between 35% and 36%, bringing the full year margin in line with our previous guidance of approximately 38%. 
And with that, I will turn it back to Marty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Danyal Hussain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Danyal Hussain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to start off asking about small business hiring. Your index suggest instability in the past few quarters, but we've seen mixed data points elsewhere about optimism and hiring and heard a more cautious [indiscernible] from one of your competitors. M
componenttext: I want to start off asking about small business hiring. Your index suggest instability in the past few quarters, but we've seen mixed data points elsewhere about optimism and hiring and heard a more cautious [indiscernible] from one of your competitors. Maybe could you just talk a little bit more about what trends you're seeing there.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What we've seen with the Paychex HRS small business index, which we released for the month yesterday, we saw the best 3 month increase in the job growth rate for small businesses under 50 in 2 years. So this wiped out all the decrease that we saw kin
componenttext: Yes. What we've seen with the Paychex HRS small business index, which we released for the month yesterday, we saw the best 3 month increase in the job growth rate for small businesses under 50 in 2 years. So this wiped out all the decrease that we saw kind of a decrease in the growth rate at the end of '15, calendar year 2015. And then this first quarter, we saw that bounce back and kind of wipe out all the decrease. So we think that small business hiring job growth is on the upswing right now. It's not huge, but it certainly has recovered the decrease we saw last year. So we're pretty optimistic about it. We're seeing it -- a lot of -- there is some part-time in there that we're seeing increase as well and you're seeing it in services like or in sectors of jobs like other services and leisure and hospitality where there tends to be some part-time jobs. But we're definitely seeing some optimism in the job growth rate.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And you're expecting I think a potential second wind with ACA selling as you approach your past and most recent quarter mandate deadline. It may be too early to say now, but are you getting any reads in your sales force? And whether you're seeing
componenttext: Got it. And you're expecting I think a potential second wind with ACA selling as you approach your past and most recent quarter mandate deadline. It may be too early to say now, but are you getting any reads in your sales force? And whether you're seeing interest pick up again over these past few weeks or accelerate?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I haven't heard it yet, but I think as the deadline for the 1095 sees [ph] tomorrow hits and there's been a lot of activity obviously in the last 30 days with clients. And those who were not providing some of the data and now are scrambling to give data a
componenttext: I haven't heard it yet, but I think as the deadline for the 1095 sees [ph] tomorrow hits and there's been a lot of activity obviously in the last 30 days with clients. And those who were not providing some of the data and now are scrambling to give data and make sure that they're covered. I think we still expect that we'll see a second wave pick up here somewhat in the next quarter. But I -- we haven't really heard back yet, but I do think it'll pick up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe one last quick one. Could you collect any nonrecurring cost related to the Advance Partners acquisition, either the deal or integration costs?
componenttext: Got it. And maybe one last quick one. Could you collect any nonrecurring cost related to the Advance Partners acquisition, either the deal or integration costs?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: There weren't any integration costs, but obviously, our expenses were higher. I think I called it out in the comments that essentially in the quarter, the additional revenue from Advance Partners was matched by the additional expense. So it's recurring. I
componenttext: There weren't any integration costs, but obviously, our expenses were higher. I think I called it out in the comments that essentially in the quarter, the additional revenue from Advance Partners was matched by the additional expense. So it's recurring. It's not nonrecurring. But it's in those numbers.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg of Jeffrey's.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg of Jeffrey's.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Kerry calling in for Jason. Just wanted to ask a question on the growth of the core payroll business in the quarter, which came a little bit below where we had modeled. I know you called out growth in the quarter to be at the low end of the f
componenttext: This is Ryan Kerry calling in for Jason. Just wanted to ask a question on the growth of the core payroll business in the quarter, which came a little bit below where we had modeled. I know you called out growth in the quarter to be at the low end of the full year range in kind of the 4% to 5%. Once I exclude the benefit from Advance, it looks like the growth is more in that 3% range. So first, is this the right way to be thinking about this? And second, anything in particular that was a drag in the quarter? And the just lastly, how should we think about the full year guidance range? Should we now expect maybe at the lower end of the range?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you packed Ryan a lot of questions in one sentence. So let me unpack that. So I think you're right that about 3% is correct. In my comments, I called out specifically that the driver of that being the 3%, which by the way, is up sequentially from last
componenttext: So you packed Ryan a lot of questions in one sentence. So let me unpack that. So I think you're right that about 3% is correct. In my comments, I called out specifically that the driver of that being the 3%, which by the way, is up sequentially from last -- from the comparable quarter a year ago where we were a little bit over 2%, really was driven by checks. And there's 2 things that happened because I'll get a number questions of this -- on the call. Third quarter is unusual compared to every other quarter in the year because third quarter is a quarter where you have more checks than normal due to the bonus checks. There's simply no way to figure it out. I have spent a lot of time looking at dollars to figure out whether they equate to checks. So we don't know whether there just may have been lower checked by in part because of bonus checks. And then the second thing that I called out is our client mix was a little bit lower in the quarter than we modeled. And so the combination of both of those drove the rate down a little bit. We'll have to see whether that's a trend that continues. In part, there's a good point to that. Our unit sales growth is, at this point, trending about 2x double what it was last year. So when you have that, you tend to have a mix that does skews a little bit lower. And then one other point that I would make on that is that the way that we report numbers, what you see is payroll is simply the portion of a bundle that is payroll. It really says nothing literally until you can aggregate so that the non-payroll portion of the sales that are made in the mid-market. And there, we saw some nice pickup in the quarter. So I think that the short of it, after I've said all of that, checks were a little bit lighter in the quarter than we anticipated. We'll see whether that's a trend that continues. Client mix skewed a little bit smaller than we had projected, but we'll see where we go from here. And no, when I say those of you will know when we talk about guidance, when I say it's between 4 and 5, you can peg where we expect it to be.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I believe in the last couple of calls you've called out new bookings growth kind of in that low double digits range. How should we think of this trend through the key selling season? Would you say it's roughly in line with where it's has b
componenttext: Great. And then I believe in the last couple of calls you've called out new bookings growth kind of in that low double digits range. How should we think of this trend through the key selling season? Would you say it's roughly in line with where it's has been the past couple of quarters? Any color would be appreciated.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we were pleased with the selling season. And I think year-to-date, we've continued to see that double-digit, low double-digit growth. So happy and it's kind of across-the-board so for the different divisions. So we're feeling good about it.
componenttext: Yes. I think we were pleased with the selling season. And I think year-to-date, we've continued to see that double-digit, low double-digit growth. So happy and it's kind of across-the-board so for the different divisions. So we're feeling good about it.

componenttextpreview: And you highlighted lastly that you refer to middle market a few times is really a particular area of strength. And I think you talked about time and attendance in that bucket. But can you just, I guess, where are you seeing strength in middle market? And
componenttext: And you highlighted lastly that you refer to middle market a few times is really a particular area of strength. And I think you talked about time and attendance in that bucket. But can you just, I guess, where are you seeing strength in middle market? And can you remind us maybe at this point how big that is? And I guess, how much more quickly is that growing than given the core overall business, I guess, to add some perspective.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I'll take that. It's -- I think what we're excited about is I think we're seeing the payout for all the technology investment that we've made. And so with Flex having added that full product suite, we're selling a lot more -- we're selling more clien
componenttext: Tim, I'll take that. It's -- I think what we're excited about is I think we're seeing the payout for all the technology investment that we've made. And so with Flex having added that full product suite, we're selling a lot more -- we're selling more clients and we're selling a lot more full bundled clients with full-time and attendance and HR support benefit enrollment, benefit administration, et cetera. So we don't break out the client base specifically, but it is growing. The sales are growing very well year-to-date and at the highest rate that it's been probably since pre-recession. So the mid-market has come on very strong year-to-date and certainly, seeing that growth stronger than on the small end. All sales are doing well year-to-date, but that's the strongest we've seen.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: In light of the commentary on strong sales retention remaining, I guess stable, but at a very good level, I guess, I struggle to think through how we should think about what that means for service revenue growth. Because if we adjust last year for the cha
componenttext: In light of the commentary on strong sales retention remaining, I guess stable, but at a very good level, I guess, I struggle to think through how we should think about what that means for service revenue growth. Because if we adjust last year for the change in PEO presentation, it really doesn't look like we've seen any acceleration in service revenue growth and if you back out the acquisition this quarter, one might even argue you've seen modest deceleration in the last quarter or 2 [ph] versus last year's trends. How should the better bookings and stable retention flow-through? I know you don't want to talk about 2017 at this point, but is there any reason that we shouldn't expect that all positive stuff you talked about is going to lead to the top line growth accelerating on an organic basis?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say Q3 is kind of a weird quarter in the sense that there's always some elements of timing in it. And if I just pick on the quarter and project Q3 forward and say what do you assume about that, I think you got to add in Q4 to get a better picture. Bec
componenttext: I'd say Q3 is kind of a weird quarter in the sense that there's always some elements of timing in it. And if I just pick on the quarter and project Q3 forward and say what do you assume about that, I think you got to add in Q4 to get a better picture. Because the back half fix tells a better picture and sequentially, Q4's going to be stronger than Q3. But I think you need to take both of those quarters together. And that gives you more accurate picture of where the company's going. And I think that obviously, you've got projections and there's 3 projections out there and they seem reasonably in line with what we expect is going to happen. And then we'll issue guidance off of that. So I don't -- this is not a business that we're -- where you can protect one quarter to tell you what the rest of years going to look like because there's always elements of timing, when days fall. For example, this quarter ended on a Monday. Whether the quarter end on a Monday or Thursday can have some impacts on revenue. So I'd say you really need to look at 3 and 4 to kind of form a better opinion.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough.
componenttext: Okay, fair enough.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we're pleased. Just one other thing, Gary. When we look at the key indicators. So before this call, I listed 12 key indicators. I'm looking at client base. I'm looking at discounting. I'm looking at net client growth. I'm looking at sales units. I'm l
componenttext: But we're pleased. Just one other thing, Gary. When we look at the key indicators. So before this call, I listed 12 key indicators. I'm looking at client base. I'm looking at discounting. I'm looking at net client growth. I'm looking at sales units. I'm looking at sales, annualized sales revenue. I mean, every vector was pointing in the right direction. The only item in the quarter that was a little bit lighter than we anticipated was checks. And there's some variability in that. So it doesn't concern me significantly.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just I've asked you this before, but I feel like [indiscernible] ask it. You have the strength and bookings. We've seen it from a lot of other HR outsourcing companies. And I think at some level, Affordable Care Act has led companies
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just I've asked you this before, but I feel like [indiscernible] ask it. You have the strength and bookings. We've seen it from a lot of other HR outsourcing companies. And I think at some level, Affordable Care Act has led companies a lot of businesses to take a fresh look outsource more and it's not just BAC compliance. Of everything broadly, PEO and others have benefited. Do you have any better sense at this point if any of that has been pulling forward future sales or there's risk of now having some point next year of comp this very strong growth of booking [ph] and it gets a lot more difficult. Or what you're hearing from your sales force and what not lead you to believe more that this is going to be a sustainable trend of more outsource.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I think it certainly has pulled some sales forward for clients who may not have made the choice to outsource before the Affordable Care Act kind of pushed them into it. By a also big in a general sense that we talked about the last
componenttext: That's a good question. I think it certainly has pulled some sales forward for clients who may not have made the choice to outsource before the Affordable Care Act kind of pushed them into it. By a also big in a general sense that we talked about the last few years, you see the need for HR and the acceptance of outsourcing and going to an HR administration and a SaaS-based product for time and attendance, HR administration benefit enrollment, payroll. We've seen that certainly come down in size from 50 employees to 100 employees down below 50. So I think there's still plenty of opportunity to have strong sales even if not just the Affordable Care Act. So we still feel good about the opportunity for future sales because of the demand has come down. So meaning more clients are interested in it and gaining value from it. And the fact that I think we've invested very timely in our products and service model to be able to respond to that increased demand.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one last one for me. If I'm doing the math right on Advance Partners, it looks like you paid a pretty healthy multiple $0.08 or $0.09 [ph] in 2020 [ph] EBITDAR or something like that for this business. I guess, can you just give us a
componenttext: Great. And then just one last one for me. If I'm doing the math right on Advance Partners, it looks like you paid a pretty healthy multiple $0.08 or $0.09 [ph] in 2020 [ph] EBITDAR or something like that for this business. I guess, can you just give us a better sense of how you justify that price as a reasonable price and particularly given how your cyclical and market it operates and, how confident are you that they can continue to grow the business at the rates that they are doing?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Gary, I think your numbers are off. So let me just correct your assumption. So we actually paid somewhere between 4 and 5x revenue for it. And we paid less than 10x EBITDA for it. So we don't typically overpay. So that's part A. So I think the number
componenttext: Hey, Gary, I think your numbers are off. So let me just correct your assumption. So we actually paid somewhere between 4 and 5x revenue for it. And we paid less than 10x EBITDA for it. So we don't typically overpay. So that's part A. So I think the numbers are slightly off. The second part is we are not in the staffing business and we have no interest in being in the staffing business. But we have a lot of interest in providing back-office services to the staffing business because we think, from a secular growth perspective and Marty alluded to it earlier in his comments, we think staffing is nothing but go up. Part A. Part B is there's lots of small and medium-sized staffing firms and those of you who covered that industry know that. And for every large staffing company, there's always spinoffs that need financing and funding and back-office services. So we had looked at this transaction literally for 3 years before we pulled the trigger to convince ourselves that the growth rates are real and that there's an opportunity for someone with the right kind of both service and capital availability to come in and make an impact. So we are very, very comfortable about both of those issues. And that's really what drove the transaction. And so far, so good.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've heard the comments about the mid-market being strong. Just curious, the low end and then the high end, any changes in the dynamics of the market, especially competitively that you guys saw in the key selling season?
componenttext: I've heard the comments about the mid-market being strong. Just curious, the low end and then the high end, any changes in the dynamics of the market, especially competitively that you guys saw in the key selling season?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Not really, Brian. We're not seeing much change from a competitive standpoint, frankly, in any of the markets. We focus primarily on that small to midsize and up to 1,000, primarily, I'd say up to 500 or so. And again, very strong in the mid-market.
componenttext: Yes. Not really, Brian. We're not seeing much change from a competitive standpoint, frankly, in any of the markets. We focus primarily on that small to midsize and up to 1,000, primarily, I'd say up to 500 or so. And again, very strong in the mid-market. And the low-end was kind of as expected in a typical selling season. As Efrain and we've both mentioned, year-to-date our net client gain is the best it's been since prerecession levels. So we're feeling good about not only the sales side of it, but also the retention.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then just thinking about this key selling season, how did net pricing look? How did that come out for the quarter and for year-to-date?
componenttext: Okay. Then just thinking about this key selling season, how did net pricing look? How did that come out for the quarter and for year-to-date?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think, Brian, pricing is always competitive during the selling season. This was no difference. And as I mentioned in a number of meetings, we discount during the quarter at a level that's appropriate to get the business. And then over time, if you
componenttext: Look, I think, Brian, pricing is always competitive during the selling season. This was no difference. And as I mentioned in a number of meetings, we discount during the quarter at a level that's appropriate to get the business. And then over time, if you deliver service, you have a chance to recoup that discount. And so I would say it was comparable to what we've seen in prior years. Yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally for me. On checks per client, I know they moderated and I think I understand that for the third quarter. What does that mean for the fourth quarter? Does it bounce back? Or does it say stay at this depressed level?
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally for me. On checks per client, I know they moderated and I think I understand that for the third quarter. What does that mean for the fourth quarter? Does it bounce back? Or does it say stay at this depressed level?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't use depression, but I use the word moderated. Look, I don't completely -- I can't completely answer that question because bonus checks, as I mentioned earlier, in Q3, have an impact. So it could be that we see a little bit lighter checks per cl
componenttext: I wouldn't use depression, but I use the word moderated. Look, I don't completely -- I can't completely answer that question because bonus checks, as I mentioned earlier, in Q3, have an impact. So it could be that we see a little bit lighter checks per client going into the fourth quarter because of client mix. But I would assume that'll be a little bit lighter than what we had initially projected in Q4.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta of North Coast Resorts.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta of North Coast Resorts.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a little bit about the Advance Partner's acquisition. Is this in opposition were you talked about the temp business growing? Is this a business that you anticipate growing organically by using your balance sheet and your distribution? Or i
componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit about the Advance Partner's acquisition. Is this in opposition were you talked about the temp business growing? Is this a business that you anticipate growing organically by using your balance sheet and your distribution? Or is this something where you have to go acquire some other companies and other geographies to build a little bit of scale for this business?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think primarily it's organically. There may be some opportunity, just like they would have if they were on their own to acquire other companies and they'll always look at that just like we are better in that kind of business. But organically, what we sa
componenttext: I think primarily it's organically. There may be some opportunity, just like they would have if they were on their own to acquire other companies and they'll always look at that just like we are better in that kind of business. But organically, what we saw was great leadership team that had been producing solid growth and it fits our market. It's small and midsized staffing companies that they provide everything from payroll funding to payroll outsourcing to HR support. And we think it's a good fit. And we saw their clients that a growing industry with their clients when we started getting into this, we were surprised that the thousands of small independent staffing firms that needed that support. And we thought they were providing a great product and add lots of growth opportunities. When you couple that with the fact that we have a number of staffing companies as clients independent staffing companies as payroll clients, we now, I think can take to our clients additional product and services so that they offer you can that'll help their growth even more. So we saw it as a really good fit, not only from a product to service market and a leadership team vantage point.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Efrain, if you're in a very enviable position, you have a balance sheet with almost $700 million in cash, no debt. I saw you bought back some shares this quarter. I guess, going forward, what's up? What's the strategy? Do you think you would con
componenttext: And then, Efrain, if you're in a very enviable position, you have a balance sheet with almost $700 million in cash, no debt. I saw you bought back some shares this quarter. I guess, going forward, what's up? What's the strategy? Do you think you would continue buying back shares? Or is this price kind of where the stock is? Prevent that? Or are there acquisition opportunities? Or is there anything changing in that environment that would allow you to take advantage of maybe acquiring a company?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 3 questions. First, I would say this that when you look at the results for the quarter, EPS was up 9% and shares were down. So we've been slowly whittling away at the share count and would anticipate. That would be flat to modestly down in the fut
componenttext: Yes. So 3 questions. First, I would say this that when you look at the results for the quarter, EPS was up 9% and shares were down. So we've been slowly whittling away at the share count and would anticipate. That would be flat to modestly down in the future. So what we do have, we added share buybacks into our capital distribution approach. But currently, the second point is that -- and Advance is one example of it. So for a number of years, you've heard us say that we wanted to keep some powder to be able to quickly to do some acquisitions. Pipes and robust as it's really been in the last 3 or 4 years. And there are a number of acquisitions that we're looking at that could consume much all or even more of that cash. And so we prefer, at this point, until that pipeline dries up, to focus on the right kinds of selective M&A as a use of that cash. If in the next 12 months, those opportunities don't materialize, then we'll have that discussion. Marty and I have had that discussion with the board. At this point part A is due to M&A and part B will be -- we'll reach that when M&A is no longer an opportunity.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from S.K. Prasad Borra of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from S.K. Prasad Borra of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple if I may. First, probably on just the revenue stability. Has anything changed this year compared to, say, the last few years you have seen, specifically from the point of view that the unit growth you're talking about, that seems to have closed o
componenttext: A couple if I may. First, probably on just the revenue stability. Has anything changed this year compared to, say, the last few years you have seen, specifically from the point of view that the unit growth you're talking about, that seems to have closed or double. What have you seen last year. Your revenue -- your retention seems to be pretty stable. So what should stop from payroll growth to accelerate in the next few quarters?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So,, just a few points on that. I think we had been very effective at the low end of the market in capturing units as compared to last year. In order to have significant growth in unit acceleration, that would be visible in 2, 3 quarters. We need to have
componenttext: So,, just a few points on that. I think we had been very effective at the low end of the market in capturing units as compared to last year. In order to have significant growth in unit acceleration, that would be visible in 2, 3 quarters. We need to have sustained -- continued sustained unit growth. And we look at strategies that drive that. And we're fairly unique in that. We play both in the micro space with everything from SurePayroll to the mid-market space with our Paychex Flex integrated solutions. So we'll have to have a number of continued strong quarters in terms of unit growth to drive that higher. But one thing I want to emphasize, which I said earlier. For us, as we think about payroll service revenue growth, increasingly, what we think about is HCM platform service growth, and we're seeing that already. You see that in the HRS numbers. What our salespeople do -- a salesperson in our 1 to 50 or small-market sales force, they are not simply selling a payroll only solution. They are increasingly selling a bundled HCM solution. And we're seeing benefits from that. The benefits don't flow into the payroll service revenue line because the portion of the HCM platform, particularly HR administration and time and attendance, where we've seen really good growth, really is reflected in HRS. So I think were seeing a bit of both and we're going to focus on both driving revenue by selling more integrated HCM and also, driving units by approaching that smaller market aggressively.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Probably just one on the cost side. Marty, you also mentioned that the implementation cost have slightly been higher compared to recent quarters. Are you broadly now capturing that in terms of your headcount increase? And would you expect the
componenttext: Okay. Great. Probably just one on the cost side. Marty, you also mentioned that the implementation cost have slightly been higher compared to recent quarters. Are you broadly now capturing that in terms of your headcount increase? And would you expect the implementation cost to stabilize now, especially the ones related to ACA? Or do you expect that to inflect [ph] higher over the next few quarters?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it stabilized at this point. I mean, unless we have a big influx of new sales, but I think this was the most difficult quarter to get through in getting all of the first time going through getting all the 1095 C [ph] forms out and so forth. So we
componenttext: I think it stabilized at this point. I mean, unless we have a big influx of new sales, but I think this was the most difficult quarter to get through in getting all of the first time going through getting all the 1095 C [ph] forms out and so forth. So we ramped up for that. I think that will be -- I'm not sure that that will decrease necessarily at this stage, but I don't think -- I think we've ramped up and I think we're holding pretty well at this stage. And then the additional any other additional headcount will really depend on sales and the number of that clients that we're adding. Obviously, we said the net client gain is better than last year, better than we've seen in a few years. And so that may drive some headcount, but I don't see any big jump over what we've already done.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Togut of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Togut of Evercore ISI.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on the strength in the mid-market. I'm trying to piece together what you're seeing with what ADP is seeing. For example, they called out an unusual drop in client retention in the December quarter, particularly tied to lower than ex
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the strength in the mid-market. I'm trying to piece together what you're seeing with what ADP is seeing. For example, they called out an unusual drop in client retention in the December quarter, particularly tied to lower than expected transition from a legacy platform to their cloud-based workforce now. So I'm just trying to understand, is the strength in the mid-market somehow tied to this probably short-term drop that client retention at ADP? Or do you think it's all related to upgrades related to Flex?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's more the upgrades really to Flex. So I think we're holding and we're maintaining a good retention in our mid-market clients, but the sales have increased. So it hasn't and it hasn't been -- I don't think from any one competitor. I think
componenttext: Yes. I think it's more the upgrades really to Flex. So I think we're holding and we're maintaining a good retention in our mid-market clients, but the sales have increased. So it hasn't and it hasn't been -- I don't think from any one competitor. I think we're doing well against our main competitor there, but I think we're winning -- we're just winning more because the product and the service levels are better. So I don't think -- and it doesn't feel like a one-time thing to me. The sales have accelerated and shown consistency.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: When specifically did sales start accelerating in mid-market?
componenttext: When specifically did sales start accelerating in mid-market?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pretty much in the last 2 quarters, but I think mostly this quarter as you get to year-end, it's a little bit skewed. But really, we got to the point last fall, September, October, when we really had kind of the full suite brought into the Software-as-a-S
componenttext: Pretty much in the last 2 quarters, but I think mostly this quarter as you get to year-end, it's a little bit skewed. But really, we got to the point last fall, September, October, when we really had kind of the full suite brought into the Software-as-a-Service product with Flex. We added the complete time and attendance and benefit administration enrollment in the electronic paperless on boarding really kind of came together on a single employee record in the September, October time frame. And that is when we started to start pick up speed.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen of Wells Fargo.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a little bit on the HR outsourcing side and the PEO and ASO. Just sort of what are you seeing on demand in client's acceptance of one versus the other? Are you seeing more clients move to the full service PEO model rather than ASO? Just
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a little bit on the HR outsourcing side and the PEO and ASO. Just sort of what are you seeing on demand in client's acceptance of one versus the other? Are you seeing more clients move to the full service PEO model rather than ASO? Just kind of get that dynamic between the 2 of those and then just more on the demand, which I believe was strong in the PEO.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we haven't really seen a big shift there, maybe a little bit leaning toward the PEO, given the fact that the Affordable Care Act requirements. But I think we're still seeing sales both sides grow pretty well. It's just a preference. And that'
componenttext: Yes. I think we haven't really seen a big shift there, maybe a little bit leaning toward the PEO, given the fact that the Affordable Care Act requirements. But I think we're still seeing sales both sides grow pretty well. It's just a preference. And that's why we feel very good that we have sales and service folks that kind of handle both. So they really respond to the client needs and what the best fit is. You still see PEO predominantly in certain states where there's a comfort level with it and there's just better knowledge of it. But we're seeing that expand to a few other states. But it's still primarily in those PEO states as I guess I'd say.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then just one follow-up. We've read in the press some stories about funding getting tougher for startups in certain situations. 2 parts to the question. I guess, first, what impact if any does that have on your client base and the growth in new client opp
componenttext: Then just one follow-up. We've read in the press some stories about funding getting tougher for startups in certain situations. 2 parts to the question. I guess, first, what impact if any does that have on your client base and the growth in new client opportunities for you? And then second, what impact might that have on the competitive environment out there for you guys?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would start by saying, I haven't, we haven't heard or seen it get that much more difficult. I think some small business lenders have come down. But there's been actually -- it's always difficult to fund new startups. And the hardest -- the biggest
componenttext: Yes. I would start by saying, I haven't, we haven't heard or seen it get that much more difficult. I think some small business lenders have come down. But there's been actually -- it's always difficult to fund new startups. And the hardest -- the biggest hit to that was the drop in the home equity because that's really how a lot of these got started and that happened back in the recession. So if anything, I think some of that has come back and not so much tightened. Now you've got also an explosion of online offerings that will provide lending to small businesses if they have some credit. So I don't -- we haven't seen that have much of an impact on us at all. There was really a big impact in the recession and I think that has slowly come back Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just a couple of the little bit more color on that just to build on what Marty said. I mentioned earlier that payroll sales or sales units this year are trending above last year. Actually sales units are growing about twice the rate that they did las
componenttext: Yes. Just a couple of the little bit more color on that just to build on what Marty said. I mentioned earlier that payroll sales or sales units this year are trending above last year. Actually sales units are growing about twice the rate that they did last year -- sales units, not client base. But what's interesting is when you disaggregate that number, our sales units from new business startups actually were up about 7% in the quarter. So it looks like the environment -- and that's a good development for us because obviously, 50% or more of our sales in a given quarter come from newly started businesses. So that's a good development and since the environment is good for sales.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim and Donald of Analysis.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim and Donald of Analysis.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of follow-up questions on Advance Partners. I think I heard that the impact on the payroll side of less than 1% and I couldn't quite hear the impact -- there's also an impact on the HR segment. Is that slightly more than 1%?
componenttext: I had a couple of follow-up questions on Advance Partners. I think I heard that the impact on the payroll side of less than 1% and I couldn't quite hear the impact -- there's also an impact on the HR segment. Is that slightly more than 1%?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's slightly more than 1%.
componenttext: Yes, it's slightly more than 1%.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. And so on Advance Partners, what kind of integration plan do you have? And what kind of timing to maybe bring it to the rest of your client base?
componenttext: Yes. Okay. And so on Advance Partners, what kind of integration plan do you have? And what kind of timing to maybe bring it to the rest of your client base?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, we're already in process of -- we've identified the clients that we have that are independent staffing agencies. We're working with the sales team at Advance to get them out and talking to them where they already have a relationship with Paychex
componenttext: Yes, Jim, we're already in process of -- we've identified the clients that we have that are independent staffing agencies. We're working with the sales team at Advance to get them out and talking to them where they already have a relationship with Paychex and now we'll see this as an additional offering. I mean, it's early-stage. We closed at the end of December. But I think we've already been working on having identified the clients, get them in the hands of the sales team, make sure the sales team understand and be very careful with how they approach those clients because their Paychex clients who we're trying to approach but offer them additional services and support. And I don't -- as Efrain said earlier, we don't see any big one-time integration cost for this. It's another great thing about the acquisition and bringing them into the Paychex family. And we saw ongoing expansion and ongoing revenue and expense, but no big one-time integration cost. It's really just bringing the groups together.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: By the way, Jim, just to point. I was asked earlier about specific integration costs in the quarter. There were modest amount, maybe between $1 million and $2 million in the quarter. We just absorbed it. Didn't call it out especially in the numbers, but i
componenttext: By the way, Jim, just to point. I was asked earlier about specific integration costs in the quarter. There were modest amount, maybe between $1 million and $2 million in the quarter. We just absorbed it. Didn't call it out especially in the numbers, but it was just not important.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe just one follow-up. So do you have expect to be able to accelerate Advance Partners growth now that you bring them into your base?
componenttext: Great. And maybe just one follow-up. So do you have expect to be able to accelerate Advance Partners growth now that you bring them into your base?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hope so. I mean, we certainly would model it that way. As we did the acquisition, we felt that they had good growth, but they were somewhat limited from a capital perspective obviously, and from a cash perspective for their funding -- for the fund
componenttext: Yes, we hope so. I mean, we certainly would model it that way. As we did the acquisition, we felt that they had good growth, but they were somewhat limited from a capital perspective obviously, and from a cash perspective for their funding -- for the funding of their clients and the work that they do and then just the client base that we have, I think between those 2, we do expect to be help them accelerate their growth.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Silber of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Silber of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick follow-up questions. Marty, at the beginning of the call, I think you said that year-to-date, you've seen your best client gains since the recession. Are you talking about total clients? Talking payroll clients? HR clients? Can you jus
componenttext: Just a couple quick follow-up questions. Marty, at the beginning of the call, I think you said that year-to-date, you've seen your best client gains since the recession. Are you talking about total clients? Talking payroll clients? HR clients? Can you just qualify that a little bit.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's payroll clients. We always kind of talk about it as payroll clients. And so it's net client gain of the total payroll base, the one that we give kind of once a year at the end of year will give the base. And year-to-date, we've seen the best cl
componenttext: Sure, it's payroll clients. We always kind of talk about it as payroll clients. And so it's net client gain of the total payroll base, the one that we give kind of once a year at the end of year will give the base. And year-to-date, we've seen the best client gain -- net client gain because of the combination of both better sales and solid retention since the recession.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: And Jeff, we typically or have been saying that we'll be between 1 and 3. And if you look at our numbers, we've been slightly under 2 the prior years. And we're trending pretty solidly between 2 and 3. So it takes a while for the client base of 600,000 clients to grow, but we feel pretty good about where we're at.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. I just wanted to double check on that. And then, Efrain, you were asked about the purchase price for Advance Partners. headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Backward looking. So it would've been -- it would've been their calendar 2015, which of course, you don't have any access to. But yes, so we acquired them right at the end of December and we paid between 4 and 5x revenue. But I would just say this about A
componenttext: Backward looking. So it would've been -- it would've been their calendar 2015, which of course, you don't have any access to. But yes, so we acquired them right at the end of December and we paid between 4 and 5x revenue. But I would just say this about Advance. And they've done a phenomenal job. The are very, very few businesses that we looked at. And we have looked at many, many, whose EBITDA margins are at/or exceed Paychex's. So obviously, that got our attention.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So, no, Jeff. So part of the -- you'll see when we do the 2 disclosures, we settle it out. We paid off an existing loan that they had. Chose to not refund it. We'll fund it again. That's the way the business works. But then we acquired a number of receivables that basically offset the amount of the loan. So on a net basis, when you filter through that, that's what I'm talking about. It will have a disclosure in the Q, which we'll file at the end of the day. It's pretty exclusive.

componenttext: Sorry, to ask another question on growth. So late in the call here. But just looking at the numbers that appear and if my math is right, that Advance have about 60 basis points to the service growth to the year, but we maintain the guidance for the year for service revenue growth. That said, momentum of the businesses remained pretty strong and your tone is very positive. So I guess, I understand the timing issue with bookings amongst other things that you mentioned. But I guess, I'm still having a little trouble reconciling your tone and then with the guide for the year vis-a-vis the acquisition. So if you feel you've already addressed this, we can take this offline or if you anything incremental to add that may clarify it, that would be great.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I get it, David. I understand the point you're making. So I think I said it at the -- in my comments that we expected the guide for revenue to be at the high end of the range. And I'm not going to call out a 10 or 20 basis point difference. So obvious
componenttext: No, I get it, David. I understand the point you're making. So I think I said it at the -- in my comments that we expected the guide for revenue to be at the high end of the range. And I'm not going to call out a 10 or 20 basis point difference. So obviously, when we guide to 7 to 8, we think we're going to be somewhere in the middle of the range at the beginning of the year. I don't know where the 60 basis points is exactly correct. It's not probably directionally all that far off. But now I'm into discussing whether it's going to be 8.1 or 7.9. It's just too close to call, especially because, as I mentioned, checks were a little bit softer. So I'm a little bit cautious about kind of where we end up in Q4. But that's the color on that number. The trends are strong.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the dynamic between the strength of the market and how quarter payroll versus HRS. So is that dynamic then continuing to fiscal '17? So you see that you would probably see better HRS growth on a relative basis in payroll because of that mix dy
componenttext: And then on the dynamic between the strength of the market and how quarter payroll versus HRS. So is that dynamic then continuing to fiscal '17? So you see that you would probably see better HRS growth on a relative basis in payroll because of that mix dynamic?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, David. And look, frankly, just to kind of expand on that, and you've covered the company for a long time. 10 years ago, what we did was we saw a payroll sales person, either in the small-market. Sold payroll. That's what they sold. And
componenttext: Yes, that's right, David. And look, frankly, just to kind of expand on that, and you've covered the company for a long time. 10 years ago, what we did was we saw a payroll sales person, either in the small-market. Sold payroll. That's what they sold. And then if there were ancillaries, they were sold by an ancillary sales force. That was the product we had. I would say in the last 5 years, certainly since Marty was CEO, that dynamic has changed pretty significantly. Our financials reflect the old dynamic, not the new one. And the new dynamic is this. 2 things. Much, much better sales efficiency so that when Mark has a client of a certain type that we've identified, it's a team sale. But we've already discussed that in prior calls. What's changed really over the last 18 months is that a small-market payroll salesperson has -- is able to sell a HCM bundled product. And they are increasingly doing that. Meaning, our payroll sales people who used to sell payroll only, now sell products that are actually included in the HRS revenue, which is time and attendance and also HR administration. So it is very, very possible that total revenue can grow nicely and payroll service revenue doesn't seem to be moving up significantly. And that's a function of where the technology has been and where the market is heading. So we're going to have to figure out how we represent that a little bit more clearly. I think it is the case as we put more emphasis on selling more integrated bundles that you could very well see payroll service revenue not growing quite as fast, but you've seen sustained growth in HRS because that's where the other components of the HCM revenue are being recorded. It wasn't a big deal several years ago. It's a bigger deal now.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Yes. It's going to be outstanding at any given time. And by the way, just in the side, David, because I think it's a great question. One of the things that we looked at, they've been around for 20 years. And obviously, I -- not I. We had looked at the acquisition very carefully. They had very, very few problems because they have very, very expensive credit process and we have a really first rate group that also does that. So we got -- and there's a lot of safeguards that go into what we do.

componenttext: Couple of quick follow-ups. First of all, you said that the retention rate has improved. Can you give us a little bit of feel for how much it's improved?

componenttext: Yes. And actually, when we look at net client gain, retention has held pretty steady, which has been around our best ever. So we're right near our best-ever retention. It hasn't really improved all that much, but it's holding very well, even if the client -- even if the sales have gone up. So we feel very good about that. Because sometimes as the sales increase, obviously, retention becomes more difficult, as we're bringing in more clients. The sales have gone up, the retention I'd say, has kind of stayed pretty level at its best ever that we saw last year.

componenttext: Great. And with regards to comments on the mid-market, can you just quantify what portion of the mid-market you're seeing the strongest growth in? In other words, small-market is up to 50 employees. And is it the 50 to 100? 50 to 200? How would you characterize that area that you're seeing the best growth in?

componenttext: Yes, Marty, I'll probably go fairly broader [ph]. But it's 50 -- I'd say, 50 to 300. That's where the most and new activity is I think when you see it because that's where this need, particularly with the ACA compliance, [indiscernible] come down and more are outsourcing and interested in outsourcing. So I think that's where we're seeing probably the biggest jump. It's not in the 500 plus. I'll say, 300 plus, 250 plus. We're still doing fine there, but the acceleration has been more that 50 to 250 or 300.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Great. And given all your comments with regards to selling additional modules. componenttext: I think, no, I feel pretty good about it. You'll never know but at this stage, the only question will then be the, we call it, ESR, would be ACA compliance does that catch that second wave or not? But overall, I think you may see a second wave in ACA as well as health and benefit insurance. For more people needing insurance, we may catch some wave there. But the 401(k), the PEO, ASO, all seem pretty steady. And as Efrain said, a lot of our bundled products on low and mid, being HR administration, on boarding time and attendance, all seem to be very continuing to be very strong. So, yes, I would expect that.
