componenttext: Excluding interest?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay. I just wanted to be clear.
componenttext: All right. Okay. I just wanted to be clear.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, no. I get your question. Thanks for clarifying.
componenttext: Yes. No, no. I get your question. Thanks for clarifying.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you highlighted -- lastly, you've referred to middle market a few times as really a particular area of strength, and I think you talked about time and attendance in that bucket. But can you just -- I guess, where are you seeing strength in
componenttext: Okay. And then you highlighted -- lastly, you've referred to middle market a few times as really a particular area of strength, and I think you talked about time and attendance in that bucket. But can you just -- I guess, where are you seeing strength in middle market? And can you remind us maybe at this point how big that is? And I guess, how much more quickly is that growing than even the core overall business, I guess, to have some perspective?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tim, I'll take that. It's a -- I think what we're excited about is, I think, we're seeing the payoff for all the technology investment that we've made. And so with Flex having added that full product suite, we're selling a lot more of -- we're sellin
componenttext: Yes. Tim, I'll take that. It's a -- I think what we're excited about is, I think, we're seeing the payoff for all the technology investment that we've made. And so with Flex having added that full product suite, we're selling a lot more of -- we're selling more clients, and we're selling a lot more full-bundled clients with full time and attendance and HR support benefit enrollment, benefit administration, et cetera. So we're -- we don't break out the client base, specifically, but it is growing. It is -- the sales are growing very well year-to-date and at the highest rate that it's been probably since prerecession. So the mid-market has come on very strong year-to-date and certainly seeing that growth stronger than on the small end. All sales are doing well year-to-date, but that's the strongest we're -- we've seen.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just in light of the commentary on strong sales, retention remaining, I guess, stable but at a very good level, I guess I struggle to think through how we should think about what that means for service revenue growth. Because if we adjust, last year, for
componenttext: Just in light of the commentary on strong sales, retention remaining, I guess, stable but at a very good level, I guess I struggle to think through how we should think about what that means for service revenue growth. Because if we adjust, last year, for the change in PEO presentation, it really doesn't look like you've seen any acceleration in service revenue growth. And if you back out the acquisition this quarter, one might even argue you've seen modest deceleration in the last quarter or 2 versus last year's trends. So how should the better bookings and stable retention flow through? I know you don't want to talk about 2017 at this point, but is there any reason that we shouldn't expect that all the positive stuff you've talked about is going to lead to the top line growth accelerating on an organic basis?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Gary, I'd say Q3 is kind of a weird quarter in the sense that there's always some elements of timing in it. And if I just pick on the quarter and project Q3 forward and say what do you assume about that, I think you got to add in Q4 to get a better p
componenttext: Yes. Gary, I'd say Q3 is kind of a weird quarter in the sense that there's always some elements of timing in it. And if I just pick on the quarter and project Q3 forward and say what do you assume about that, I think you got to add in Q4 to get a better picture because the back half takes -- tells a better picture. And sequentially, Q4 is going to be stronger than Q3. But I think you need to take both of those quarters together, and that gives you a more accurate picture of where the company is going. And I think that, obviously, you've got projections and there's 3 projections out there, and they seem reasonably in line with what we expect is going to happen. And then we'll issue guidance off of that. So I don't -- this is not a business that -- where you can project one quarter to tell you what the rest of the year is going to look like because there's always elements of timing, when days fall. For example, this quarter ended on a Monday. Whether the quarter ends on a Monday or a Thursday can have some impacts on revenue. So I'd say you really need to look at 3 and 4 to kind of form a better opinion. We're very pleased -- but we're pleased. Just one other thing, Gary. When we look at the key indicators -- so before this call, I looked at 12 key indicators. I'm looking at client base. I'm looking at discounting. I'm looking at net client growth. I'm looking at sales units. I'm looking at sales, annualized sales revenue. I mean every vector was pointing in the right direction. The only item in the quarter that was a little bit lighter than we anticipated was checks. And there's some variability in that, so it doesn't concern me, significantly.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just I've asked you this before, but I feel like I keep needing to ask it. You've had this strength in bookings. We've seen it from a lot of other HR outsourcing companies. And I think at some level, Affordable Care Act has led compa
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just I've asked you this before, but I feel like I keep needing to ask it. You've had this strength in bookings. We've seen it from a lot of other HR outsourcing companies. And I think at some level, Affordable Care Act has led companies to -- a lot of businesses to take a fresh look and decide if they should outsource more. And it's not just the ACA compliance, but I think, broadly, PEO and other have benefited. Do you have any better sense at this point if any of that has been pulling forward future sales or there's risk of now having to, at some point in the next year, comp this very strong growth in bookings you've seen and it gets a lot more difficult? Or are you -- is -- what you're hearing from your sales force and whatnot leads you to believe more that this is going to be a sustainable trend of more desired outsource?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a good question. I think it certainly has pulled some sales forward for clients who may not have made the choice to outsource before the Affordable Care Act kind of pushed them into it. But I also think, in a general sense that we've talked ab
componenttext: Yes. That's a good question. I think it certainly has pulled some sales forward for clients who may not have made the choice to outsource before the Affordable Care Act kind of pushed them into it. But I also think, in a general sense that we've talked about the last few years, you see the need for HR and the acceptance of outsourcing and going to an HR administration and a SaaS-based product for time and attendance, HR administration, benefit enrollment, payroll. We've seen that certainly come down in size from 50 employees to 100 employees down below 50. So I think there's still plenty of opportunity to have strong sales even -- it's not just the Affordable Care Act. So I -- we still feel good about the opportunity for future sales because the demand has come down, so meaning more clients are interested in it and gaining value from it and the fact that I think we've invested very timely in our products and service model to be able to respond to that increased demand.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one last one for me. If I'm doing the math right on Advance Partners, it looks like you paid a pretty healthy multiple, 8 or 9x sales and 20x EBITDA or something like that for this business. I guess, can you just give us a better sens
componenttext: Great. And then just one last one for me. If I'm doing the math right on Advance Partners, it looks like you paid a pretty healthy multiple, 8 or 9x sales and 20x EBITDA or something like that for this business. I guess, can you just give us a better sense how you justify that price as a reasonable price? And particularly given the highly cyclical end market it operates in, how confident are you they can continue to grow the business at the rates that they've been doing?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Hey, Gary, I think your numbers are off. So let me just correct your assumption. So we actually paid somewhere between 4 and 5x revenue for it, and we paid less than 10x EBITDA for it. So we don't typically overpay. So that's part A. So I think the
componenttext: Okay. Hey, Gary, I think your numbers are off. So let me just correct your assumption. So we actually paid somewhere between 4 and 5x revenue for it, and we paid less than 10x EBITDA for it. So we don't typically overpay. So that's part A. So I think the numbers are slightly off. The second part is we are not in the staffing business, and we are not -- have no interest in being in the staffing business. But we have a lot of interest in providing back-office services to the staffing business because we think, from a secular growth perspective, and Marty alluded to it earlier in his comments, we think temp staffing is going to do nothing but go up. Part A. Part B is there's lots of small- and medium-sized staffing firms, and those of you who cover that industry know that. And for every large staffing company, there's always spinoffs that need financing and funding and back-office services. So we had looked at this transaction literally for 3 years before we pulled the trigger to convince ourselves that the growth rates were real and that there's an opportunity for someone with the right kind of both service and capital availability to come in and make an impact. So we are very, very comfortable about both of those issues, and that's really what drove the transaction. And so far, so good.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I heard the comments about the mid-market being strong. Just curious, the low end and then the high end, any changes in the dynamics in the market, especially competitively, that you guys saw in the key selling season?
componenttext: I heard the comments about the mid-market being strong. Just curious, the low end and then the high end, any changes in the dynamics in the market, especially competitively, that you guys saw in the key selling season?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Not really, Bryan. We're not seeing much change from a competitive standpoint, frankly, in any of the markets. We focus primarily on that small to midsize and up to 1,000, and primarily, I'd say, up to 500 or so. And again, very strong on the mid-mar
componenttext: Yes. Not really, Bryan. We're not seeing much change from a competitive standpoint, frankly, in any of the markets. We focus primarily on that small to midsize and up to 1,000, and primarily, I'd say, up to 500 or so. And again, very strong on the mid-market. And the low-end was kind of as expected in a typical selling season. As Efrain -- and we've both mentioned, year-to-date, our net client gain is the best it's been since prerecession levels. So we're feeling good about not only the sales side of it, but also the retention.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just thinking about this key selling season, how did net pricing look? How did that come out for the quarter and for year-to-date?
componenttext: And then just thinking about this key selling season, how did net pricing look? How did that come out for the quarter and for year-to-date?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think, Bryan, pricing is always competitive during the selling season. This was no different. And as I mentioned in a number of meetings, you discount during the quarter at a level that's appropriate to get the business. And then, over time, if yo
componenttext: Look, I think, Bryan, pricing is always competitive during the selling season. This was no different. And as I mentioned in a number of meetings, you discount during the quarter at a level that's appropriate to get the business. And then, over time, if you deliver service, you have a chance to recoup that discount. And so I would say it was comparable to what we've seen in prior years.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally for me, on checks per client, I know they moderated, and I think I understand that for the third quarter. What does that mean for the fourth quarter? Does it bounce back? Or does it say -- stay at this depressed level?
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally for me, on checks per client, I know they moderated, and I think I understand that for the third quarter. What does that mean for the fourth quarter? Does it bounce back? Or does it say -- stay at this depressed level?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't use depression, but I use the word moderated. Look, I don't completely -- I can't completely answer that question because bonus checks, as I mentioned earlier, in Q3 have an impact. So it could be that we see a little bit lighter checks per cli
componenttext: I wouldn't use depression, but I use the word moderated. Look, I don't completely -- I can't completely answer that question because bonus checks, as I mentioned earlier, in Q3 have an impact. So it could be that we see a little bit lighter checks per client going into the fourth quarter because of client mix. But I would assume they'll be a little bit lighter than we had initially projected in Q4.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marty and Efrain, I wanted to ask a little bit about the Advance Partners acquisition. Is this an acquisition where -- you talked about the temp business growing, so is this a business that you anticipate co-growing organically by using your balance sheet
componenttext: Marty and Efrain, I wanted to ask a little bit about the Advance Partners acquisition. Is this an acquisition where -- you talked about the temp business growing, so is this a business that you anticipate co-growing organically by using your balance sheet and your distribution? Or is this something where you have to go acquire some other companies in other geographies to build a little bit of scale for this business?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- well, I think that primarily, it's organically. It's -- there may be some opportunity just like they would have if they were on their own to acquire other companies, and they'll always look at that just like we are that are in that kind of business.
componenttext: I -- well, I think that primarily, it's organically. It's -- there may be some opportunity just like they would have if they were on their own to acquire other companies, and they'll always look at that just like we are that are in that kind of business. But organically, what we saw was a great leadership team that had been producing solid growth, and it fits our market. It's small and midsize staffing companies that they provide everything, from payroll funding to payroll outsourcing to HR support. And then we think it's a good fit. And we saw their clients. That's a growing industry with their clients. We were -- when we started getting into this, we were surprised at the thousands of small independent staffing firms that needed that support. And we thought they were providing a great product and had lots of growth opportunities. When you couple that with the fact that we have a number of staffing companies as clients, independent staffing companies as payroll clients, we now, I think, can take to our clients additional product and services that they offer, and that'll help their growth even more. So we saw it as a really good fit, not only from a product, a service, a market and a leadership team vantage point.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Efrain, you're in a very enviable position. You have a balance sheet with almost $700 million cash, no debt. I saw you bought back some shares this quarter. I guess, going forward, what's up? What's the strategy? Do you think you would continue
componenttext: And then, Efrain, you're in a very enviable position. You have a balance sheet with almost $700 million cash, no debt. I saw you bought back some shares this quarter. I guess, going forward, what's up? What's the strategy? Do you think you would continue buying back shares? Or is this price, kind of where the stock is, prevent that? Or are there acquisition opportunities? Or is there anything changing in that environment that would allow you to take advantage of maybe acquiring a company?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 3 questions. First, I would say this that when you look at the results for the quarter, EPS was up 9% and shares were down. So we've been slowly whittling away at the share count, and would anticipate that will be flat to modestly down in the futu
componenttext: Yes. So 3 questions. First, I would say this that when you look at the results for the quarter, EPS was up 9% and shares were down. So we've been slowly whittling away at the share count, and would anticipate that will be flat to modestly down in the future. So what we do have, we added share buybacks into the -- into our capital distribution approach. But Kartik, the second point is that -- and Advance is one example of it. So for a number of years, you've heard us say that we wanted to keep some powder dry to be able to move quickly to do acquisitions. The pipeline is as robust as it's really been in the last 3 or 4 years. And there are a number of acquisitions that we're looking at that could consume much or all or even more of that cash. And so we prefer, at this point, until that pipeline dries up, to focus on the right kinds of selective M&A as a use of that cash. If in the next 12 months, that -- those opportunities don't materialize, then we'll have that discussion. Marty and I have had that discussion with the board, and at this point, part A is do M&A and then part B will be -- we'll reach that when M&A is no longer an opportunity.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from S.K. Prasad Borra of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from S.K. Prasad Borra of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple, if I may. First, probably on just the revenue visibility. Has anything changed this year compared to, say, the last few years you have seen, specifically from the point of view that the unit growth you're talking about, that seems to have close
componenttext: A couple, if I may. First, probably on just the revenue visibility. Has anything changed this year compared to, say, the last few years you have seen, specifically from the point of view that the unit growth you're talking about, that seems to have close to doubled compared to the trends. What have you seen last year? And your revenue retention seems to be pretty stable. So what should stop from payroll growth to accelerate in the next few quarters?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So S.K., just a few points on that. So I think we had been very effective at the low end of the market in capturing units as compared to last year. In order to have significant growth in unit acceleration that would be visible in 2 or 3 quarters, we need
componenttext: So S.K., just a few points on that. So I think we had been very effective at the low end of the market in capturing units as compared to last year. In order to have significant growth in unit acceleration that would be visible in 2 or 3 quarters, we need to have sustained -- continued sustained unit growth. And we look at strategies that drive that. And we're fairly unique, in that we play both in the micro space, with everything from SurePayroll, to the mid-market space with our Paychex Flex integrated solution. So we'll have to have a number of continued strong quarters in terms of unit growth to drive that higher. But one thing I want to emphasize, which I said earlier. For us, as we think about payroll service revenue growth, increasingly, what we think about is HCM platform service growth, and we're seeing that already. You see that in the HRS numbers. What our salespeople do, a salesperson in our 1 to 50 or small-market sales force, they are not simply selling a payroll-only solution. They are increasingly selling a bundled HCM solution, and we're seeing benefits from that. The benefits don't flow into the payroll service revenue line because the portion of the HCM platform, particularly HR administration and time and attendance, where we're seeing really good growth, really is reflected in HRS. So I think we're seeing a bit of both, and we're going to focus on both driving revenue by selling more integrated HCM and also driving units by approaching that smaller market aggressively.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. Probably just one on the cost side. But Marty, and you also mentioned that the implementation costs have slightly been higher compared to recent quarters. Are you broadly now [ph] capturing that in terms of your headcount increase? And
componenttext: Okay. That's great. Probably just one on the cost side. But Marty, and you also mentioned that the implementation costs have slightly been higher compared to recent quarters. Are you broadly now [ph] capturing that in terms of your headcount increase? And would you expect the implementation costs to stabilize now, especially the ones related to ACA? Or do you expect that to inflect higher over the next few quarters?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's stabilized at this point, I mean, unless we have a big influx of new sales. But I think this was the most difficult quarter to get through in getting all of the -- first time going through getting all the 1095-C forms out and so forth. So we
componenttext: I think it's stabilized at this point, I mean, unless we have a big influx of new sales. But I think this was the most difficult quarter to get through in getting all of the -- first time going through getting all the 1095-C forms out and so forth. So we ramped up for that. I think that will be -- I'm not sure that, that will decrease necessarily at this stage, but I don't think it's -- I think we've ramped up, and I think we're holding pretty well at this stage. And then, the additional -- any other additional headcount will really depend on sales and the number of net clients that we're adding. Obviously, we said that net client gain is better than last year and better than what we've seen in a few years. And so that may drive some headcount, but I don't see any big jump over what we've already done.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Togut of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Togut of Evercore ISI.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on the strength in the mid-market. I'm trying to piece together what you're seeing with what ADP is seeing. For example, they called out an unusual drop in client retention in the December quarter, particularly tied to slower-than-e
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the strength in the mid-market. I'm trying to piece together what you're seeing with what ADP is seeing. For example, they called out an unusual drop in client retention in the December quarter, particularly tied to slower-than-expected transition from a legacy platform to their cloud-based Workforce Now. So I'm just trying to understand, is the strength in the mid-market somehow tied to this probably short-term drop in client retention at ADP? Or do you think it's all related to upgrades related to Flex?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's more the upgrades related to Flex. So I think we're holding and we're maintaining a good retention in our mid-market clients, but the sales have increased. So it hasn't -- and it hasn't been, I don't think, from any one competitor. I thi
componenttext: Yes. I think it's more the upgrades related to Flex. So I think we're holding and we're maintaining a good retention in our mid-market clients, but the sales have increased. So it hasn't -- and it hasn't been, I don't think, from any one competitor. I think we're doing well against our main competitor there, but I think we're winning -- we're just winning more because the product and the service levels are better. So I don't think -- it doesn't feel like a onetime thing to me. The sales have accelerated and shown consistency.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: When specifically did sales start accelerating in mid-market?
componenttext: When specifically did sales start accelerating in mid-market?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pretty much in the last 2 quarters, but I think mostly this quarter, as you get to year-end, it's a little bit skewed. But really, we got to the point last fall, September, October, when we really had kind of the full suite brought into the software-as-a-
componenttext: Pretty much in the last 2 quarters, but I think mostly this quarter, as you get to year-end, it's a little bit skewed. But really, we got to the point last fall, September, October, when we really had kind of the full suite brought into the software-as-a-service product, the Flex. We added the complete time and attendance, and benefit administration enrollment and the electronic paperless onboarding really kind of came together on a single employee record in the September, October time frame. And that is when we started to start pick up speed.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen of Wells Fargo.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a little bit on the HR outsourcing side and the PEO and the ASO. Just sort of what are you seeing on demand in clients' acceptance of one versus the other? Are you seeing more clients move to the full-service PEO model rather than ASO?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a little bit on the HR outsourcing side and the PEO and the ASO. Just sort of what are you seeing on demand in clients' acceptance of one versus the other? Are you seeing more clients move to the full-service PEO model rather than ASO? Just kind of get that dynamics between the 2 of those, and then just more on the demand, which I believe was strong in the PEO.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we haven't really seen a big shift there. Maybe a little bit leaning toward the PEO, given the fact that -- the Affordable Care Act requirements. But I think we're still seeing sales both sides grow pretty well. It's just a preference. And th
componenttext: Yes. I think we haven't really seen a big shift there. Maybe a little bit leaning toward the PEO, given the fact that -- the Affordable Care Act requirements. But I think we're still seeing sales both sides grow pretty well. It's just a preference. And that's why we feel very good that we have sales and service folks that kind of handle both. So they really respond to the client needs and what the best fit is. You still see PEO predominantly in certain states, where there's a comfort level with it and there's just a better knowledge of it. But we're seeing that expand to a few other states. But it's still primarily in those PEO states, as I guess I'd say.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then just one follow-up. We've read in the press some stories about funding getting tougher for startups in certain situations. Two parts to the question. I guess, first, what impact, if any, does that have on your client base and the growth in new client
componenttext: Then just one follow-up. We've read in the press some stories about funding getting tougher for startups in certain situations. Two parts to the question. I guess, first, what impact, if any, does that have on your client base and the growth in new client opportunities for you? And then, second, what impact might that have on the competitive environment out there for you guys?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would start by saying I haven't -- we haven't heard or seen it get that much more difficult. I think some small business lenders have come down. But there's been actually -- it's always difficult to fund new startups. And the hardest -- the biggest
componenttext: Yes. I would start by saying I haven't -- we haven't heard or seen it get that much more difficult. I think some small business lenders have come down. But there's been actually -- it's always difficult to fund new startups. And the hardest -- the biggest hit to that was the drop in the home equity, because that's really how a lot of these got started, and that happened back in the recession. So if anything, I think some of that has come back and not so much tightened. Now you've got also an explosion of online offerings that will provide lending to small businesses if they have some credit. So I don't -- we haven't seen it have much of an impact on us at all. There was really a big impact in the recession, and I think that has slowly come back. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just a couple of -- a little bit more color on that, just to build on what Marty said. I mentioned earlier that payroll sales or sales units this year are trending above last year. Actually, sales units are growing about twice the rate that they did
componenttext: Yes. Just a couple of -- a little bit more color on that, just to build on what Marty said. I mentioned earlier that payroll sales or sales units this year are trending above last year. Actually, sales units are growing about twice the rate that they did last year -- the sales units, that's not client-base. But what's interesting is when you disaggregate that number, our sales units from new business startups actually were up about 7% in the quarter. So it looks like the environment -- and that's a good development for us because obviously, 50% or more of our sales in a given quarter come from newly started businesses. So that's a good development, and it says the environment is good for sales.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim MacDonald of Analysis.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim MacDonald of Analysis.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of follow-up questions on Advance Partners. I think I heard that the impact on the payroll side was less than 1%. Did you -- and I couldn't quite hear the impact -- there was also an impact on the HR side. Was that more -- slightly more tha
componenttext: I had a couple of follow-up questions on Advance Partners. I think I heard that the impact on the payroll side was less than 1%. Did you -- and I couldn't quite hear the impact -- there was also an impact on the HR side. Was that more -- slightly more than 1%?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's slightly more than 1%. Yes.
componenttext: Yes, it's slightly more than 1%. Yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so on Advance Partners, what kind of integration plan do you have? And what kind of timing to maybe bring it to the rest of your client base?
componenttext: Okay. And so on Advance Partners, what kind of integration plan do you have? And what kind of timing to maybe bring it to the rest of your client base?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, we're already in process of -- we've identified the clients that we have that are independent staffing agencies. We're working with the sales team at Advance to get them out and talking to them where they already have a relationship with Paychex
componenttext: Yes, Jim, we're already in process of -- we've identified the clients that we have that are independent staffing agencies. We're working with the sales team at Advance to get them out and talking to them where they already have a relationship with Paychex. And now we'll see this as an additional offering. I mean, it's early stage. We closed it at the end of December. But I think we've already been working on having identified the clients, get them in the hands of the sales team, make sure the sales team understands and be very careful with how they approach those clients, because they're Paychex clients, and we're trying to approach them but offer them additional services and support. And I don't -- as Efrain said earlier, we don't see any big onetime integration cost for this. It's another great thing about the acquisition and bringing them into the Paychex family. And we saw ongoing expense and ongoing -- revenue and the expense, but no big onetime integration cost. It's really just bringing the groups together.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: By the way, Jim, just a point. I was asked earlier about specific integration costs in the quarter. There were a modest amount, maybe between $1 million and $2 million in the quarter. We just absorbed it, didn't call it out, especially in the numbers. Tho
componenttext: By the way, Jim, just a point. I was asked earlier about specific integration costs in the quarter. There were a modest amount, maybe between $1 million and $2 million in the quarter. We just absorbed it, didn't call it out, especially in the numbers. Thought it was just not important.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe just one follow-up. So do you expect to be able to accelerate Advance Partners' growth now that you're bringing them into your base?
componenttext: Great. And maybe just one follow-up. So do you expect to be able to accelerate Advance Partners' growth now that you're bringing them into your base?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hope so. I mean, we certainly would model it that way. As we did the acquisition, we felt that they had good growth, but they were somewhat limited from a capital perspective, obviously, and from a cash perspective for their funding -- for the fun
componenttext: Yes, we hope so. I mean, we certainly would model it that way. As we did the acquisition, we felt that they had good growth, but they were somewhat limited from a capital perspective, obviously, and from a cash perspective for their funding -- for the funding of their clients and the work that they do and the -- and then, just the client base that we have, I think between those 2, we do expect to be able to help them accelerate their growth.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Silber of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Silber of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick follow-up questions. Marty, at the beginning of the call, I think you said that year-to-date you've seen your best client gains since the recession. Are you talking about total clients? Are you talking payroll clients? HR clients? C
componenttext: Just a couple of quick follow-up questions. Marty, at the beginning of the call, I think you said that year-to-date you've seen your best client gains since the recession. Are you talking about total clients? Are you talking payroll clients? HR clients? Can you just qualify that a little bit?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's payroll clients. We always kind of talk about it as payroll clients. And so it's the net client gain of the total payroll base, the one that we give kind of once a year at the end of the year, we'll give the base. And year-to-date we've seen th
componenttext: Sure. It's payroll clients. We always kind of talk about it as payroll clients. And so it's the net client gain of the total payroll base, the one that we give kind of once a year at the end of the year, we'll give the base. And year-to-date we've seen the best client gain -- net client gain because of a combination of both better sales and solid retention since the recession.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jeff we, typically, have been saying that we'll be between 1 and 3. And if you looked at our numbers, we've been slightly under 2 in prior years, and we're trending pretty solidly between 2 and 3. So it takes a while for a client base of 600,000 clien
componenttext: And Jeff we, typically, have been saying that we'll be between 1 and 3. And if you looked at our numbers, we've been slightly under 2 in prior years, and we're trending pretty solidly between 2 and 3. So it takes a while for a client base of 600,000 clients to grow, but we feel pretty good about where we're at.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I just wanted to double check on that. And then, Efrain, you were asked about the purchase price for Advance Partners. I think you said something in the range of 4 to 5x revenues and less than 10x EBITDA. What time frame are we talking about
componenttext: Okay, great. I just wanted to double check on that. And then, Efrain, you were asked about the purchase price for Advance Partners. I think you said something in the range of 4 to 5x revenues and less than 10x EBITDA. What time frame are we talking about for the revenues and EBITDA? Is it forward-looking? Backward-looking?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's backward-looking. So it would've been their calendar 2015, which, of course, you don't have any access to. But yes, so we acquired them right at the end of December, and we paid between 4 and 5x revenue. But I would just say this about Advance, and t
componenttext: It's backward-looking. So it would've been their calendar 2015, which, of course, you don't have any access to. But yes, so we acquired them right at the end of December, and we paid between 4 and 5x revenue. But I would just say this about Advance, and they've done a phenomenal job. There are very, very few businesses that we have looked at, and we have looked at many, many, whose EBITDA margins are at or exceed Paychex's. So obviously, that got our attention.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I'm sorry, just one more clarification on that. That includes the debt that you absorbed in the transaction, net of cash?
componenttext: Okay. And then, I'm sorry, just one more clarification on that. That includes the debt that you absorbed in the transaction, net of cash?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So no, Jeff. So part of the -- you'll see when we do the 2 disclosures, we settled it out. We paid off an existing loan that they had, chose to not refund it. We'll fund it again. That's the way the business works. But then we acquired a number of re
componenttext: Yes. So no, Jeff. So part of the -- you'll see when we do the 2 disclosures, we settled it out. We paid off an existing loan that they had, chose to not refund it. We'll fund it again. That's the way the business works. But then we acquired a number of receivables that basically offset the amount of the loan. So on a net basis, when you filter through that, that's what I'm talking about. It -- we'll have a disclosure in the Q, which we'll file at the end of the day. It's pretty explicit. Call me if there's any questions on it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Grossman of Stifel Financial.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Grossman of Stifel Financial.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So sorry to ask another question on growth so late in the call here. But I'm just looking at the numbers. It would appear that, if my math is right, that Advance adds about 60 basis points to the service growth [ph] for the year, but we maintained the gui
componenttext: So sorry to ask another question on growth so late in the call here. But I'm just looking at the numbers. It would appear that, if my math is right, that Advance adds about 60 basis points to the service growth [ph] for the year, but we maintained the guidance for the year for service revenue growth. That said, momentum of the businesses remain pretty strong and your tone is very positive. So I guess, I understand the timing issues with bookings among some of the other things that you mentioned. But I guess, I'm still having a little trouble reconciling your tone and then with the guide for the year vis--vis the acquisition. So if you feel you've already addressed this, we could take this offline, or if you have anything incremental to add that may clarify it, that would be great.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I get it, David. I understand the point you're making. So I think I said at the -- in my comments that we expected the guide for revenue to be at the high end of the range. And I'm not going to call out a 10 or 20 basis point difference. So obviously,
componenttext: No, I get it, David. I understand the point you're making. So I think I said at the -- in my comments that we expected the guide for revenue to be at the high end of the range. And I'm not going to call out a 10 or 20 basis point difference. So obviously, when we guide to 7% to 8%, we think we're going to be somewhere in the middle of the range at the beginning of the year. I don't know whether 60 basis points is exactly correct. It's not probably directionally all that far off. But now I'm into discussing whether it's going to be 8.1% or 7.9%. It's just too close to call, especially because, as I mentioned, checks were a little bit softer, so I'm a little bit cautious about kind of where we end up in Q4. But that's the color on that number. The trends are strong.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, on the dynamic between the strength in the market and how that gets recorded as payroll versus HRS. So does that dynamic then continue into fiscal '17? So you see that -- you would probably see better HRS growth on a relative basis than payroll
componenttext: And then, on the dynamic between the strength in the market and how that gets recorded as payroll versus HRS. So does that dynamic then continue into fiscal '17? So you see that -- you would probably see better HRS growth on a relative basis than payroll because of that mix dynamic?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, David. And look, frankly, just to kind of expand on that -- and you've covered the company for a long time. 10 years ago, what we did was we saw a payroll salesperson, either -- in the small market, sold payroll. That's what they sold.
componenttext: Yes, that's right, David. And look, frankly, just to kind of expand on that -- and you've covered the company for a long time. 10 years ago, what we did was we saw a payroll salesperson, either -- in the small market, sold payroll. That's what they sold. And then, if there were ancillaries, they were sold by an ancillary sales force. That was the product we had. I would say, in the last 5 years, certainly since Marty was CEO, that dynamic has changed pretty significantly. Our financials reflect the old dynamic, not the new one. And the new dynamic is this. Two things. Much, much better sales efficiency so that when Mark has a client of a certain type that we've identified, it's a team sale. But we've already discussed that in prior calls. What's changed really over the last 18 months is that a small-market payroll salesperson has -- is able to sell a HCM bundled product, and they are increasingly doing that. Meaning, our client -- our payroll salespeople, who used to sell payroll only, now sell products that are actually included in the HRS revenue, which is time and attendance and also HR administration. So it is very, very possible that total revenue can grow nicely and payroll service revenue doesn't seem to be moving significantly. And that's a function of where the technology has been and where the market is heading. So we're going to have to figure out how we represent that a little bit more clearly. I think it is the case, as we put more emphasis on selling more integrated bundles, that you could very well see payroll service revenue not growing quite as fast, but you're seeing sustained growth in HRS, because that's where the other components of that HCM revenue are being recorded. It wasn't a big deal several years ago. It's a bigger deal now.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could, just one last question on Advance. Can you give us any sense of how much balance sheet exposure you have at any given point in time now that you've got that acquisition?
componenttext: Great. And if I could, just one last question on Advance. Can you give us any sense of how much balance sheet exposure you have at any given point in time now that you've got that acquisition?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So again, I'll just point you to the Q. Our -- we established a dedicated line of credit for Advance, and that number is going to be somewhere between $125 million to $150 million.
componenttext: Yes. So again, I'll just point you to the Q. Our -- we established a dedicated line of credit for Advance, and that number is going to be somewhere between $125 million to $150 million.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and is the vast majority of that outstanding at any given time?
componenttext: Okay, and is the vast majority of that outstanding at any given time?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's going to be outstanding at any given time. And by the way, just an aside, David, because I think it's a great question. One of the things that we looked at, they've been around for 20 years. And obviously, I -- not I, we had looked at the acquis
componenttext: Yes. It's going to be outstanding at any given time. And by the way, just an aside, David, because I think it's a great question. One of the things that we looked at, they've been around for 20 years. And obviously, I -- not I, we had looked at the acquisition very carefully. They've had very, very few problems because they have very, very extensive credit vetting process and we have a really first-rate group that also does that. So we've got -- there's a lot of safeguards that go into what we do.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Marcon of R. W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Marcon of R. W. Baird.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marty and Efrain, a couple of quick follow-ups. First of all, you said that the retention rate has improved. Can you give us a little bit of feel for how much it's improved?
componenttext: Marty and Efrain, a couple of quick follow-ups. First of all, you said that the retention rate has improved. Can you give us a little bit of feel for how much it's improved?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And actually, what we -- when we look at net client gain, retention has held pretty steady, and -- which has been around our best ever. So we're right near our best-ever retention. It hasn't really improved all that much, it's -- but it's holding ver
componenttext: Yes. And actually, what we -- when we look at net client gain, retention has held pretty steady, and -- which has been around our best ever. So we're right near our best-ever retention. It hasn't really improved all that much, it's -- but it's holding very well, even as the client -- even as the sales have gone up. So we feel very good about that, because sometimes, as the sales increase, obviously, retention becomes more difficult as we're bringing in more clients. The sales have gone up, the retention, I'd say, has kind of -- it's stayed pretty level at its best ever that we saw last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's still in that 81% range?
componenttext: So it's still in that 81% range?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little better. A little -- closer to 82%, I think.
componenttext: Yes, a little better. A little -- closer to 82%, I think.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, with regards to the comments on the mid-market, can you just quantify what portion of the mid-market you're seeing the strongest growth in? In other words, small market is up to 50 employees. Then, is it the 50 to 100? 50 to 200? How woul
componenttext: Great. And then, with regards to the comments on the mid-market, can you just quantify what portion of the mid-market you're seeing the strongest growth in? In other words, small market is up to 50 employees. Then, is it the 50 to 100? 50 to 200? How would you characterize that area that you're seeing the best growth in?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, I'll probably go fairly broad there. But it's 50 -- I'd say, 50 to 300. That's where the most new activity is, I think, when you see it because that's where there's need, particularly with the ACA compliance and so forth has come down and more
componenttext: Yes, Mark, I'll probably go fairly broad there. But it's 50 -- I'd say, 50 to 300. That's where the most new activity is, I think, when you see it because that's where there's need, particularly with the ACA compliance and so forth has come down and more are outsourcing and interested in outsourcing. So I think that's where we're seeing, probably, the biggest jump. It's not in the 500 plus. The -- let's say, 300-plus, 250-plus. We're still doing fine there, but the acceleration has been more that 50 to 250 or 300.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, given all your comments with regards to selling additional modules, it sounds like you should have some confidence that the HRS growth is going to hold steady at these current levels that you're seeing for this year going forward, just gi
componenttext: Great. And then, given all your comments with regards to selling additional modules, it sounds like you should have some confidence that the HRS growth is going to hold steady at these current levels that you're seeing for this year going forward, just given the dynamics. Or is there something that would drive that down lower?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, no, I feel pretty good about it. I mean, you never know, but at this stage, the only question will then would be -- we call it ESR, would be ACA compliance. Does that catch that second wave or not? But overall, I think you may see a second wave i
componenttext: I think, no, I feel pretty good about it. I mean, you never know, but at this stage, the only question will then would be -- we call it ESR, would be ACA compliance. Does that catch that second wave or not? But overall, I think you may see a second wave in ACA as well as health and benefit insurance. For more people needing insurance, we may catch some wave there. But the 401(k), the PEO, ASO, all seem very steady. And as Efrain said, a lot of our bundled products on low and mid, being HR administration, on-boarding time and attendance, all seem to be very -- continuing to be very strong. So yes, I would expect that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: What do you think the ACA, on a direct basis, is contributing to this -- the second half of this year's growth?
componenttext: What do you think the ACA, on a direct basis, is contributing to this -- the second half of this year's growth?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, it's -- so I'll answer it. That's my pause. I'm trying to figure out how to best -- it's probably less than 1%.
componenttext: Yes, Mark, it's -- so I'll answer it. That's my pause. I'm trying to figure out how to best -- it's probably less than 1%.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, one follow-up with regards to the comment around -- or the question around acquisitions. In terms of the acquisitions that you're looking at, are you looking at things that are still more in the Advance size range? Or was there some sugge
componenttext: Great. And then, one follow-up with regards to the comment around -- or the question around acquisitions. In terms of the acquisitions that you're looking at, are you looking at things that are still more in the Advance size range? Or was there some suggestion that, perhaps, we could look at things that are even bigger and could potentially be a bigger impact with regards to the balance sheet? And what's the minimum level of cash that you're comfortable holding on the balance sheet?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Boy, that's 3 questions. So let me answer. So part A, Mark, would be that much of what we're looking at is in that Advance kind of SurePayroll Advance range. So that's part A. Part B, and if you've heard me in conferences say this, we do look at larg
componenttext: Yes. Boy, that's 3 questions. So let me answer. So part A, Mark, would be that much of what we're looking at is in that Advance kind of SurePayroll Advance range. So that's part A. Part B, and if you've heard me in conferences say this, we do look at larger acquisitions. It would have to be right. It would -- the numbers would have to add up, and it would have to give us some sort of durable, sustainable, competitive advantage in the market. We would look. Not likely, but it's not out of the question. Minimum cash, it's lower than what we have on the balance sheet now, but this is a business where you have to project a sense of financial strength to the customers to whom -- who are entrusting $4.5 billion of cash to you. So I don't know precisely where that is, but certainly, you need, I would say not just cash, but liquidity. And if you've looked at what we've done, we've been adding greater and greater liquidity over the last 2 or 3 years, quietly, to make sure that we're never in a position where there's any issues on that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just to go back to the mid-market. It sounds like most of the mid-market growth has really been through adding more modules as opposed to necessarily an increase in terms of competitive wins. Is that a correct interpretation? Or do you think yo
componenttext: Great. And just to go back to the mid-market. It sounds like most of the mid-market growth has really been through adding more modules as opposed to necessarily an increase in terms of competitive wins. Is that a correct interpretation? Or do you think your competitive wins have actually increased as well?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No -- yes, I don't think so. I think our number of competitive wins have increased. And I think, particularly as I mentioned in the fall as those products -- as the full product suite got into that single employee record, and we have that full single
componenttext: Yes. No -- yes, I don't think so. I think our number of competitive wins have increased. And I think, particularly as I mentioned in the fall as those products -- as the full product suite got into that single employee record, and we have that full single sign-on kind of flexibility. No, they definitely have picked up. So while we certainly are bullish on how well we've done on ancillary sales and add-ons and full packages, it's been also the payroll in the mid-market has been very strong. Strong as it's been in years. So we feel good about the -- very good about the mid-market payroll sales as well. Payroll and full bundle.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lisa Ellis of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lisa Ellis of Bernstein.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question about Flex. I know one of the unique aspects of Flex is that you've got this like tiered service structure to it. How are you seeing client response to that? What types of service levels are the most popular? Kind of how are you seeing th
componenttext: I had a question about Flex. I know one of the unique aspects of Flex is that you've got this like tiered service structure to it. How are you seeing client response to that? What types of service levels are the most popular? Kind of how are you seeing that evolve now that you've rolled it out?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, for the mid-market where we've been talking a lot about this morning, I think that the biggest -- the best impact for our clients has been the multiproduct centers that we've been putting together. So in the past, you would have your payroll
componenttext: Yes. I think, for the mid-market where we've been talking a lot about this morning, I think that the biggest -- the best impact for our clients has been the multiproduct centers that we've been putting together. So in the past, you would have your payroll support, and then you would have your additional products in unique support, where they're uniquely trained on that product, time and attendance and HRO. And while that worked well, sometimes clients would say, "Geez, it would be even better if you were kind of more connected as a team, so that things between various products if I had questions on how to use something or best get the most value out of it." And so those multiproduct centers have been established by John Gibson and the team, and we're staffing those up now. And we're seeing more clients come into those multiproduct centers. That's probably been the biggest benefit. The other one is, last year at some point, we went to the 24/7 service, and that's been a benefit. I would say that's more of a benefit on the small end of clients, and we've seen an increased use of that where, hey, they're doing payroll themselves online, and it's off-hours. It's Saturday. It's Sunday. It's weeknight, late at night, and they get hung up on something that they want to do, and they can call for that 24/7 support now. And that's gained a lot of interest and a lot of positive feedback as well. So I think it's that flexibility or -- and as well, of course, they can do a lot more self-service. They can do a lot more things themselves. And we're finding that clients don't actually stick to one service model. They're -- this week, might want to be doing more things themselves, then get hung up on creating a couple of special bonuses or something the next week and need support. And the next week, they might need after-hours support. So it's that flexibility that, we're finding, is getting positive feedback.

componenttext: There's not a significant change in pricing there. We don't really charge a lot extra for this. We -- well, we charge it in the price. If you're taking a full bundle of products and you're supported by the multiproduct center, we feel you're paying for that level of support in the price of the product. So we're not having you sign up for various support levels. We feel that when you're buying a full product suite from us, we're going to give you a full multiproduct service response to your needs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. I mean, there's payroll only. There's obviously various product bundles, and we're seeing more take multiple products. It's never enough for us. We'd always like to see even more of that. But we certainly have a lot of payroll only, but we also
componenttext: Sure. Yes. I mean, there's payroll only. There's obviously various product bundles, and we're seeing more take multiple products. It's never enough for us. We'd always like to see even more of that. But we certainly have a lot of payroll only, but we also are picking up a lot of steam, as Efrain mentioned, with taking the full product suite right up front. Our model used to be, "Hey, let me sell you payroll." Once you're used to it, it's working well, you're feeling good about our relationship, 2 months later, we come in with a sales force on 401(k) or a sales force on time and attendance or whatever. Now we're selling much more of the full suite of products right up front in the sale through integrated or team selling.

componenttextpreview: Just I wanted to ask, given the selling commentary here, can we infer that full-service outsourcing demand is getting better versus self-service or point solutions? I know I've asked that in the past, but I wanted to see if we can tie those things togethe
componenttext: Just I wanted to ask, given the selling commentary here, can we infer that full-service outsourcing demand is getting better versus self-service or point solutions? I know I've asked that in the past, but I wanted to see if we can tie those things together.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- Tien-tsin, it's kind of a mix. I mean, I do think there's -- it's going both ways. You're seeing those with needs coming down. So I'd say even 20-plus employees, sometimes 15, depending on the business, they want more of a full-service sol
componenttext: I think it's -- Tien-tsin, it's kind of a mix. I mean, I do think there's -- it's going both ways. You're seeing those with needs coming down. So I'd say even 20-plus employees, sometimes 15, depending on the business, they want more of a full-service solution. So they're not just looking for payroll. They're looking for help with recruiting and onboarding their clients and screening and all that, that's tied right in with their payroll. They're not just looking for payroll. So there's that growth in demand. Then there's also, on the low end, much more of a -- there's more clients who say, "Hey, I just want an online solution with 24/7 support when I need it, and I'm willing to do -- and I want to do more things myself. So we're trying -- the changes we've been making the last few years in technology and service models have been to respond to kind of all of that. So if you're an online client, we made the online, and continuing to do that, actually, this next 12 months, make it much more easier, make it kind of an employee journey for the clients so that they can walk through all the way from hiring right through to payroll, HR, et cetera, in a very self-service format, if that's the way they want to do it.

I wouldn't say it's big, measurable or anything, but particularly in those markets on the West -- Midwest and West Coast where they -- it's been most visible, I think, we've probably picked up a little bit of demand there.
