Welcome, and thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Martin Mucci, President and Chief Executive Officer. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, and thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings release call and webcast. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, and thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings release call and webcast. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. 
This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended May 31, 2016. You can access our earnings release on our Investor Relations webpage, and we will file our Form 10-K by the end of July. This teleconference is being broadcast over the Internet and will be archived and available on our website for approximately 1 month. 
On today's call, I will review highlights for the fourth quarter and fiscal 2016 related to sales, operations and product development areas. Efrain will review our fourth quarter fiscal 2016 financial results and discuss our fiscal 2017 guidance, and then we'll open it up for your questions. 
We are pleased with our strong finish to fiscal 2016. Our momentum continued in the fourth quarter. Efrain will talk in more detail about the financial results, but I want to touch on a couple of key points. First, total revenue was up 9% in the quarter and 8% for the fiscal year, reaching nearly $3 billion, a new record for Paychex. Payroll service revenue continued to experience steady growth of 4% for fiscal '16, driven by growth in client base and revenue per check, and our payroll quite this finish this year at approximately 605,000 clients, the highest client growth in recent years. 
Solid sales execution during fiscal '16, along with high client retention in excess of 82% positively impacted our client base. Client retention was consistent with last year's record-high retention. 
HRS revenue benefited from strong demand for our comprehensive human resource outsourcing services as we once again realized double-digit growth in client worksite employees that we serve. In particular, our PEO has been an area of strong growth. In addition, our full service Affordable Care Act product contributed to the HRS revenue increase. 
During fiscal 2016, we made significant enhancements to our Paychex Flex platform, which is our proprietary cloud-based human capital management, or HCM, solution. Paychex Flex is a robust technology and service model that supports our clients' delivery phase of their employees' journey from recruiting to retirement. This model allows business owners and HR professionals to tailor a solution encompassing tools, capabilities and services that meet the unique needs of their organization and employees. 
Earlier this year, we completed the integration of the remaining key HCM modules with Paychex Hiring, Paychex Time and Paychex Benefits. We believe we also have the best-in-market mobility offerings for both administrative users and employee self-service that allows access to our HCM suite with a single mobile application. 
Paychex Flex continues to receive positive reviews evidenced by multiple awards and acknowledgments received throughout this year. Earlier in the year, we earned recognition from the Brandon Hall Group Excellence awards for advancements in workforce management technology for small and midsize businesses. PC Magazine's review referred to Paychex Flex as excellent, calling it more robust and scalable than some of our competitors' platforms. And most recently in the quarter, we received the 2016 TekTonic Award for HR -- from HRO Today for the best-in-class mobile and cloud-based technology suite for comprehensive integrated HCM services. We are very pleased by this recognition, and it supports our belief that Paychex Flex technology, combined with the unique mix of personalized, flexible service options, sets us apart and provides great value to our clients. We remain committed to our investments and product development and technology to keep us a market leader. 
Sales execution during '16 was strong, with another year double-digit growth, especially within the mid-market space. We believe the value that our Flex platform provides is a key driver to this success. 
During fiscal '16, we announced the acquisition of Advance Partners, who joined the Paychex' team during the third quarter. Advance Partners offers customized -- customizable solutions to the temporary staffing industry, including payroll funding and outsourcing services. Advance Partners and its leadership team has already proven to be a great addition with our positive results and opportunity for growth in the expanding staffing market. 
Throughout the year, we have continued our shareholder-friendly actions. We maintain a strong dividend yield. And in July of '15, we increased our regular quarterly dividend by 11%. The dividend increase supports our history of providing exceptional shareholder value while continuing to make strategic investments for the long-term sustained growth of Paychex. We have also continued to repurchase Paychex stock and acquired an additional 2.2 million shares of common stock for $108 million in fiscal 2016. 
As of May 31, 2016, our stock price was over $54 per share, and that is a total return of over 102% or 15% on an annualized basis over the past 5-year period. 
The regulatory landscape for HCM continues to get more complicated, making managing HR increasingly difficult. We strive to be a valuable resource to our clients to educate them on changes and assist them with compliance. Recently, new overtime rules were approved by the Department of Labor that will expand overtime protection to millions of workers. We are well positioned to help our clients comply with these new regulations. Our advanced suite of time and attendance products, including web and mobile tools, can assist companies with the scheduling, tracking and reporting of time, which will be critical to managing this new regulation. 
In summary, I'm extremely proud of the leadership team and all of our employees at Paychex who have continued to deliver great service and product solutions, resulting in continued high client satisfaction and continued high levels of client retention. We also continue to focus on providing leading-edge, user-friendly technology and unique personalized service to our clients, while delivering solid, consistent, top line growth, strong operating margins and excellent returns to our shareholders. 
I will now turn the call over to Efrain Rivera to review our financial results in more detail. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call, we'll make some forward-looking statements that refer to future events, and thus, involve some risks. Refer to the customary disclosures. As Marty indicated, we h
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call, we'll make some forward-looking statements that refer to future events, and thus, involve some risks. Refer to the customary disclosures. 
As Marty indicated, we had a strong finish to 2016. I'll cover some of the key highlights for the quarter and for the fiscal year and then provide greater detail in certain areas and wrap with a review of our 2017 outlook. 
Total service revenue grew 9% for the quarter and 8% for the fiscal year. Interest on funds held for clients increased 14% for the fourth quarter to $12 million and 9% for the fiscal year to $46 million. Increases were primarily the result of higher average interest rates earned. Average investment balances were up 1% for the fiscal year, showing a positive impact from client growth, which is offset by lower state unemployment insurance rates. 
Total expenses increased by 8% in the fourth quarter and by 7% for the fiscal year. These increases were mainly in compensation-related costs, resulting from higher wages and higher performance-based comp. Strong growth in our PEO also contributed to the increases. 
Advance Partners contributed approximately 1% of the growth in total expenses for the fourth quarter, but less than 1% for the fiscal year. Operating margin was 36% for the fourth quarter and 38% for fiscal 2016. operating income, net of certain items, increased 10% to $264 million for the fourth quarter and 9% to $1.1 billion for fiscal 2016. 
Our effective tax rate was 34.3% for the year compared to 36.3% for fiscal 2015. This is due to software production tax benefits as we've discussed in prior calls. In our first quarter, we recognized a discrete item in the form of a tax benefit derived on income from prior year related to customer-facing software we produced. This discrete item was the largest -- had the largest impact on the effective tax rate. While we have ongoing benefits, the impact is not as significant. 
Net income growth increased 11% to $178 million for the fourth quarter and 12% to $757 million for the fiscal year. Diluted EPS increased 11% to $0.49 per share for the fourth quarter and increased 13% to $2.09 per share for fiscal 2016. Net income and diluted earnings per share would have increased 9%, respectively, without the discrete tax benefit recognized in the first quarter. 
Payroll service revenue increased 5% for the fourth quarter and 4% for the fiscal year. We benefited from increases in revenue per check and client base. Revenue per check was positively impacted by price increases, partially offset by discounts. 
Fiscal 2016 also benefited from 2 additional processing days during the year, 1 day in the first quarter and 1 day in this quarter, fourth quarter. The extra days added approximately 1/2 percent to total payroll revenue as did the acquisition of Advance. 
HRS revenue increased 14% to $311 million for the fourth quarter and 13% to $1.2 billion for the fiscal year. HRS service continued to experience solid growth in clients and client worksite employees served. The PEO, in particular, contributed double-digit growth in client worksite employees served. Insurance services revenue growth benefited from continued growth of our ACA product and an increase in health and benefit applicants. The workers' compensation portion continued to grow with higher average premiums and growth in clients. Advance Partners contributed approximately a little bit less than 2% to growth in HRS revenue for the fourth quarter and approximately 1% to fiscal year growth. 
Investments and income. Our primary goal, as you know, continues to be to protect principal and to optimize liquidity. Combined portfolio, including both short-term and long-term investments, have average return rate of return of 1.1% for both the fourth quarter and fiscal year. We did see moderate benefit from the 25 basis point increase by the Federal Reserve on the short-term portion of our portfolio. But our long-term portfolio as of May 31, 2016, has an average yield maturity of 1.7% and an average duration of 3.1 years. Fairly unchanged from last year. 
Average investment balances for our client funds were flat for the quarter and up 1% for the fiscal year. Our client growth positively impacted our average balances. This was offset by the impact of lower state unemployment insurance rates this year. 
The average invested balances for our corporate funds were down 9% for the year, largely due to the cash outflow for the business acquisition as well as share repurchases. 
I'll now walk you through the highlights on our financial position. It remains strong with cash and total corporate investments of $793 million as of May 31, 2016, and no debt. Our cash flows from operations hit a milestone, exceeding $1 billion for the fiscal year, 14% higher than last year. Our net income, non-cash adjustments and favorable working capital changes all contributed to the increase. 
Funds held for clients as of May 31, 2016, were $4 billion compared to $4.3 billion as of May 31, 2015. Funds held for clients vary widely on a day-to-day basis and averaged $4.1 billion for the fiscal year, a year-over-year increase of approximately 1%. Our total available-for-sale investments, including corporate investments and funds held for clients, reflecting net unrealized gains of $48 million as of May 31, 2016, compared to $14 million as of the end of last year. 
Total stockholders' equity was $1.9 billion as of May 31, reflecting $607 million in dividends paid during the fiscal year. Dividends paid represented 80% of net income. Our return on equity for the past 12 months was a sterling 40%. 
Now let's turn to guidance for fiscal 2017. I'd like to remind you that the guidance and our outlook is based on our current view of economic and interest rate conditions continuing without significant changes. Payroll service revenue is projected to increase approximately 4% compared to fiscal 2016. The projected growth is based on an anticipated client-based growth and increases in revenue per check. This growth is tempered by 1 less processing day in fiscal 2017. So we'll have 1 less processing day this year, and that day will occur in the third quarter. So I'll come back to that in a second. So 1 less day occurs in the third quarter. 
HRS revenue growth is expected to be in the range of 12% to 14%. Total service revenue is expected to increase in the range of 7% to 8%. Net income is expected to increase approximately 8%, excluding the impact of the discrete tax benefit recognized in the first quarter of fiscal 2016. And that's important to bear in mind when the 2 years are compared. 
Our operating income net of certain items as a percent of service revenue, is expected to be approximately 38%. We anticipate a modest impact on leverage growth as we are making investment in operations to support both mid-market and compliance solution services. So I will get the question, and I'll answer it now. So we don't anticipate -- do we anticipate leverage? Yes, we do. We think it will be modest because, as I just called out, we're making investments in with operations and compliance service solutions to bolster and to support that growth. 
With respect to the quarters, as previously mentioned, there'll be 1 less processing day in the third quarter of fiscal 2017. 
Now let me get a little bit more granular so you can fine-tune your models. Payroll revenue for the first and second quarters is expected to be at/or above the full year guidance for payroll revenue. The third quarter, we expect to be below. We've -- I just mentioned we have 1 less day. It'll be below the full year range. And then the fourth quarter, at this stage, we anticipate will be between 3% and 4%. 
So just to reiterate. First and second quarters, we expect to be at/or above full year guidance for payroll revenue; third quarter, below; and fourth quarter, below 3% and 4% at this point. 
HRS is expected to be within the full year guidance range with the exception of the third quarter, which will fall below the full year range. The effective tax rate for fiscal 2016 is expected to be between 35.5% and 36%. 
Interest on funds is anticipated to be in the mid-single-digit range. We have not included any potential Fed fund rate increases in our guidance. 
I'd like to call out that when I reviewed consensus models, many of the numbers were close to what I'm reporting, but there was one important difference. Interest on funds held for clients was higher in the consensus models, and it looked like to the tune of about $0.01 to $0.02. We are not including any assumptions with respect to Fed rate rise increases. And as you well can appreciate, those look a lot more uncertain than they did even 3 or 4 weeks ago. 
And then finally, with respect to EPS, we expect EPS in each of the quarters to be comparable, meaning pretty similar, with the following exception. First quarter, we expect will be modestly higher and the third quarter, modestly lower. The third quarter, in particular, because of the 1 less day on payroll processing. So that's the fine tuning on the guidance. 
And then just want to make one final comment. It was about 5 years ago that Marty started to assemble the team that has led Paychex over the 5-year period. And he set an ambitious goal. The goal was to hit $3 billion in revenue. That was an ambitious goal because when we finished 2011, we were growing 4%. This quarter, we're really on the cusp of that goal. It's an important milestone internally for us. Marty cited the returns for the past 5 years. We compared very favorably versus the S&P 500 and even against the S&P Technology Index. Those results are a testament to both employees, the executive team and to Marty's leadership. 
We're not the kind of people who brag or smack talk, but we're quietly very, very pleased that we've -- we're on the cusp of that milestone. But we're also grounded enough to understand that we have to earn the trust of our clients, employees and our shareholders every day if we want to succeed. Every question you've asked in the last 5 years has caused us to think, to question and it's challenged us. And we've appreciated that. And yes, finally, we're not satisfied. We're hungry for more. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Marty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to start with a question on core payroll, and appreciate all the quarterly color for the fiscal '17. That's helpful. I'm assuming that the first half of the year, being above the full year guide, is largely because of Advance. And then obviously, y
componenttext: Wanted to start with a question on core payroll, and appreciate all the quarterly color for the fiscal '17. That's helpful. I'm assuming that the first half of the year, being above the full year guide, is largely because of Advance. And then obviously, you've got the headwind in Q3 from 1 less day. And then you've mentioned Q4 being 3% to 4%. I think would not be burdened by processing days or by Advance, so it seems like kind of a cleaner number. I'm just trying to think sort of medium-term-ish, harkening back to the Analyst Day last year. I mean, would that imply or would it be fair to infer then that 3% to 4% run rate is something that's realistic to sustain, assuming no other acquisitions or typical fluctuations in processing days?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, so I think that is a fair number. The only caveat I would add to that is that what that number that we're doing on payroll suggests is we're just not getting an uplift from checks per payroll, which if you went back 2 years ago, we were getting 2-p
componenttext: Jason, so I think that is a fair number. The only caveat I would add to that is that what that number that we're doing on payroll suggests is we're just not getting an uplift from checks per payroll, which if you went back 2 years ago, we were getting 2-plus percent on checks per payroll, combination -- a small combination of mix, but just very, very modest assumptions on checks per payroll just don't contribute to payroll revenue growth. So I think it's somewhere in that range.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And still 2 to 4 on pricing for payroll this year.
componenttext: Okay. And still 2 to 4 on pricing for payroll this year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes, yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understood. And then just switching over to leverage and that color on it maybe investments this year is helpful. Is there anything we should be thinking about also, though, in terms of mix shift, meaning, I'm thinking about areas like PEO, which ar
componenttext: Okay. Understood. And then just switching over to leverage and that color on it maybe investments this year is helpful. Is there anything we should be thinking about also, though, in terms of mix shift, meaning, I'm thinking about areas like PEO, which are obviously growing very well for you, but presumably carries lower-margin percentage. So when we think about the ability for the business over multiple years to drive meaningful operating margin expansion, is that an inhibitor? Is it big enough?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really not. I'd just say, if you look at our results this year, our leverage down to the EBIT line was down 100 basis points. So we had a pretty good year in terms of leverage. Now what you're seeing there is the fact that 2 things that are implicit there
componenttext: Really not. I'd just say, if you look at our results this year, our leverage down to the EBIT line was down 100 basis points. So we had a pretty good year in terms of leverage. Now what you're seeing there is the fact that 2 things that are implicit there. Number one, we had a really good year in mid-market sales. In some areas, our win rates were really, really strong. And as we look into the year, we did 2 things this year. In 2016, we added to the mid-market sales force, which we don't typically do mid-year, but we did. And as we added to the mid-year sales force, we were also transforming the service model. So we've made a lot of changes on the service model to improve service to mid-market clients. And just in anticipation of that growth, we decided that it was important to have a year where we put more money into bolstering our service there. So that's what happened. I think it's really kind of more of a 1- to 2-year thing than a long-term issue in terms of affecting leverage. And finally, to your point, PEOs just not big enough to really move the needle. It could if it really grew significantly, but beyond where it is now. But not affecting it now.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just last one for me. Can I get your perspective on where we are in the ACA cycle? What's assumed in the fiscal '17 HRS guidance for ACA versus what the contribution looks like in fiscal '16? Because obviously, the overall guide for HRS is calling for
componenttext: And just last one for me. Can I get your perspective on where we are in the ACA cycle? What's assumed in the fiscal '17 HRS guidance for ACA versus what the contribution looks like in fiscal '16? Because obviously, the overall guide for HRS is calling for steady growth.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- well, obviously, today is a big filing day and it's been certainly a complicated process. Probably the most complicated is just helping clients through the process what was needed and especially those clients that came in kind of later in
componenttext: Yes, I think -- well, obviously, today is a big filing day and it's been certainly a complicated process. Probably the most complicated is just helping clients through the process what was needed and especially those clients that came in kind of later in taking the product. But an outstanding job by the employee teams that have been working on it. And we feel pretty good about the filing that we're doing and a lot of work, by the way, with the IRS to our compliance teams working with the IRS for this first year of real true filing. I think you'll see some of that sales. Obviously, there was a lot of upfront sales, and I think you'll see some of that slow down some. However, when you think about how many new clients come into us every year, we think we'll have a great attachment rate of that product. It really is necessary work. And one of the costs, as Efrain said, with the investment in the mid-market, one of those costs is continuing to invest in the ACA support. Because as we've learned, as we've gone through, this requires even more support of the clients and the filing requirements and a little more technology to kind of help the clients through the process. So feel good about it. It's been a tough number of months to get through this, but we're excited on the filing date and on the additional investments we're going to make.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Jason, on the other question, this year, ACA compliance services were contributed less than 1% of the growth in revenue. Next year, it really is pretty negligible in terms of growth. If there's some, I should say it's not 0. But most of the clien
componenttext: Okay. So Jason, on the other question, this year, ACA compliance services were contributed less than 1% of the growth in revenue. Next year, it really is pretty negligible in terms of growth. If there's some, I should say it's not 0. But most of the clients -- the bulk of the clients that needed the service signed up, and a number of them will probably understand that they needed it, and we'll have some additional clients. But we've absorbed that headwind, if you will, that modest headwind into our guidance and feel pretty comfortable about where revenues going to land next year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Danyal Hussain.
componenttext: The next question comes from Danyal Hussain.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on leverage. I guess, it sounds like a lot of the investment is onetime or sort of catch up in nature or maybe anticipatory in nature. But is the go-forward operating leverage in that model, is it more service-oriented? And so is it lower
componenttext: Just a follow-up on leverage. I guess, it sounds like a lot of the investment is onetime or sort of catch up in nature or maybe anticipatory in nature. But is the go-forward operating leverage in that model, is it more service-oriented? And so is it lower going forward?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think 2 things. One is you only go through a Flex transition a few times in a technology cycle. So frankly, it's a byproduct of the success we're having selling Flex. So it's not a change to the model. It's really, frankly, the suc
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think 2 things. One is you only go through a Flex transition a few times in a technology cycle. So frankly, it's a byproduct of the success we're having selling Flex. So it's not a change to the model. It's really, frankly, the success we're having in the mid-market requiring in our world, bolstering our service a bit. So that technology and that service is scalable as you grow clients initially the way we are now, just have to scale up the service component of it. So it's more short term in nature.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And to that point, actually, on Flex, so if you think about R&D spend, given the changes you've gone through and the product set recently, are we at the point now where maybe you can start to see more leverage on that cost? Or is there maybe not a
componenttext: Got it. And to that point, actually, on Flex, so if you think about R&D spend, given the changes you've gone through and the product set recently, are we at the point now where maybe you can start to see more leverage on that cost? Or is there maybe not as much opportunity given how much you have to update the ACA?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- well, there's always continued investment. But I think we're at a pretty good place for the level of IT spend in R&D. And so I don't -- I think we -- you'll gain something there, but we won't be going up much in that spend, I don't think,
componenttext: Yes, I think -- well, there's always continued investment. But I think we're at a pretty good place for the level of IT spend in R&D. And so I don't -- I think we -- you'll gain something there, but we won't be going up much in that spend, I don't think, but you once you go down a lot either, but pretty good steady place there. I think what Efrain has talked about the most is we have -- that we're gearing up for some of the service as you added all -- if we added all these products, we're changing some of our service models, and we're putting more technology in self-service for the client. So if there are some things that they can do, there's more things they can do if they want to or they can still come into the payroll specialist or other teams. And so I think IT is at a pretty good spend rate and they'll continue to go up, but not as much as they have in the past because we got a pretty good place with the level of investment.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Togut from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Togut from Evercore ISI.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given your commentary about the mid-market sales force, can you quantify your anticipated growth in the sales force for fiscal '17 as a whole? And if you could call out any variations versus overall growth by segment, that will be helpful.
componenttext: Given your commentary about the mid-market sales force, can you quantify your anticipated growth in the sales force for fiscal '17 as a whole? And if you could call out any variations versus overall growth by segment, that will be helpful.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll talk and then let Marty give some more comment on it. So David, this year, we have pretty strong growth. Actually, even a little bit higher than we had planned on the payroll services side, which would include mid-market. And as I mentioned,
componenttext: Yes. So I'll talk and then let Marty give some more comment on it. So David, this year, we have pretty strong growth. Actually, even a little bit higher than we had planned on the payroll services side, which would include mid-market. And as I mentioned, we had pretty healthy growth in mid-market sales at. So overall, we're still going to be in the 2% to 3% growth range this year. But that's because in payroll services last year, we were between 5% and 6%. So some of those adds were done in anticipation of this year. And we had selectively to certain sales force, as you've heard in previous calls, for example, that when a year or so ago, 1.5 years, we added to PEO, and that paid some dividends. So each year, we're taking along a look at where we think there's opportunities and adding selectively to the sales force.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's consistent growth, as Efrain said. And because we added -- and we're very happy with the fact that we added kind of mid-year, particularly in that mid-market area, earlier than normal. So instead of making sure we were staffed up at the
componenttext: Yes, I think it's consistent growth, as Efrain said. And because we added -- and we're very happy with the fact that we added kind of mid-year, particularly in that mid-market area, earlier than normal. So instead of making sure we were staffed up at the beginning of this fiscal year, we actually added probably 3 months earlier than normal into the mid-market because of the demand, which was a really good thing. But you'll see overall, I think the growth of the normal kind of 3% range. And we added a little bit to all of them. But mostly, as Efrain said, it's on payroll space, and particularly in the mid-market.

componenttext: Oh, I would say it's probably in the 2% to 3% range. Unless -- so assuming rates were lower this year and it's a little bit tough to anticipate. But I'm just assuming it'll be wage growth and not -- there won't be a change in any of the other balance figures.

componenttext: A good question. So we'll let them talk about that. But I'd just give 2 pieces of guidance. We've said we like to keep it in that low 80s range as a percentage of net income. And we like to track income. Yes, so it'll be somewhere in that range.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So help me understand one thing. As I look at the guidance and I think about how you talked about the business in the last year, so you've got the best client growth in 2007. You're at record retention again this year. You've had a real ramp in bookings t
componenttext: So help me understand one thing. As I look at the guidance and I think about how you talked about the business in the last year, so you've got the best client growth in 2007. You're at record retention again this year. You've had a real ramp in bookings the last 2 years. Floats no longer a big drag. You've got 7 months of the acquisition in the upcoming year versus 5 in the year you just finished. I really struggle to understand why revenue wouldn't accelerate at least modestly, and the guidance implies none. So is there something else going on like less pricing? It just feels like something doesn't add up here with a simple math. And I did hear you clearly that the checks per client is not as big a driver as it's been in the past. But it just feels like there should be some acceleration given how strong you've been performing.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say the first thing I mentioned is part of the answer to that, Gary. So checks per client, when they go flat to modestly negative because of client mix, you end up having an impact on payroll service growth, number one. Number two, it is -- it's
componenttext:
Well, I'd say the first thing I mentioned is part of the answer to that, Gary. So checks per client, when they go flat to modestly negative because of client mix, you end up having an impact on payroll service growth, number one. Number two, it is -- it's not 7 months. It's actually about 6 months' worth of revenue that will get it from Advance. So although that's pretty minor number, it's not quite as much as you're suggesting. And I think there's more -- I think what we've recognized as we've gone through the year is that the higher the client growth and we've set pretty ambitious goals again next year I think between 2% and 3%. Initially, that comes at some impact in terms of what you're expecting on overall pricing. So we recoup that over time. But as you grow, and this has been history of the company prior to the recession, you pay a little bit of a price on checks and also on overall rate by -- based on what's happening with client growth. So it's all of that. And then the third thing that I would say, which you're not factoring in, is we had a nice bump -- uplift from the ACA compliance product. And while I mentioned it earlier in response to Jason's question that we absorbed it in the guidance, of course, we're not having that uplift in growth this year that we had last year. So if you stripped all of that out, you'd see underlying acceleration. We're obviously not going to detail all of that out to get to the guidance. So those are the factors that are -- that affect the overall rate.
Sorry, one other thing. By the way -- sorry, about that, Gary. We had 1 less day in the year, so that's the other part of payroll service growth.
So all of those things imply, if you made it won't put you through the pain of doing, you'd see that we're actually accelerating a bit.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then a question on Flex. Just how does the product road map looks from here? You've talked in prior quarters about some of the major components that were added this last fiscal year. Are there more big pieces to the puzzle that n
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then a question on Flex. Just how does the product road map looks from here? You've talked in prior quarters about some of the major components that were added this last fiscal year. Are there more big pieces to the puzzle that need to be integrated or added? And then also as part of that, where are you now in terms of migration of customers?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Flex product, Gary, I think we've got most of everything the main pieces in there, particularly the paperless onboarding and recruiting and the benefits administration now they came in from BeneTrac that we integrated in. So we feel pretty good. I
componenttext: On the Flex product, Gary, I think we've got most of everything the main pieces in there, particularly the paperless onboarding and recruiting and the benefits administration now they came in from BeneTrac that we integrated in. So we feel pretty good. I think there's always other components that we're looking at competitively to see if we need to add. But for the most part, kind of the vast majority of everything is in now and integrated on a kind of single employee record, which is working well for the sales and so forth. The vast majority of our clients have -- are on the Flex platform. And so while we continue to work on some of the mid-market, the vast majority of the clients are already on Flex, and there isn't a migration that's needed from that standpoint. So I think we're in good shape with people on Flex. And they're gaining -- any one on Flex is gaining all the mobility addition. So a lot of work now is going to making mobility and the online visibility into a simpler, easier to use, more HTML5 kind of language, also the options for -- we haven't talked about it, but the options for Spanish. We've really put most everything in Spanish now, and we're seeing a nice uptick in sales to Hispanic businesses, which has been a focus for us the last few years from both a sales and service perspective. So I think what you'll see now is not as much product functionality that's missing as it is the look, the feel in the mobility piece of it. And by the way, everything's being developed here in our mobile first. So basically, you make it simple so that almost everything can be done on the phone, and then it grows more complex online.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Sara Gubins, Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from Sara Gubins, Bank of America.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: With any payroll service for the client count growth, I'm wondering if you're able to assess how much of the growth is coming from new business formation in the last year versus taking share of existing businesses?
componenttext: With any payroll service for the client count growth, I'm wondering if you're able to assess how much of the growth is coming from new business formation in the last year versus taking share of existing businesses?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have a precise number on that, Sara. But I can say that in the fourth quarter, in sales to newly formed businesses, were up about 10% from the quarter before. We had pretty nice bump. So I think we're getting some uplift from being, I think,
componenttext: Yes, I don't have a precise number on that, Sara. But I can say that in the fourth quarter, in sales to newly formed businesses, were up about 10% from the quarter before. We had pretty nice bump. So I think we're getting some uplift from being, I think, one, probably more competitive there; and second, from a little bit better business environment.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the client mix shift, given the fast growth in PEO, the ACA tailwind and Paychex Flex, are you seeing the client mix shifting more towards companies with over 50 employees?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the client mix shift, given the fast growth in PEO, the ACA tailwind and Paychex Flex, are you seeing the client mix shifting more towards companies with over 50 employees?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Actually, I think I mentioned it in previous call, and we'll put out the exact number to the right decimal in the K. But average client size was 17. We may have ended the year at 16.92 or .95. No significant change. I think we continue to have str
componenttext: No, no. Actually, I think I mentioned it in previous call, and we'll put out the exact number to the right decimal in the K. But average client size was 17. We may have ended the year at 16.92 or .95. No significant change. I think we continue to have strong mid-market sales. I would expect that number may go up. But this year, it was a little bit anomalous in that it's skewed a little bit lower. The timing it moves the needle.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last question on M&A. You've talked in the past about being interested in doing some larger M&A. What does the landscape look like? Is that something on the horizon in fiscal '17?
componenttext: Okay. And then just last question on M&A. You've talked in the past about being interested in doing some larger M&A. What does the landscape look like? Is that something on the horizon in fiscal '17?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're still pretty active, and we've got probably one of the better pipelines we've had. Still looking. It's -- the decision is the value and fit, and we're very selective about what we've acquired. We've done more acquisitions in the last 5 years th
componenttext: Yes, we're still pretty active, and we've got probably one of the better pipelines we've had. Still looking. It's -- the decision is the value and fit, and we're very selective about what we've acquired. We've done more acquisitions in the last 5 years than, I think, probably any time in history. And we felt very good about each one of those, whether from SurePayroll to now, Advance Partners. So I think we're still very active in it. It's hard to say whether things will come to fruition or not, but we feel good about the pipeline that's out there and the activity that we're involved in right now.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just following up earlier on the Flex question. Can you talk a little bit how the client uptake has been on the neural modules that you've rolled out?
componenttext: I guess, just following up earlier on the Flex question. Can you talk a little bit how the client uptake has been on the neural modules that you've rolled out?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's been good, the -- particularly the time and attendance piece of it as we've integrated it in and the mobility functionality. That's whether you can punch in, punch out and so forth, I think has been probably the most popular. I think tha
componenttext: Yes, I think it's been good, the -- particularly the time and attendance piece of it as we've integrated it in and the mobility functionality. That's whether you can punch in, punch out and so forth, I think has been probably the most popular. I think that's because you see there's overtime rules that have been approved now and that will be enacted soon. I think a lot of number of clients are now looking at time and attendance as something they really have to have, and they're looking at great options like ours. I think the electronic, basically, paperless onboarding and recruiting of new employees has been good. It's relatively new, and getting the sales teams to make sure it's in that first proposal has probably been more of a challenge. So we'll get it all in there. But I think that one has got a tremendous opportunity in front of it. I think we're going to -- we're starting to really capture that now a few months into after the release of it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just with your success in the mid-market and the team selling that you've talked about a lot recently. Is there like an average number of modules that clients are taking currently and how might that compare to last couple of years. Are you seeing
componenttext: And then just with your success in the mid-market and the team selling that you've talked about a lot recently. Is there like an average number of modules that clients are taking currently and how might that compare to last couple of years. Are you seeing that number going up?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: It definitely is going up because we can see it from a revenue per unit standpoint. We've seen a nice uptick over the years of revenue per unit. So more clients are taking the products upfront, particularly with the integrated selling approach. And that's
componenttext: It definitely is going up because we can see it from a revenue per unit standpoint. We've seen a nice uptick over the years of revenue per unit. So more clients are taking the products upfront, particularly with the integrated selling approach. And that's kind of it all sizes of clients, mid-market, right down to, I'd say, 10 to 15 employees even. There's much more of an acceptance of taking more modules, and there's much more of a need for it. And so the value has been much greater. I don't know if I could really -- if there's really an average number, but it definitely has increased the revenue per unit. And we're good at both. I think we're much better now at the integrated selling of selling that value up front that we talked about. And then as we go on, if the clients don't have it, we have a great team that kinds of back around to the clients and said, "Hey, now that you have, let's say, payroll and time and attendance, let's talk about benefit administration and so that can help you and the Affordable Care Act and everything else that we offer." So it definitely attachment has been a big part of our -- a big assistance to our growth rate.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last question, just following up on Sara's question in M&A. What areas are you looking at most? Is it things to add in payroll, in HRS? Are you looking at some of the adjacent other business areas you've talked about in the past?
componenttext: Last question, just following up on Sara's question in M&A. What areas are you looking at most? Is it things to add in payroll, in HRS? Are you looking at some of the adjacent other business areas you've talked about in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say we're always looking at payroll. There's opportunities out there for that. And we're looking also at product additions, tuck-in for product. But we've got most of that now, but we're always looking for that. And then, of course, all the areas
componenttext: Yes, I'd say we're always looking at payroll. There's opportunities out there for that. And we're looking also at product additions, tuck-in for product. But we've got most of that now, but we're always looking for that. And then, of course, all the areas that we're in, whether it be 401(k), PEO business, we're always looking at those opportunities as well. And then always looking at outside the country as well. What other opportunities are there for us. It's just a matter of, as I said it, we've never been probably more active or a longer pipeline, but the valuations are still relatively high. And we're very selective as to what we go forward with. But I would say all the above we're interested in, as long as they're a good fit and are good for both obviously, for the company, for our shareholders, we look to go forward with it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Kartik Mehta from Northcoast Research.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Efrain, any thoughts on how you might manage the fluid portfolio, considering where in a little bit of a different environment than we were a few months ago? Have you changed your thoughts on that at all?
componenttext: Efrain, any thoughts on how you might manage the fluid portfolio, considering where in a little bit of a different environment than we were a few months ago? Have you changed your thoughts on that at all?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's interesting you say that, Kartik. So I was driving in this morning, I was trying to figure out what happens if we're in an environment where the Fed doesn't raise during the year. And at this stage, I haven't decided to make any changes. But it's cer
componenttext: It's interesting you say that, Kartik. So I was driving in this morning, I was trying to figure out what happens if we're in an environment where the Fed doesn't raise during the year. And at this stage, I haven't decided to make any changes. But it's certainly something that we'd have to look at the duration of the portfolio, if the yield curve looks the way it is now over time. And no decisions on that. But that's something I'll -- we'll have some discussions on as we go through the quarter. It's just -- as you can imagine, it's pretty dizzying trying to figure out what the right scenario is when, I would say 3 months ago, we were thinking there might be as many as 3 raises in the next -- in the fiscal year. And now, it looks increasingly like if you get one, that'll be a lot, maybe 0. So yes, we're thinking about how to create the right portfolio structure without increasing risk.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Marty, you talked a little bit about Flex. And obviously, Flex is a much better product for your clients. And you talked a little bit about maybe trying to sell more value-added services. It seems like that's just starting. Could you see legs because
componenttext: And Marty, you talked a little bit about Flex. And obviously, Flex is a much better product for your clients. And you talked a little bit about maybe trying to sell more value-added services. It seems like that's just starting. Could you see legs because of its -- your ability to sell other value-added products at least what you're seeing so far, help kind of accelerate the revenue growth rate for the payroll business?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly hope so. I mean, what we've seen is more revenue per client. And we've seen that consistently. And that's because the Flex platform allows that integration of various product bundles of different functionality within a single employee r
componenttext: Well, we certainly hope so. I mean, what we've seen is more revenue per client. And we've seen that consistently. And that's because the Flex platform allows that integration of various product bundles of different functionality within a single employee record. And that it also allows you that access to the mobile app, which has been very popular. So I think the opportunity is there. I mean, when we look out, obviously, as far as we can go as the guidance that we look at pretty closely that Efrain has detailed. And so we certainly hope the opportunity is there. We're keeping it and we're, I think, very, very competitive with it, and that certainly is our hope.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing, Kartik, I'd like to add that is important and I think I mentioned this after the third quarter in a number of comments. It's important to remember that when we sell Flex, a portion of that revenue is payroll. And a lot of it's been report
componenttext: The other thing, Kartik, I'd like to add that is important and I think I mentioned this after the third quarter in a number of comments. It's important to remember that when we sell Flex, a portion of that revenue is payroll. And a lot of it's been reported in HRS. I caution that while we're not walking away from looking at payroll revenues an important part of the revenue growth of the company. Increasingly, when we sell Flex, a portion of that's reported in HRS. So all of the discussions we've talked about, modules like time and attendance, HR administration, expense management, applicant tracking and recruiting, employee shared responsibility or ACA, those are all reported in HRS. So you need to look at both pieces to really kind of get a complete assessment of how we're doing.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think of it more kind of in total service revenue because it does obviously, it bleeds over into both of them.
componenttext: Yes, we think of it more kind of in total service revenue because it does obviously, it bleeds over into both of them.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And just for the last question, now that you've owned Advance Partners for a few months, and that was a business that you were excited about in the beginning. I'm just wondering, is that something that still is what you expected? And is that
componenttext: That's fair. And just for the last question, now that you've owned Advance Partners for a few months, and that was a business that you were excited about in the beginning. I'm just wondering, is that something that still is what you expected? And is that a business that you could potentially acquire other businesses to get additional scale?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. In fact, we feel they've been performing extremely well. The whole leadership team has come with the company, so we're excited about that. So they performed well. We've already been looking for opportunities to increase the scale there an
componenttext: Yes, I think so. In fact, we feel they've been performing extremely well. The whole leadership team has come with the company, so we're excited about that. So they performed well. We've already been looking for opportunities to increase the scale there and have a few kind of in the pipeline that we're looking at. And yes, we think we're very pleased with the first 6 months of how that's been going and the results that they have. And of course, to tie into our clients that have a number of opportunities for them and some opportunities from their clients for us. So we're very pleased with the acquisition and the team there and how we're off to a good start.

componenttext: I know you're mostly a U.S.-centric-focused company, but I'm just curious in terms of the impact of Brexit, if at all. Would this maybe preclude you from potentially expanding in that region? If you can impart on the U.S. business at all.

componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Marty. I don't think so. We don't -- we're mostly outside the U.S., we're mostly in Germany. And then we have the Brazil started there. So we don't see it. Obviously, from an acquisition standpoint, there are opportunities there that we would
componenttext: Yes, this is Marty. I don't think so. We don't -- we're mostly outside the U.S., we're mostly in Germany. And then we have the Brazil started there. So we don't see it. Obviously, from an acquisition standpoint, there are opportunities there that we would be probably a little more cautious about given kind of the uncertainty over a longer period of time. But right in the short term, certainly, it has very little, if any, impact on us, at least from the U.K. perspective.

componenttext: Was waiting for that. You get the gold star for that question, Jeff. So the answer is we had some small investments that we wrote down the value. Didn't write them off but grow down the value in that portfolio, very, very small things. But the way we record that is in that line. So that's why it went negative.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Grossman, Stifel Financial.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Grossman, Stifel Financial.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping maybe, Marty, you can address your comments about the middle-market. Seems you're doing well. And as you probably know, there are several others claiming prosperity in that segment as well. How much of that, maybe is HR driven or other fundam
componenttext: I was hoping maybe, Marty, you can address your comments about the middle-market. Seems you're doing well. And as you probably know, there are several others claiming prosperity in that segment as well. How much of that, maybe is HR driven or other fundamental factors in the marketplace? And obviously, you've done a lot to invest in that segment over the last several years and just curious if there are other factors that work there that maybe driving mid-market clients to go to an outsourced solution.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think definitely a number of them. One, I think the need -- the complications of compliance with all the regulations have increased. So you have ACA, but you have the recently done overtime regulations. You have paid leave now for families you got
componenttext: Yes, I think definitely a number of them. One, I think the need -- the complications of compliance with all the regulations have increased. So you have ACA, but you have the recently done overtime regulations. You have paid leave now for families you got to keep track of. You have a lot more immigration and keeping track of who your employees are and all that, that you have to be backed up with. And the enforcement of the rules is we see are stronger. So more businesses are being impacted by audits, by investigations, by are you following the rules correctly. And because states and the Fed's are also looking for more revenue sources, so states can go after things. So I think that whole regulation side is becoming increasingly more complex at a lower level. So we're seeing people -- we're seeing clients buy time and attendance that normally were probably 40 employees and higher, 30. PEO tended to be higher. Now it's coming down lower. They're looking for help with insurance and benefit plans because they have to be more competitive. The other second thing would be the market is more competitive now for employees as you get closer to lower unemployment and full employment. And so people need more help with having more competitive benefits, more competitive recruiting tools, being able to recruit online, paperless, attract new employees. And I think -- there was another one there I was thinking about -- oh, and I think the acceptance of cloud-based technology and having -- and getting away from desktop and on-premise solutions has rapidly increased the last 3 to 4 years. But we're still seeing that increase where years ago, you -- people want to do more things themselves, worry about their security. Now they want to trust their security of information with a third-party outsourcer. Kind of totally reversed from 5 or 6 years ago. Now they just Paychex is large enough and a big enough IT security team that they're going to do their best to protect their information where I used to have to do it inside. So I think there's just a big push of regulations, compliance and the need, therefore, pushing down to a lower level. And so we're seeing -- that mid-market that I would say used to be 50 to 500 or 1,000 has really pushed down to maybe 15 or 20 to 500 is a real sweet spot right now that a lot of focus.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with the products that you have now, obviously, you're at one point historically that was a limiting factor for you in the mid-market. And so any appetite to go after a bigger client segment of the market? Or do you feel you'd rather just sit below the
componenttext: So with the products that you have now, obviously, you're at one point historically that was a limiting factor for you in the mid-market. And so any appetite to go after a bigger client segment of the market? Or do you feel you'd rather just sit below the radar screen where others may define the mid-market.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, never feels like were below radar. But I think there's -- that the real sweet spot of what has taken off many companies, at least a period to do well and I know how we're doing well, is really even that 15 or 20 to 500. I mean, we were still selling
componenttext: Yes, never feels like were below radar. But I think there's -- that the real sweet spot of what has taken off many companies, at least a period to do well and I know how we're doing well, is really even that 15 or 20 to 500. I mean, we were still selling anywhere from 1 employee to 1,000. But I would say the hottest area right now is 20 to 250 or 20 to 500. Those are the clients that really has been pushed with much more regulation and need for the products. And I don't know how much more open to outsourcing. So I think we feel good about the opportunity that's ahead of us that that's going to drive our growth. And it also allows us to really focus on those market. That's a pretty huge market,, 1 to 1,000, and we feel pretty good bet and we're very focused on that and that's what we provide the best service and the best products to.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: So net is 0?

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: The next question comes from James Schneider, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe talk about the -- on the HR Services forecast, whether anything specific in terms of product-specific drivers you call out contributing to the growth. You've talked about time and attendance and HR administration as bein
componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe talk about the -- on the HR Services forecast, whether anything specific in terms of product-specific drivers you call out contributing to the growth. You've talked about time and attendance and HR administration as being drivers of the past. Anything notable to call out as far as the FY '17 guidance is concerned?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think PEO, we haven't talked as much about that, but I think PEO is still very strong. And that  part of that is supported by or helped by the need for insurance support and benefit plans and so forth. So we still see that growing very well. Worksite em
componenttext: I think PEO, we haven't talked as much about that, but I think PEO is still very strong. And that  part of that is supported by or helped by the need for insurance support and benefit plans and so forth. So we still see that growing very well. Worksite employees are double-digit growth again. And so I think the PEO and ASO, both models are continuing to grow well. 401(k) has been really steady. And I think we talked about the fact that he went after larger, what we call large market or higher-asset client. And we feel that that's got a great opportunity as well. A lot of things kick around about 401(k)s and so forth. But we're still doing very well, really introducing, sell more 401(k) record, keeping plans that anybody else, and we've got a solid sales and service team that really do very well there. So the sales have been consistent, the client growth very consistent in 401(k). And the retention this year, probably the best it's been in our history, so I think all those components we don't talk to as much, but they've been steady and real good components of the growth.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe could you just may be comment at a broad level about the level of discounting you're seeing in the market right now maybe whether there's more pressure, less pressure than it was a year ago, and if so, in what segment?
componenttext: And maybe could you just may be comment at a broad level about the level of discounting you're seeing in the market right now maybe whether there's more pressure, less pressure than it was a year ago, and if so, in what segment?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a little bit more pressure probably. I think with more competitors and so forth, it's not a big change in the competitive environment, believe it or not, for the number that are out there all seem to be doing well. But I think there's a
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a little bit more pressure probably. I think with more competitors and so forth, it's not a big change in the competitive environment, believe it or not, for the number that are out there all seem to be doing well. But I think there's a little more pressure on price. And on the low end, there's a little more pressure because I think as new businesses, as Efrain said, the new businesses have kind of come back. And so when you have new businesses that start-up, there's always a little pressure for them to first kind of outsource and go to someone to do their payroll and maybe their payroll and time and attendance. There's a little more price pressure to get them in started. But remember that we've enrolled off a lot of times the discount for a period of time. So I think a little bit more pressure there, but nothing that would be major at this point.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: There certainly has been sales growth. That's -- as Efrain and I said, that's where we added a nice percent of the sales force mid-year, which is rare for us. We felt the opportunity was so good with the Flex product and all the modules that we added. So sales have been definitely stronger. I think the other thing you made mentioned...

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just saying post the calendar year transition and that surge of activity, the clients that may have come on just because it's like, "Okay, we're scrambling to get ready for this." Now that that scramble is over, are you seeing any sort of change in th
componenttext: I'm just saying post the calendar year transition and that surge of activity, the clients that may have come on just because it's like, "Okay, we're scrambling to get ready for this." Now that that scramble is over, are you seeing any sort of change in the pace?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not, really. Okay. We really haven't. I mean, those -- and that's why we felt good about having those additional sales reps in place there because we're seeing a strong demand. And I think it's all the things I mentioned earlier that why we're seeing
componenttext: No, not, really. Okay. We really haven't. I mean, those -- and that's why we felt good about having those additional sales reps in place there because we're seeing a strong demand. And I think it's all the things I mentioned earlier that why we're seeing that. So now we feel very good. And the other thing is mid-market, I think I mentioned earlier, it's funny. It used to be that kind of 50 line for us. But I think you're seeing a lot of what you could call mid-market demand anyway is kind of gotten down to an even lower size. And so in that momentum has picked up and that gives you a lot of opportunity to sell more products as they need more.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about the -- what the right level of leverage expectations beyond this year would likely be like how do we think about that relative to the normal historical pattern?
componenttext: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about the -- what the right level of leverage expectations beyond this year would likely be like how do we think about that relative to the normal historical pattern?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Mark, I...
componenttext: Yes, so Mark, I...

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: X float.
componenttext: X float.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, x float. So we -- this year, x float, we were at about 50 basis points of leverage, which is what we typically do in a given year. We'll be less than that next year for the reasons that I called out. But I still think that going forward, we're going
componenttext: Yes, x float. So we -- this year, x float, we were at about 50 basis points of leverage, which is what we typically do in a given year. We'll be less than that next year for the reasons that I called out. But I still think that going forward, we're going to try to be in that 50-plus basis point leverage range. And if we can't hit that in a given year, then we can have a specific reason why we can't. In this case, we had a lot of discussions internally about do we add the resources that both in compliance services, as I mentioned earlier, and it mid-market. And it was pretty clear that given the amount of growth we had to do that. But I don't think that's going to happen every single year. But it was important this year. But I don't think it changes long term the trajectory of building plans that include 50 basis points plus because that's the way we go into our planning cycles. And we think it's doable. It's hard. It takes a lot of work, but we think it's doable.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And can you talk about the opportunity to go in and sell some of the newer modules, the newer solutions to some of the older, existing clients in the mid-market? What's -- how much runway do you have there in terms of upselling some of those existi
componenttext: Great. And can you talk about the opportunity to go in and sell some of the newer modules, the newer solutions to some of the older, existing clients in the mid-market? What's -- how much runway do you have there in terms of upselling some of those existing clients?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think still quite a bit of room. When you think about the penetration, these products really haven't been -- many of our products, even HR administration online and time and attendance online are older time and attendance products really haven't be
componenttext: Yes, I think still quite a bit of room. When you think about the penetration, these products really haven't been -- many of our products, even HR administration online and time and attendance online are older time and attendance products really haven't been around that long. It's been more of the last 3 to 4 years, maybe 5, tops. BeneTrac a little bit longer and benefits admin. So there's room there. And I think if they see the benefit of Flex and the mobility that comes with it, mobile options and the whole different look and feel to it, I think that helps sell them, along with that there's many other product modules available to you. And the fact that it's really with one single employee record I think that is pulling a lot of clients in where 5 years ago, we would have said you have payroll and other modules, but they're not fully integrated. Now there's much more of the pull from the clients. I think we've got some nice opportunities still in the mid-market you're selling new -- we're selling much more integrated upfront and better attachment rates, but there still a lot of room, which we -- and we do that's the attack and go back to the base to sell them the value-added features that they need.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you doing that with the regular sales force? Or is there a kind of a gatherer group that kind of goes into existing clients?
componenttext: Are you doing that with the regular sales force? Or is there a kind of a gatherer group that kind of goes into existing clients?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a mix. We have both kind of a virtual sales that go back into the base as well. But those existing reps who have the relationships and so forth will also with the clients will go back and sell it. So both can sell.
componenttext: Yes, it's a mix. We have both kind of a virtual sales that go back into the base as well. But those existing reps who have the relationships and so forth will also with the clients will go back and sell it. So both can sell.

componenttextpreview: Okay. I have a sort of a broader GDP sensitivity question. So when you look at the mix of business that you have now, which has a higher contribution, higher percent contributions from HRS, which to me basically says bigger share of wallet and any time yo
componenttext: Okay. I have a sort of a broader GDP sensitivity question. So when you look at the mix of business that you have now, which has a higher contribution, higher percent contributions from HRS, which to me basically says bigger share of wallet and any time you have bigger share of wallet, it probably means a more stable client. You got the bigger mid-market business, again similar conclusion. You got investment contribution that's kind of almost going the last downturn. So how do you think of the potential impact of a downturn in economic expectations should it happen?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if it should happen, I mean, I think, obviously the biggest impact -- if I get your question right, Ashwin, I think the biggest impact there would be new client growth. Because last -- any time a recessionary-type thing happens, it has impact on the pa
componenttext: So if it should happen, I mean, I think, obviously the biggest impact -- if I get your question right, Ashwin, I think the biggest impact there would be new client growth. Because last -- any time a recessionary-type thing happens, it has impact on the payroll service revenue growth because the clients either more of a loss because they can't sustain the business and fewer startup. So the client growth puts obviously a damper on that. I don't think we've definitely laid out what exactly it would be. It doesn't always have an impact on the number of products they buy because they typically buy those -- that bundle, let's say, because they need it for those staying business. The biggest impact will be losses, client retention and new business startups would be the biggest impact, I'd say.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's basically what I was trying to say earlier on that piece of it was it's not -- for a while, that was -- well, it was hurting margins a bit, but we were offsetting a lot of it with operational efficiencies and driving those efficiency, those
componenttext: I think that's basically what I was trying to say earlier on that piece of it was it's not -- for a while, that was -- well, it was hurting margins a bit, but we were offsetting a lot of it with operational efficiencies and driving those efficiency, those dollars kind of back to IT for technology investment and kind of resetting the level of technology spend versus the operational spend. And so now we kind of feel like the technology spend got to a point where it's pretty normalized. It's in a good place. We don't see that going up dramatically. I don't necessarily see it going down because there's always technology, and we want to stay on the leading edge from a competitive standpoint. But -- and then there's not as much operational leverage. But we continue to, as Efrain said, we're going to -- we continue to try to look. It's kind of in our DNA here that we always are looking at revenue growth is x, we're always trying to look for 50 basis points or so to see if we can continue to leverage the business. And obviously, the better that growth rate is, the better opportunity we have to leverage. And that's a constant focus. Anything you want to add to that?
