componenttext: Yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from James Schneider, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from James Schneider, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe talk about the -- I mean, HR Services growth forecast, whether there's anything specific in terms of product, specific drivers you can call out contributing to the growth. You've talked about time and attendance and HR a
componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe talk about the -- I mean, HR Services growth forecast, whether there's anything specific in terms of product, specific drivers you can call out contributing to the growth. You've talked about time and attendance and HR administration as being drivers in the past. Anything notable to call out as far as the FY '17 guidance is concerned?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, PEO. We haven't talked as much about that, but I think PEO is still very strong. And that -- part of that is supported by or helped by the need for insurance support and benefit plans and so forth, so we still see that growing very well. Worksite
componenttext: I think, PEO. We haven't talked as much about that, but I think PEO is still very strong. And that -- part of that is supported by or helped by the need for insurance support and benefit plans and so forth, so we still see that growing very well. Worksite employees are double-digit growth again. And so I think the PEO and ASO, both models are continuing to grow well. 401(k) has been very steady. And we've -- I think we've talked about the fact that we went after a larger, what we call a large market or higher-asset clients, and we feel that, that's got a great opportunity as well. A lot of things kick around about 401(k)s and so forth, but we're still doing very well, really introduce and sell more 401(k) recordkeeping plans than anybody else, and we've got a solid sales and service team that really do very well there. So the sales have been consistent, the client growth very consistent in 401(k) and the retention this year probably the best it's been in our history. So I think all those components, we don't talk to as much, but they've been steady and real good components of the growth.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe -- could you just maybe comment at a broad level about the level of discounting you're seeing in the market right now and maybe whether there's more pressure or less pressure than it was a year ago? And if so, in what segment?
componenttext: And maybe -- could you just maybe comment at a broad level about the level of discounting you're seeing in the market right now and maybe whether there's more pressure or less pressure than it was a year ago? And if so, in what segment?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a little bit more pressure, probably. I think with more competitors and so forth, it's not a big change in the competitive environment, believe it or not, for the number that are out there, it all seem to be doing well. But I think there
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a little bit more pressure, probably. I think with more competitors and so forth, it's not a big change in the competitive environment, believe it or not, for the number that are out there, it all seem to be doing well. But I think there's a little more pressure on price. And on the low end, there's a little more pressure because I think as new businesses -- as Efrain said, the new businesses have kind of come back. And so when you have new businesses that's startup, there's always a little pressure to -- for them to first kind of outsource and go to someone to do their payroll, and maybe their payroll and time and attendance. There's a little more price pressure to get them in, started. But remember that we then roll-off a lot of times the discount for a period of time. So I think a little bit more pressure there, but nothing that would be major at this point.

componenttext: That's excluding that benefit, Rick [ph]. So yes, I called that out, so it's important to remember.

componenttextpreview: So a few questions. First of all, with regards to the mid-market, has there been any discernible change in the pace in terms of bookings growth, the pipeline, post this kind of on the mid-market, little bit of the ACA surge in that over 50 employee segmen
componenttext: So a few questions. First of all, with regards to the mid-market, has there been any discernible change in the pace in terms of bookings growth, the pipeline, post this kind of on the mid-market, little bit of the ACA surge in that over 50 employee segment?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- there certainly has been sales growth. That's -- as Efrain and I said, that's where we added a nice percent to the sales force mid-year, which is rare for us. We felt the opportunity was so good with the Flex product and all the additional modules th
componenttext: I -- there certainly has been sales growth. That's -- as Efrain and I said, that's where we added a nice percent to the sales force mid-year, which is rare for us. We felt the opportunity was so good with the Flex product and all the additional modules that we added. So sales booking have been definitely stronger. I think the other thing you may have mentioned...

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just saying like post the calendar year transition and that surge of activity, the clients that may have come on just because it's like, "Okay, we're scrambling to get ready for this." Now that, that scramble is over, are you seeing any sort of change
componenttext: I'm just saying like post the calendar year transition and that surge of activity, the clients that may have come on just because it's like, "Okay, we're scrambling to get ready for this." Now that, that scramble is over, are you seeing any sort of change in the pace?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Not really. No. Okay. No, not -- we really haven't. I mean, those -- and that's why we felt good about having those additional sales reps in place there because we're still seeing there's a strong demand. And I think it's all the things that I mention
componenttext: No. Not really. No. Okay. No, not -- we really haven't. I mean, those -- and that's why we felt good about having those additional sales reps in place there because we're still seeing there's a strong demand. And I think it's all the things that I mentioned earlier that -- and why we're seeing that. So now we feel very good. And the other thing is mid-market, as I might -- I think I mentioned earlier, it's funny, it used to be that kind of 50 line for us, but I think you're seeing a lot of what you could call mid-market demand anyway is kind of gotten down to an even lower size. And so -- and that momentum has picked up and that gives you a lot of opportunity to sell more products as they need more.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about the -- what the right level of leverage expectations beyond this year would likely be? Like how do we think about that relative to the normal historical pattern?
componenttext: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about the -- what the right level of leverage expectations beyond this year would likely be? Like how do we think about that relative to the normal historical pattern?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Mark, I...
componenttext: Yes, so Mark, I...

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ex float.
componenttext: Ex float.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, ex float. So we -- this year, ex float, we were at about 50 basis points of leverage, which is what we typically do in a given year. We'll be less than that next year for the reasons that I called out. But I still think that going forward, we're goin
componenttext: Yes, ex float. So we -- this year, ex float, we were at about 50 basis points of leverage, which is what we typically do in a given year. We'll be less than that next year for the reasons that I called out. But I still think that going forward, we're going to try to be in that 50-plus basis point leverage range. And if we can't hit that in a given year, then we're going to have a specific reason why we can't. In this case, we had a lot of discussions internally about do we add the resources that -- both in compliance services, as I mentioned earlier, and in mid-market. And it was pretty clear that given the amount of growth we had to do that. But I don't think that's going to happen every single year, but it was important this year. But I don't think it changes, long term, the trajectory of building plans that include 50 basis point plus because that's the way we go into our planning cycles. And we think it's doable. It's hard. It takes a lot of work, but we think it's doable.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then can you talk about the opportunity to go in and sell some of the newer modules, the newer solutions to some of the older, existing clients in the mid-market? What's -- how much runway do you have there in terms of upselling some of those e
componenttext: Great. And then can you talk about the opportunity to go in and sell some of the newer modules, the newer solutions to some of the older, existing clients in the mid-market? What's -- how much runway do you have there in terms of upselling some of those existing clients?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think still quite a bit of room when you think about the penetration. These products really haven't been -- many of our products, even HR administration online and time and attendance online are older time and attendance products, really haven't be
componenttext: Yes. I think still quite a bit of room when you think about the penetration. These products really haven't been -- many of our products, even HR administration online and time and attendance online are older time and attendance products, really haven't been around that long. It's been more of the last 3 to 4 years, maybe 5, tops. BeneTrac a little bit longer and benefits admin. So there's room there. And I think as they see the benefit of Flex and the mobility that comes with it, the mobile options and the whole different look and feel to it, I think that helps sell them along with, that there's many more product modules available to you. And the fact that it's really with one single employee record, I think, that is pulling a lot of clients in. Where 5 years ago, we would have said, a, you have payroll and you have other modules, but they're not fully integrated. Now there's much more of a pull from the clients. So I think we've got some nice opportunities still in the mid-market. Selling new -- we're selling much more integrated upfront and better attachment rates, but there's still a lot of room, which we -- and when we do that, we attack, we go back into the base to sell them the value-added features that they need.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I have a sort of a broader GDP sensitivity question. So when you look at the mix of business that you have now which has a higher contribution, higher percent contribution from HRS, which to me it basically says bigger share of wallet. And any time
componenttext: Okay. I have a sort of a broader GDP sensitivity question. So when you look at the mix of business that you have now which has a higher contribution, higher percent contribution from HRS, which to me it basically says bigger share of wallet. And any time you have bigger share of wallet, it probably means a more stable client. You got the bigger mid-market business, again, similar conclusion. You got investment contribution that's kind of almost 1/3 of what it was going to the last downturn. So how do you think of the potential impact of a downturn in economic expectations, should it happen?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if it should happen, I mean, I think, obviously the biggest impact -- if I get your question right, Ashwin, I think the biggest impact there would be on new client growth. Because last -- any time a recessionary-type thing happens, it has impact on the
componenttext: So if it should happen, I mean, I think, obviously the biggest impact -- if I get your question right, Ashwin, I think the biggest impact there would be on new client growth. Because last -- any time a recessionary-type thing happens, it has impact on the payroll service revenue growth because the clients either -- more go loss because they can't sustain the business and fewer start up. So the client growth puts obviously a damper on that. I don't think we've definitely laid it out what exactly that would be. It doesn't always have an impact on the number of products they buy because they typically buy those that bundle, but let's say, because they need it, for those that are staying in business. The biggest impact will be losses, client retention and new business startups would be the biggest impact, I'd say.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Specific to technology spend. Last year, I think was the first time in many years that you said basically that it's maybe the rate of growth was settling down, similar comment this year. Is this just the kind of market and client expectation that you have
componenttext: Specific to technology spend. Last year, I think was the first time in many years that you said basically that it's maybe the rate of growth was settling down, similar comment this year. Is this just the kind of market and client expectation that you have to keep that tech spend up where you don't really get leverage from it, but it's clearly not hurting on operating margins? So you kind of -- when you say steady, steady as a percent of revenue? Is it...

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's basically what I was trying to say earlier on that piece of it was it's not -- for a while, that was -- well, it was hurting margins a bit, but we were offsetting a lot of it with operational efficiencies and driving those efficiency,
componenttext: Yes. I think that's basically what I was trying to say earlier on that piece of it was it's not -- for a while, that was -- well, it was hurting margins a bit, but we were offsetting a lot of it with operational efficiencies and driving those efficiency, those dollars kind of back to IT for technology investment and kind of resetting the level of technology spend versus the operational spend. And so now we kind of feel like the technology spend got to a point where it's pretty normalized. It's in a good place. We don't see that going up dramatically. I don't necessarily see it going down because there's always technology and we want to stay on the leading edge from a competitive standpoint. But -- and then there's not as much operational leverage. But we continue to, as Efrain said, we're going to -- we continue to try to look. It's kind of in our DNA here that we always are looking, hey, if revenue growth is x, we're always trying to look for 50 basis points or so to see if we can continue to leverage the business. And obviously, the better that growth rate is, the better opportunity we have to leverage. And that's a constant focus. Anything you want to add to that?

componenttext: Just one quick one for me. Can you just talk about with Advance, now that you're 5 or 6 months into the acquisition, the role they're going to be playing in your portfolio? Like are they a customer acquisition engine for you where you'll be able to sell in your existing payroll and other services? Or how should we be thinking about that, both for Advance and then, I guess, future acquisitions like that?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. For them, as Efrain mentioned, they're really not in our client count, so -- in our payroll client count that we always give for the over 600,000 clients. And so it's not so much about client acquisition other than for themselves. So we're looking fo
componenttext:
Yes. For them, as Efrain mentioned, they're really not in our client count, so -- in our payroll client count that we always give for the over 600,000 clients. And so it's not so much about client acquisition other than for themselves. So we're looking for them to grow their revenue base through new clients, obviously, and selling more product to them. To us, it was broadening really the markets that we serve. So here's a company that is profitable, is -- had nice revenue growth, good leadership team, saw a lot of potential. And the staffing business, that they support those staffing companies, we saw as a growing market. And because there's continued more temporary help in staffing, help that's going to be needed, I think particularly with overtime rules and so forth, so we saw them as a component of the portfolio to grow revenue. There'll be some overlap between us in the fact that we have a number of staffing companies that are payroll clients or other products, and so we'll look to refer. We're already doing that, looking to see if those staffing companies who are clients of us for payroll could be helped by payroll funding and other support from Advance. But I think that's how we look at it as another opportunity to broaden our revenue growth because we see staffing companies as a real growth opportunity.
Is that it, Tessa?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining us for our discussion of Paychex First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results f
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining us for our discussion of Paychex First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. 
This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results for first quarter ended August 31, 2016. Our Form 10-Q will be filed with the SEC within the next few days, and you can access our earnings release and Form 10-Q on our Investor Relations webpage as they become available. This teleconference is being broadcast over the Internet and will be archived and available on our website for approximately 1 month. 
On today's call, I'll review highlights for the first quarter in relationship -- in relation to sales and ops and product management, development areas. Efrain will review first quarter financial results and discuss our full year guidance, and then we'll open it up your questions. 
We are off to a solid start for Fiscal 2017 with positive results across all major product lines. The number of client worksite employees served by our human resource outsourcing services grew by double digits over -- on a year-over-year basis. Our cloud-based HCM services, including time and attendance and human resource management, continued to gain strong market acceptance in the quarter as well as last year. 
Payroll service revenue grew 4% for the first quarter. HRS revenue increased 15% for the quarter, driven largely by growth in the client base across all major HCM categories. Total service revenue, up 9%. We acquired Advance Partners last December and are very pleased with their contribution to our results. Advance Partners contributed approximately 1.5% to the growth in the service revenue for the first quarter. 
Client retention has remained strong, providing excellent customer service as our top priority. We've continued to invest in our operations and compliant services to support growth and ensure we maintain best-in-class client service. 
One area of focus has been the expansion of our multiproduct service center, which primarily assist our mid-market clients who attach additional services with payroll. We have also invested in our insurance operations [indiscernible] to increase support for our Affordable Care Act service clients as we approach the 2016 calendar ry filing. 
We usually announced the expansion of the AICPA Paychex partner program to include Human Resource Services in addition to payroll and retirement benefits. This program allows CPAs who refer to us to broaden our advisory role with clients by offering them a suite of best-in-class services and provide a strong referral channel for us. We are proud to be the preferred provider of payroll retirement and now human resource outsourcing services for the AICPA, CPA.com and its CPA members. 
The Department of Labor's Final Overtime Rule has become effective -- will become effective December 1, which will expand overtime for millions of workers. This new legislation makes accurate time and attendance tracking more important than ever, and we have found that many business remain unaware of the legislation and the impact on their business. We recently announced enhancements to our time and service portfolio with the addition of Paychex Flex Time essentials, TrueShift timeclock and an advanced scheduling feature within our Paychex Flex Time module. The investment in this technology demonstrates our continued commitment to providing industry-leading solutions that educate and assist our clients to comply with the new regulations and stay more connected to their employees and their businesses. These new products enhance our commitment to supporting our clients through the entire employee journey, from the posting of a position, interviewing and job offer, onboarding the new employee and handling all the daily tasks and life events with a simple, integrated, SaaS software-as-a-solution platform, combined with personalized and flexible service options. We're very proud of the support our employees provide small and midsized businesses with this broad and advanced product set in commitment to great service, particularly as we enter our 45th [ph] year in business. 
Along with that, I'm very proud of some recent recognition our Paychex team has received. Our insurance agency ranked #23 on Business Insurance magazine's 2016 list of top 100 brokers of U.S. business. This is our sixth appearance on the list, and we once again ranked as one of the fastest-growing insurance agencies in the nation. 
We've been named to Selling Power Magazine's 2016 list of 50 Best Companies To Sell For, landing at #7. This is the fourth consecutive year of Paychex has appeared in the list, moving up from the #9 spot last year. Very proud to be in the top 10 of best companies to sell for. 
And Paychex was once again ranked as the largest 401(k) recordkeeper by total number of defined contribution plans according to the recent survey [indiscernible] sponsored magazine, a national publication dedicated to the pension and retirement industry. 
We also continue with our shareholder friendly actions in the first quarter. In July, we increased our quarterly dividend by 10% or $0.04 per share to $0.46 per share. Our Board of Directors also approved an additional authorization to repurchase up to $350 million of our outstanding common stock, which expires now in May of 2019. We did not repurchase any shares in the first quarter, but will continue to assess the opportunity to buy back shares during the year to offset dilution. 
In summary, we are off to a great solid start. We're receiving very good recognition, and I'm very appreciative of the great work of our Paychex employee team, sales ops and all the support teams in the company. 
I'll now turn the call over to Efrain Rivera, and Efrain will review our financial results in more detail. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call with certain forward-looking statements -- will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such involve some risks. Please refer to our ea
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call with certain forward-looking statements -- will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such involve some risks. Please refer to our earnings release that includes a discussion of forward-looking statements and related risk factors. 
As discussed, first quarter financial results for fiscal 2017 represent a solid start to the year. Here are some of the key highlights for the quarter. I'll provide greater detail in certain areas and end with the review of our 2017 outlook. 
Total service revenue grew 9% for the first quarter to [ph] $774 million. Interest on funds held for clients increased 11% for the first quarter to $12 million as a result of higher average interest rates earned. Expenses increased 8% for the first quarter, and Advance Partners contributed approximately 1% of this growth. Compensation-related expenses increased 6%, primarily due to higher wages resulting from growth in headcount in both operations and sales. Our effective income tax rate was 33% [ph] for the first quarter compared to 29.7% to the prior year's first quarter. The effective income tax rates have been impacted by discrete tax items recognized in both of these periods, so last quarter -- last year's first quarter [indiscernible] year's first quarter. In the first quarter of this fiscal year, we recorded the tax benefit resulting from the adoption of new accounting guidance, partially offset by the recognition of an additional provision related to a state tax matter. These items increased diluted earnings per share by approximately 2 and 1/2 cents share to be precise. If you remember last year in the first quarter, we recognized a net tax benefit, an income from prior tax years related to customer-facing software we produced. This resulted in an increase in diluted earnings per share of approximately $0.06 per share for that period. So now if I could just do an editorial. 
You'll see that when we talk about net income, we carefully say as reported net income. So we're going to give you guidance on as reported net income and net income excluding discrete items. The punchline to that is that there's been no change. We just need you to look at those 2 items down to discrete items. We'll talk about that in a second and see that essentially, it doesn't change the guidance. I have seen some notes that seem to think it does. It doesn't. I'll come to that in a second. 
I just mentioned adoption of new accounting guidance impacting the effective tax rate. We early adopted new accounting guidance related to employee share-based payment. As a result, we recognized a net tax benefit and an income statement. This was previously required to be recorded as additional paid in capital in equity. On an as reported basis, net income increased 4% to $217 million and diluted EPS increased 3% to $0.60 per share in the first quarter. Growth rates for net income and diluted earnings per share were impacted by approximately 5% and 6% as a result of the recognition of the discrete items in the respective periods. So I give you those numbers so you can reconcile back to what it would look like if you excluded those items. 
Let's talk about payroll service revenue. Increased 4% for the first quarter to $451 million. We benefited from increases in client base and revenue per check. Revenue per check grew as a result of price increases net of discounting. 
In addition, Advance Partners, which we acquired last year, contributed approximately 1% to the growth in payroll service revenue for the first quarter. Checks per payroll were not a contributing factor in the recorded payroll revenue growth, and we expect to continue to see that to be the case. 
HRS revenue increased strongly to 15% in the first quarter, $323 million. Increase reflected strong growth in client base across all major HCM services, including our comprehensive outsourcing services, retirement services, time and attendance and HR administration. I take this point or pause to just say that remember that part of what we report nature [ph] as are the modules that we sell on the HCM system. So in order to understand clearly what we're doing, you need to look at both categories. 
Within Paychex HR Services, we continue to see strong demand, which is reflected in a double-digit year-over-year growth in a number of client worksite employees served. 
Insurance services benefited from continued growth in revenue from our full service Affordable Care Act product and growth in the number of health and benefit applicants. Our workers' comp insurance product benefited from higher average premiums and client base growth. Retirement services revenue benefited from increase in asset fee revenue earned on the value purchase and funds as well as an increase in clients served. 
Last, Advance Partners contributed approximately 2% to the growth in HRS revenue for the first quarter. 
Investments in income. Our goal is to predict principal and optimize liquidity. As you all know, on the short-term side, primary short-term investment vehicles are bank demand, deposit accounts and variable-rate demand notes in our longer-term portfolio. We invest primarily in high credit quality municipal bonds, corporate bonds and U.S. government securities. 
Our long-term portfolio has an average yield of 1.7% and an average duration of 3.3 [ph] years. Combined portfolios [indiscernible] had an average of 1.2% for the first quarter, which is up from 1% last year. I'd just say one note on that. The Fed, it's very difficult to figure out what exactly is going on. Our guidance at this point does not include or anticipate any increases in the interest rate. As I look at consensus model, looked like some of you are modeling an increase in there. At this point, it's not in our guidance. 
Average balances for interest on funds held for clients decreased by approximately 1% during the first quarter, primarily as a result of lower state unemployment rates, partially offset by growth in client base. 
I'll now walk you to the highlights of our financial position. It remained strong with cash and total corporate investments of $944 million as of the end of the quarter. Funds held for clients as of August 31, were $3.4 billion compared to $4 billion as of May 2016. But as you know, funds held for clients vary widely on a day-to-day basis and they average $3.8 billion for the quarter. 
Our total available for sale investments, including corporate investments and funds held for clients, reflected net unrealized gains of $63 million as of the end of the quarter, and this compares with the net unrealized gains of $48 million as of the end of May 31. 
Total stockholder's equity was $2 billion as of August 31, 2016, reflecting $166 million in dividends paid during the first quarter, our return on equity for the past 12 months with a sterling 39%. Our cash flows from operations were $295 million for first quarter, an increase of 6% over the prior year period. This change was primarily a result of higher net income, a slight increase in net Cash adjustment and situations in working capital. 
Now guidance for the remainder of the year. So with the close of the first quarter, we're going to take the opportunity to fine-tune the guidance we've provided last quarter. We remind you that our outlook is based on our current view of economic and interest rate conditions continuing with no significant changes [indiscernible] for the full year of fiscal 2017 is as follows: Payroll service revenue growth is anticipated to be in the range of 3% to 4%. And if you recall, this is a change we had said 4%. And from our perspective, it's fine tuning. Let me give you some detail on the quarter so you know how we expect to get to that. 
On a quarterly basis, if you look at the second and the fourth quarters, second and fourth quarters, we expect it to be in this strange. In the third quarter, which is where we lose 1 day this year, we expect to be between 2% and 3%. So let me just reiterate that. Second and fourth quarters, comparable on a day basis to last year, we expect to be in that range of 3% to 4%. In the third quarter, we expect to be between 2% and 3%. We have 1 less day in the third quarter. HRS revenue growth is anticipated to remain the same, which is 12% to 14%. 
Total service revenue continues to be in the range of 7% to 8% also. Consistent with prior guidance, income, excluding float as a percentage of total service revenue, is expected to be approximately 38%. As you know, first quarter has typically had a higher margin. And we expect that operating income, excluding float in that second quarter, won't be as high. We expect it to be between 38% and 39%. Now as reported net income growth is anticipated to be approximately 7%. Some people took that and assumed it was a change in guidance. It's simply reflecting the fact that we now have discrete items in first quarter and discrete items in the prior year first quarter. We wanted to give you a number that you can anchor your model on to understand what it looks like before you subtract them. So as reported, I repeat that again, net income growth is anticipated to be approximately 7%. This reflects the impact of the discrete tax items I just mentioned, which were recognized in both this quarter and the prior year first quarter. And it should be obvious that our previous guidance with adjusted for the discrete item in the first quarter of fiscal year 2016. Obviously, we did not know at the time we're going to record a discrete item in the first quarter where we would have told you. 
When you make the adjustments, and we exclude non-recruiting items, net income will be the same as our prior guidance. So there's no change to the guidance. It simply gives you another data point on which to anchor the model. 
Our effective tax rate for the year is expected to be approximately 35%, which also reflects the impact of the discrete tax items. So you can see our tax rate in the first quarter was lower. Subsequent quarters will be higher to get us to approximately 35% for the year. Other aspects of our guidance have remained unchanged from what we previously provided. So I hope that clarifies the guidance, and I will turn it now back to Marty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rayna on for the David Togut. Thanks for the clarification on the net income guidance. That was very helpful. Just one more on the guidance. I know you typically fine tuned your payroll service revenue from 4% growth to now 3% to 4%. I guess, what
componenttext: This is Rayna on for the David Togut. Thanks for the clarification on the net income guidance. That was very helpful. Just one more on the guidance. I know you typically fine tuned your payroll service revenue from 4% growth to now 3% to 4%. I guess, what are you seeing that may be different in the market that made you bring that guidance a notch down?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we said the guidance was approximately 4% when we released in -- or when we discussed it in fourth quarter. And it just simply reflects fine tuning as we look through the remainder of the quarters and the year. So we don't think it represents a sign
componenttext: Well, we said the guidance was approximately 4% when we released in -- or when we discussed it in fourth quarter. And it just simply reflects fine tuning as we look through the remainder of the quarters and the year. So we don't think it represents a significant change from where we were. And it's -- puts us pretty comfortable to the growth rate we had last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So your largest competitor have seen some client losses in the mid-market. Are you -- is Paychex benefiting from this?
componenttext: Got it. So your largest competitor have seen some client losses in the mid-market. Are you -- is Paychex benefiting from this?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- this is Marty. I think to some degree, yes. I mean, I don't think we've felt like the competitive environment has changed all that much. I do think that we're very proud of the product that we have now very full suite of HCM total solution, inc
componenttext: I think -- this is Marty. I think to some degree, yes. I mean, I don't think we've felt like the competitive environment has changed all that much. I do think that we're very proud of the product that we have now very full suite of HCM total solution, including the latest time and attendance additions. And so I think were competing very well with them. I think -- I don't think it's changed. We haven't seen a change dramatically, but we certainly continue to feel very positive about where we are.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And lastly, could you just quantify on that price increases you have seen in both payroll and HR Services?
componenttext: That's very helpful. And lastly, could you just quantify on that price increases you have seen in both payroll and HR Services?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So payroll is different from HR Services, but both are in the same range, in the range of 2% to 4%. On HRS, we don't uniformly apply price increases across all products. We really do that based on where we see the market, so -- but our price increases are
componenttext: So payroll is different from HR Services, but both are in the same range, in the range of 2% to 4%. On HRS, we don't uniformly apply price increases across all products. We really do that based on where we see the market, so -- but our price increases are in the 2% to 4% range.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg from Jefferies.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a follow up on the core payroll outlook, and I understand that in terms of order of magnitude, it is fine-tuning from about 4% to 3% to 4%. But I think historically, it's somewhat unusual for Paychex to tweak its outlook really at all
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a follow up on the core payroll outlook, and I understand that in terms of order of magnitude, it is fine-tuning from about 4% to 3% to 4%. But I think historically, it's somewhat unusual for Paychex to tweak its outlook really at all so early in the fiscal year. So just curious what led to the decision to kind of formally make that change even though it's not a big one, given that you've got 8 months left in the fiscal year. Was there anything kind of company specific? Or I think you said you're not really assuming any changes in the macro backdrop. So just on the margin, was there a little bit of adjustment from your perspective?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, Jason, what -- the answer to that is this way. So when we look at the year, there are lots of things that can affect what we expect the growth rate to be not the least of which is what's the competition of the days and the year. And so where
componenttext: Yes, I guess, Jason, what -- the answer to that is this way. So when we look at the year, there are lots of things that can affect what we expect the growth rate to be not the least of which is what's the competition of the days and the year. And so where we began and where we end has an impact as we go through the year and we look at what the run rate is of a particular day. That's one thing that influences it. The second thing is what is the actual impact about 1 less day in a given quarter? So in the third quarter, we had 1 less day. We quantified the impact as we go through the year and understand what we think it will be. And that basically was what was impacting our decision to fine tune a bit.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, as you look beyond this year, I mean, is 3% to 4% kind of a new normal? I mean, you've got the U.S. economy that's basically running in the range of unemployment [ph]. You still got I think a little bit of help from Advance on a full year ba
componenttext: Okay. I mean, as you look beyond this year, I mean, is 3% to 4% kind of a new normal? I mean, you've got the U.S. economy that's basically running in the range of unemployment [ph]. You still got I think a little bit of help from Advance on a full year basis this year. So I just want to make sure our expectations are properly calibrated. I mean, eventually, unemployment will probably tick up. So I mean, is 3% to 4% a decent range? Or do you think you can really be mid-single digits in core payroll kind of over the medium to longer term?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so 2 things I'd say, Jason. One is it's early. I think we need to go through the year and see. I would say this that we do not get the contribution from checks per payroll that we were getting 2 or 3 years ago and don't expect that, that will recur.
componenttext: Yes, so 2 things I'd say, Jason. One is it's early. I think we need to go through the year and see. I would say this that we do not get the contribution from checks per payroll that we were getting 2 or 3 years ago and don't expect that, that will recur. So you got to work a little bit harder. And then the third thing I'd say is that I want to be careful to say that the payroll service revenue is core payroll. It is not. Payroll service revenue is core payroll plus the portions of the HCM bundle that are payroll. That number can vary, and it will depend on what -- how much of those packages somewhat in the mid-market been price in them payroll you have to look at both components of revenue in order to understand what the trends are. So subject to all of that, we'll update as we go through -- we'll update when we get to the end of the year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one more for me. I think you haven't bought back any shares in I think 3 of the past 4 quarters [ph] [indiscernible] but you did the new authorization over the summer. So is the lack of buybacks just because the current price is not viewed as a
componenttext: Okay. Just one more for me. I think you haven't bought back any shares in I think 3 of the past 4 quarters [ph] [indiscernible] but you did the new authorization over the summer. So is the lack of buybacks just because the current price is not viewed as attractive enough? Or is the M&A pipeline becoming more robust? Or any other factors that you might highlight?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, appreciate it. I think it has something to do with the timing of the authorization and the other factors you mentioned, excluding the price of the shares that's really not part of what goes into our thinking.
componenttext: Yes, appreciate it. I think it has something to do with the timing of the authorization and the other factors you mentioned, excluding the price of the shares that's really not part of what goes into our thinking.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Danyal Hussain from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Danyal Hussain from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about the relative performance of payroll versus HRS. And I know note, Efrain, there's one thing you've called out before and there's this revenue allocation process that maybe you can talk a little bit more about it. And specifically
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the relative performance of payroll versus HRS. And I know note, Efrain, there's one thing you've called out before and there's this revenue allocation process that maybe you can talk a little bit more about it. And specifically, you said that clients are being given an explicitly higher discount on payroll upfront in exchange for adding more modules? Or do they only see a single bundle price? Just a little more color there would be helpful.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Daniel, to your point, there's no general answer I can give on that. But certainly, depending on the deal, you discount at what you think makes sense and is logical. So it could very well be that a bundle that has more modules in it is disc
componenttext: Well, I think, Daniel, to your point, there's no general answer I can give on that. But certainly, depending on the deal, you discount at what you think makes sense and is logical. So it could very well be that a bundle that has more modules in it is discounted more than a bundle that has fewer modules in it. So that's part of the equation. And -- but there's other elements of that which is what the composition and the size of the clients you're selling any given quarter. So that can be variable. So as we go through the year, we'll see where we end up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the focus more and more, they do see a bundled price. So I think more and more, we tend to look at this total service revenue. There's the allocations between them. Because we're selling more and more bundles and the bundles are getting larger and
componenttext: I think the focus more and more, they do see a bundled price. So I think more and more, we tend to look at this total service revenue. There's the allocations between them. Because we're selling more and more bundles and the bundles are getting larger and more complex, I think we tend to more and more look at the total service revenue growth and where that growth is and how we targeted that. So it gets a little bit harder here. As Efrain said, they keep kind of splitting this up and allocating it out and getting really fine-tuned on everything.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a question on the upcoming December 1 deadline. Can you just remind us what the current penetration is of the time and attendance product? And then you mentioned some of these newer, I guess, versions of it. Is there any revenue upli
componenttext: Got it. And then just a question on the upcoming December 1 deadline. Can you just remind us what the current penetration is of the time and attendance product? And then you mentioned some of these newer, I guess, versions of it. Is there any revenue uplift associated with those?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly expect it to be. What we're doing is he fine-tune the full product, the flextime with more -- with better more -- I guess, I'd say more advanced scheduling modules. So there's lot more flexibility to scheduling and how you do it. We've added
componenttext: We certainly expect it to be. What we're doing is he fine-tune the full product, the flextime with more -- with better more -- I guess, I'd say more advanced scheduling modules. So there's lot more flexibility to scheduling and how you do it. We've added a clock on the low end that gives you -- it's a wireless cock and [indiscernible] the shift time and makes it easier to have a clock and maybe some difficult locations. And it has a couple of other features with it as well. And the essentials is probably the biggest thing we've introduced. It's basically a scaled-down version of our web-based flextime Paychex Flex Time offering so to make it easier for clients to get started and to have a product that doesn't have quite as many bells and whistles on it, but that they need it. So we do think there's going to be some uplift. We've seen high -- double-digit increases in the sales. I'd say the penetration still pretty low, so it's definitely -- I would say where we are now, 10% or somewhere in there, a little bit more. But with a lot of room to grow. And our biggest opportunity I think right now is we still see 50%, slightly over 50% of our clients based on our surveys are in businesses in general, small businesses that are impacted who are not even aware of the overtime regulation. So we think there's going to be some good sales, not only this quarter, next quarter, but I think it's going to continue as the compliance requirements and may be some pushback on enforcement makes businesses realize that they really got to get involved and make sure that they are recording and scheduling time appropriately.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim Schneider from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Schneider from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe comment one last time on kind of the pricing environment. And I think, Marty, you referenced the fact that the mid-market you're seeing a little bit more mid-market pricing pressure. Can you maybe say whether that is at
componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe comment one last time on kind of the pricing environment. And I think, Marty, you referenced the fact that the mid-market you're seeing a little bit more mid-market pricing pressure. Can you maybe say whether that is at all a contributor to the downtick in the core payroll guidance? Or whether it's just an artifact of the bundled pricing that you referenced earlier?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't -- on the mid-market, if I did, I'd be -- it might be a misread. I didn't really feel -- I don't see too much different pricing pressure there. I feel the competitive environment is pretty much the same as it has been, same number of competit
componenttext: Yes, I don't -- on the mid-market, if I did, I'd be -- it might be a misread. I didn't really feel -- I don't see too much different pricing pressure there. I feel the competitive environment is pretty much the same as it has been, same number of competitors. I think, if anything, we're feeling stronger about where we are from a mid-market product then we certainly did a year or 2 years ago with the complete bundled product that we offer and the additions that we're constantly making almost quarterly to the HCM bundle we have for Flex. So we're feeling good about it. The pricing is, as Efrain said, still in that 2% to 4% kind of increase range. I think we're holding price pretty well, practically in that mid-market. And we're gaining more revenue per client based on the bundles. So we feel pretty good about it right now. I think the only thing that can -- that we see impacting that would be more of the economy in general. And we don't really see any major changes there other than that businesses are getting closer to full employment, and we're seeing that checks per client slow. But we expected that, frankly, for the last couple of years as people came back from the recession. So we feel pretty good about the mid-market, and we're fully staffed. In fact, we increased more reps there than any other division in the mid-market because of the product investments we've made and the opportunity we have between service and products. So feel pretty good about the mid-market right now and the opportunity, a decree for selling season.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understand. And then maybe can you maybe comment on the bookings environment you've seen over the past few months. Separately, on the HRS versus the PEO side? And whether those have been running kind of ahead of plan given the fact that you've been puttin
componenttext: Understand. And then maybe can you maybe comment on the bookings environment you've seen over the past few months. Separately, on the HRS versus the PEO side? And whether those have been running kind of ahead of plan given the fact that you've been putting up a little bit stronger HRS revenue growth in the current quarter than you guided to?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the human resource outsourcing in total, we're reaching nearly 1 million client employees now and between our product sets. And I think that need continues to grow. So we're feeling good about overall HR outsourcing solutions that we're providing.
componenttext: I think the human resource outsourcing in total, we're reaching nearly 1 million client employees now and between our product sets. And I think that need continues to grow. So we're feeling good about overall HR outsourcing solutions that we're providing. And so I think that's going to continue. Is the need -- as these rules keep getting more complex, whether it's time and attendance or minimum wage or ACA, even for this year for many clients now starting to even pay attention that didn't last year, as the rules and deadlines are really sticking this year as opposed to being delayed last year, I think that needs going to continue to increase and we'll do well on that in that category.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.

componenttext: The first one is just a quick follow-up on the question related to the time and attendance products. Can you just confirm that, that's an HRS piece of the -- how you reported? So if there's an update, it would be an HRS?

componenttext: Yes, I'd confirm 2 things. One is yes, it is. And second, we did see an uptick.

componenttextpreview: Specifically from the time and attendance?
componenttext: Specifically from the time and attendance?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did.
componenttext: Yes, we did.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then the next question's just more of a sort of a philosophical one about service versus technology. With you guys having built out your technology platform and to have the full functionality here and you're turning up the dial on some service inves
componenttext: Okay. Then the next question's just more of a sort of a philosophical one about service versus technology. With you guys having built out your technology platform and to have the full functionality here and you're turning up the dial on some service investments, maybe if you could just talk a little bit about how you view service relative to technology and the competitive differentiation there? I know in the past, you've talked about how you think your service is a big strong differentiator. So just what -- how do you view that now? And what do you think the investments you're making are going to continue to deepen that?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've always been very much known as a service company, and our technology was really more internal than external for the client base. And beginning about 6 years ago, we really ramped up the investment in technology. And I think the technolo
componenttext: Yes, I think we've always been very much known as a service company, and our technology was really more internal than external for the client base. And beginning about 6 years ago, we really ramped up the investment in technology. And I think the technology becomes part of the service story. Clients want to do more themselves. They want to do it online, mobile. They want to do with how they wanted what, when and where they want. Anything the investments have been very balanced in both technology and service. From a service perspective, the big investments, particularly the last a few years, have been driving now multiproduct centers. So pooling our folks together to service multiple products in those bundles together, driving a little bit more self-service so clients can do more things and their employees can on the web or on mobile apps. I think it's always going to be about service. It's how you define service, and the service definition has become a lot more about technology and how easy it is for clients to use it if they want to use it and when and how they want to use it. So we feel very good about the balance of investments that we've made in technology and service and continue to make.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta from Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta from Northcoast Research.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marty, I wanted to ask you about -- you talked about ACA and that being a benefit. I'm wondering, as you look at the HRS business, how much of a benefit do you think that is? And can it continue into next year? Or does it -- do you start comping against t
componenttext: Marty, I wanted to ask you about -- you talked about ACA and that being a benefit. I'm wondering, as you look at the HRS business, how much of a benefit do you think that is? And can it continue into next year? Or does it -- do you start comping against that next year?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you do to some degree. Obviously, even last year, the big sales opportunity was that initial push for the majority of our existing clients to say, "Hey, you need this." And we sell it to them. We've done well there with the retention and the
componenttext: Well, I think you do to some degree. Obviously, even last year, the big sales opportunity was that initial push for the majority of our existing clients to say, "Hey, you need this." And we sell it to them. We've done well there with the retention and the sales last year. Now you're selling more to those clients that in our client base either weren't -- were not aware of it, it didn't apply to them or they just didn't bother to buy it and try to get through it on their own. And then new clients coming out, of course, that now needed more changing. So I think you'll see that has some impact this year because there's not as obviously as much opportunity as doing it last year. But what then -- on the hand, we see time and attendance in the overtime regulations as the new opportunity. Not quite as big as the ACA opportunity, but I think yes, the [indiscernible] get tough run at only -- but more to last year because you had that initial that can sell a lot of clients that my existing client base that doesn't have.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Efrain, I know I apologize. I know I'm parsing words here but I just want to make sure you talked about checks per client not helping. Was it a detractor? Or was it just neutral?
componenttext: And Efrain, I know I apologize. I know I'm parsing words here but I just want to make sure you talked about checks per client not helping. Was it a detractor? Or was it just neutral?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It actually had a slight negative effect largely due to mix. But we've been -- that's been part of the equation over the last 3 or 4 quarters. Certainly, the last 3 quarters.
componenttext: It actually had a slight negative effect largely due to mix. But we've been -- that's been part of the equation over the last 3 or 4 quarters. Certainly, the last 3 quarters.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one last question, Marty. Advance partners, seems like that acquisition is going well. I just wanted to get your thoughts on your ability to maybe consolidate that industry more and make it a bigger part of Paychex. Is that a possibility now
componenttext: And then just one last question, Marty. Advance partners, seems like that acquisition is going well. I just wanted to get your thoughts on your ability to maybe consolidate that industry more and make it a bigger part of Paychex. Is that a possibility now that you've owned it? And just your perspective on the industry and Paychex's ability to grow in that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kartik, I think it is. I think there's an opportunity there that we've seen the leadership team there and their results have been very positive and better than we expected. And as we've gotten to know that industry a little bit more from the leadersh
componenttext: Yes, Kartik, I think it is. I think there's an opportunity there that we've seen the leadership team there and their results have been very positive and better than we expected. And as we've gotten to know that industry a little bit more from the leadership team there and now getting to know the business even better, we do think there's an opportunity for more roll up there with various smaller firms. There's a tremendous amount of companies that do this on a small basis and our niche kind of oriented, and I that think really benefits from consolidation strategy there. So we're certainly looking at that in trying to be very opportunistic and see if the valuations are correct. And I do think we have the capacity to do that and the leadership team there has the capacity to do that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have a question from Tim McHugh from William Blair.
componenttext: Have a question from Tim McHugh from William Blair.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Stephen Sheldon in for Tim. First, now that Paychex flexes out in the market and most products are on the platform, I guess, where are you guiding kind of incremental investments spending at this point?
componenttext: It's Stephen Sheldon in for Tim. First, now that Paychex flexes out in the market and most products are on the platform, I guess, where are you guiding kind of incremental investments spending at this point?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's been -- continues to be in to that product leg. When you think about -- I think now we're getting more probably fine tuning. When you think about time and attendance, for example, we saw that the existing module is very good for mid-market and
componenttext: Well, it's been -- continues to be in to that product leg. When you think about -- I think now we're getting more probably fine tuning. When you think about time and attendance, for example, we saw that the existing module is very good for mid-market and more complex clients, but that we had a real opportunity. One of the difficulties with time and attendance is it's somewhat complex to get started and that turns clients off sometimes. And so we scaled down and rolled out the flextime essentials now just this quarter. And so I think you'll see continued investments like that. The other thing is analytics. We're getting more into data analytics and using our reporting packages to guide to make them more flexible and easier to gain data out of the reporting packages to offer data analytics to our clients frankly of all sizes. And you'll see continued investment in analytics and reporting. And I would say as well, continued kind of adding more kind of bells and whistles. At the same time, we're building out a simpler interface to HTML5 for all of our products and mobile first design. So everything is being designed now mobile first so that it can be used very effectively on a mobile app as well as it expand to whatever device you're using. So more product kind of finding niches where the products like Flex Time Essentials can be used and the design itself making it easier to use.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then I think just a little bit before but just wanted to ask about uses of cash from this point and maybe an update on the M&A environment and the pipeline you're seeing?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then I think just a little bit before but just wanted to ask about uses of cash from this point and maybe an update on the M&A environment and the pipeline you're seeing?

componenttext: Yes, so I think earlier, I answered the question on Jason might have asked about share repurchase. So we'll do share repurchases to combat some dilution that we're seeing, so that will be part of it this year. And then the M&A pipeline is pretty robust. So there are a number of opportunities that we see could use a part of that cash or all of it. So we are -- we continue to evaluate those, frequent to get far down the road and then for whatever reason, doesn't -- it doesn't work Out. We're pretty choosy, but we think there's opportunities out there and that's why in part, that cash is there.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the questions. I think Marty, you had mentioned in response to Affordable Care Act that you thought you were pretty much comping against that strength already this year. I just want to make sure that I heard that right.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- well, what we're having against is, yes, that big first burst last year that we had been able to sell a lot to the existing client base that didn't have it basically went from no one having it to a large number of our clients having it. Now you
componenttext: I think -- well, what we're having against is, yes, that big first burst last year that we had been able to sell a lot to the existing client base that didn't have it basically went from no one having it to a large number of our clients having it. Now you're selling to those clients that now need it because their situation changed, they are new clients or they just didn't bother with it last year because they thought it didn't apply to them. So it does put a little bit of a push on us that we've got to sell pass the initial growth rate last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

componenttext: No, [indiscernible] in '18. Actually more the pressures this year because we're selling -- yes, yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then the second question I had, this week, one of the ERP vendors mentioned that they were moving down market. And I think the way they characterize that was about 250 employees. And i know that's probably above your sweet spot, but I'm just cu
componenttext: Right. And then the second question I had, this week, one of the ERP vendors mentioned that they were moving down market. And I think the way they characterize that was about 250 employees. And i know that's probably above your sweet spot, but I'm just curious what your views are on that segment given that it seems to be getting increasingly crowded. And then if you could tie that into your comment about the use of -- the increasing focus on technology and more interaction, if you will, with the end user?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I heard -- we've -- I'm not sure exactly who that because I haven't seen that. But there's a number of over the years, you know that there's been a large number of large players who have said, hey, I'm going to come down into that below 500 market an
componenttext: Yes, I heard -- we've -- I'm not sure exactly who that because I haven't seen that. But there's a number of over the years, you know that there's been a large number of large players who have said, hey, I'm going to come down into that below 500 market and capture that. And the issue is usually, they're very heavy in technology and complicated technology and have a hard time bringing it down to a business that has an HR department of 1 to 5 to 10 people and making it simple for them to use, affordable for them to use and then being able to service them and keep the margins that they're used. But they also tend to be much higher in software development typically and technology only than knowing how to service those kind of clients. I think we've add obviously a track record of moving up. And we do feel like in the mid-market, our sweet spot is certainly anywhere from 20 to 500 in that mid-market space. We used to think it was 50 plus, but it really has come down some with the needs of the business. So it doesn't -- we haven't seen much change in the competitive environment, and while I'm always concerned about changing competition, we don't see anybody right now new that's coming down that necessarily could be that successful. But hey, that's what we've got to keep our product and service great so that we can certainly compete with anybody.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So [indiscernible] just kind of how important the technology is versus a service as you migrate between these different breakpoints in terms of employee?
componenttext: Right. So [indiscernible] just kind of how important the technology is versus a service as you migrate between these different breakpoints in terms of employee?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you -- I think the technology gets more important as a component of service when you get 100 plus, 200 plus because there also we're seeing clients move more toward pushing employees to be more self-service. But that's exactly where a number of
componenttext: Yes, when you -- I think the technology gets more important as a component of service when you get 100 plus, 200 plus because there also we're seeing clients move more toward pushing employees to be more self-service. But that's exactly where a number of our investments have been going as being sure that whether on it's a mobile app for the employee of the client or for the client itself, that they can do things, they can make changes. they can view -- so they're taking heat off of the HR departments of these companies. And I think -- so when you get 100 plus, 200 plus, the technology is important, but you better have the service to back it up because while it sounds great, when those employees go to do something self-service, you want to have some place for them to fall back on the call. And that's where I think we're very good at balancing both the technology investment and our service, particularly now when we've added web chat, 7-by-24 service, multiproduct centers, all those are appealing to that group that's looking for technology, but wants a fall back to personalized committed service.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. You know what, David, yes, so I would expect that. And then every year, we go through another round of seeing what's happening with employment rates so we could have some variability.

So we're fully staffed and ready to handle it.

componenttext: I've been asked that a couple of times, so same-day ACH, if it reached widespread adoption, could impact short-term cash balances, probably not long term. It also has a benefit in that. You may be able to get it additional fees for running very late payroll. So it's too early to tell. I would say it's a very modest negative, but that would depend on it being adopted in a widespread way.

componenttext: Yes, we really see it, it's a benefit to our clients that have a last-minute change or something. As Efrain said, there might be some revenue opportunity there. It's more an additional service really that we can provide.

componenttext: And was there sort of a catch-up impact? Or was this just that there was, for some reason, a bigger tax benefit than normal from option this quarter and now that flows through the P&L versus historically it didn't?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, there wasn't a catch-up. It -- we're not getting into the leads on the mechanics of the computation, which are complex. Suffice it to say that the combination of an increase in share price, coupled with an increase in share exercises, ended up creating a situation where we had more benefit in the quarter. And it -- this will happen periodically throughout in the future, and we'll just call it out when it happened. It will -- we don't anticipate that it will be as sharp as it was this quarter.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then there's always a lot of questions about the payroll growth versus HR. And I guess, it seems to me that you've alluded to a couple of times and may be distinction isn't as strong as it was in the past. But from that perspective, can y
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then there's always a lot of questions about the payroll growth versus HR. And I guess, it seems to me that you've alluded to a couple of times and may be distinction isn't as strong as it was in the past. But from that perspective, can you just help us understand, how much of your selling efforts headcount, time in the field, however, you want to talk about it, is focused on up selling more components to broader product fit into a pretty sticky and large base versus people who are out there prospecting for new payroll customers? Has that changed? Is more of the focus telling more stuff into the base today than it was in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's changed. Well, obviously, there's a lot more opportunity, but I would say if you took -- probably if you thought about core payroll and that sales team and then the way MMS -- the mid-market team goes after it, probably, 40%, 50% is sti
componenttext: I don't think it's changed. Well, obviously, there's a lot more opportunity, but I would say if you took -- probably if you thought about core payroll and that sales team and then the way MMS -- the mid-market team goes after it, probably, 40%, 50% is still on acquiring new clients and going after them and getting them on board and the other 50% is really there -- because when you think about all of HRS really, they're selling into the base for the most part. And then a number of the core and MMS payroll teams are back selling more client, more products, but I'd say it's probably around 50-50. And I don't know if it's changed all that much. I think their focus though on selling the full package upfront is different. So while it's a little bit different than the way I would probably you're thinking about it, we sell a lot more full package right upfront. Our old style would be sell you payroll. You get used to us. You get happy with us. 6 months later, I come back and see if a 401(k) is a value to our workers' compre health insurance. Now what we're finding is clients want the full value upfront. They want -- they have a full need in mind and it's not just, yes, I want payroll for now and then I'll come talk to me. So we're selling more what we call integrated sales approach where multiple teams will go and see a brand-new client and sell them could be everything, including HR outsourcing because that's what they really were looking for and payroll was just coming along with it. So -- but I think if you say 50-50 roughly, that would be fine. It's just the focus is very different now for the sales teams, every from core right through.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you just give us an update on penetration of some of the key categories? And what's the gating factor to further penetrating, whether it's 401(k) or the outsourced and some of the other major product categories? Is it price? Is it you getting
componenttext: And then can you just give us an update on penetration of some of the key categories? And what's the gating factor to further penetrating, whether it's 401(k) or the outsourced and some of the other major product categories? Is it price? Is it you getting out and telling the story? What can you do to drive that penetration higher?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a something obviously we're looking at. I think the penetration rates are still pretty low, so lots of opportunity there for us. I think it's a combination of all of those. It's a combination of what is the client see the value in for like a
componenttext: Well, that's a something obviously we're looking at. I think the penetration rates are still pretty low, so lots of opportunity there for us. I think it's a combination of all of those. It's a combination of what is the client see the value in for like a 401(k) for example and -- or do they feel the pressure from their employee base? We're feeling more clients come to us for products like insurance and 401(k) because, hey, there's -- it's harder with full employment. They're moving towards full employment, it's harder for them to capture new employees unless they have the benefit packages that they might not have needed 2 years ago in order to compete for their employees. So it's the need in the market. It's the value to the client and it's execution. Obviously, we spent a tremendous amount of time training, making sure the products are available, making sure that we have the training and all the sales force tools. We've added a tremendous amount of tools to the sales force, data analytics, what clients we have that are most likely to buy a 401(k), most likely to buy insurance, sales force, all of the tools all help execution. So it's a number of things. I would say penetration rate still give us a tremendous amount of opportunity. We're moving them up, but there's still a lot of room to grow and I think we're putting everything in place to be successful about it.
