componenttext: I would say that's a long-term issue. And when I mentioned this, look at the technologies, right, and we think there's a strategic advantage in buying a company on, for example, SurePayroll, that was not accretive, we'll do it. So every deal is not going to be accretive right out of the gate. Some are. So we're pretty tough on the criteria of dilution in the first year. But if it makes sense, we'll look at it.

componenttext: Well, I think we actually had a pretty good uptick double-digit growth in this quarter. As we're getting closer to that December 1 time frame, this month, next couple of months should see probably the biggest benefit. But I think after that, I think clients are really just kind of making themselves aware. The other thing is there's a lot of discussion in the news about will it be overturned? Could be pushed back through some court proceeding? But we don't see that happening at this point but that could be making clients say, hey, I'm going to kind of wait and see how it happens. So it should be a good year overall certainly for time and attendance. But I think that this next quarter, this quarter and next quarter probably the best.

componenttext: We feel good about how we're positioned. We've got fully staffed from a sales rep standpoint. We grew pretty much all the divisions, but in particular, the payroll divisions. And so we feel that we're kind of on target for what we expected.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the HRS services, could you just talk about like what are the 2 most penetrated solutions that you're currently offering? And what sort of penetration rate that has in order to give a perspective in terms of the opportunity for further cost sales?
componenttext: Just on the HRS services, could you just talk about like what are the 2 most penetrated solutions that you're currently offering? And what sort of penetration rate that has in order to give a perspective in terms of the opportunity for further cost sales?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the 2 most penetrated were probably workers' comp and the insurance and the 401(k) and -- but the biggest opportunities are still 401(k) certainly. And I think we've talked about it. We've expanded the last -- roughly now 2 years into what we
componenttext: Yes, I think the 2 most penetrated were probably workers' comp and the insurance and the 401(k) and -- but the biggest opportunities are still 401(k) certainly. And I think we've talked about it. We've expanded the last -- roughly now 2 years into what we called large market 401(k). So where we focused a lot on new plans for the first almost 18 years of having the product. The last couple of years, we added a full team, which has expended on conversion plan. So larger asset plans. And that group has been doing very well, particularly in first quarter. We had some nice growth there. So were building relationships with brokers who refer us know. And as these rules get more complex for brokers, I think they're bringing our talented kind of tenured team on the large market into more deals. So that's very good. So lots of opportunity on 401(k) and a lot of opportunity in HR outsourcing would certainly be the next largest, meaning ACA -- I'm sorry, ASO, PEO and our HR essentials. So biggest opportunities because revenue basis and opportunities to grow our 401(k) and HR outsourcing by far.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

componenttext: And what's the penetration rate currently?

componenttext: On HR outsourcing? Less than 10%. componenttext: I would say it's hard to look at because the way we bundle it, we don't think of it quite as modules. I think if you're asking how many do we sell a larger bundle upfront, I'd say it's closer -- it's more in the 20% to 30% range that we're selling a bundle versus payroll only and it has at least 1 additional service or module with it. I mean, we've seen the revenue per client has been -- we've been successful at driving up that revenue per client year after year. So it's frankly the last couple of years. So I hope that helps.

componenttext: We sell small. I mean, we absolutely compete very well. It's an interesting point, Mark. And I think we've been doing very -- we've been very effective particularly in the fourth quarter last year, we had very good unit growth. So we continue to see unit growth. And there's a little bit of a trade-off between unit growth, the unit growth we've been seeing, which has been between 2% and 3% and size of client. So that impacts a little. It has a little bit of a drag on growth, in the short term not in the long term.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the comments related to the Accountable Care Act. Kind of now that you're into the first quarter, I know there's been a lot of debate about whether this year is going to kind of continue to be strong in Obamacare companies that
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the comments related to the Accountable Care Act. Kind of now that you're into the first quarter, I know there's been a lot of debate about whether this year is going to kind of continue to be strong in Obamacare companies that didn't choose to comply last year due this year versus whether they're sort of a hangover effect or not. So how are you feeling about that now that you're a few months in?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're -- I think the point was, Lisa, that just that last year, it was kind of that first chance to go after the entire client base, nobody basically have the product. There are a very few, and so we're able to sell a lot in the particularly in th
componenttext: Yes, so we're -- I think the point was, Lisa, that just that last year, it was kind of that first chance to go after the entire client base, nobody basically have the product. There are a very few, and so we're able to sell a lot in the particularly in the first few quarters of the year. And now when you anniversary that, we're still selling the product, but there's not as much opportunity there. So I think then the question was what does it apply for '18? '18 won't be much of an issue because I think we'll be very consistent with '17 to '18. But '16 to this year, '17, there is some impact that  we're selling as much. On the other hand, we're selling more of the time and attendance solutions, but their revenue is not quite as much the opportunity is not quite as much there. And it's not as probably as far-reaching or as demanding or as creating as much angst with clients as the Affordable Care Act was because of the penalty situation. Now the overtime stuff could start to pick up if enforcement picks up as well. But I think that's just going to take a little bit longer. So again, it's having some impact to versus last year, but it's not a huge thing but it's having some impact.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And are there other regulatory changes or rules on the horizon that you would call out like that you see sort of a study pipeline of these rules being considered either at the federal level or in some states that would kind of continue to drive the i
componenttext: Yes. And are there other regulatory changes or rules on the horizon that you would call out like that you see sort of a study pipeline of these rules being considered either at the federal level or in some states that would kind of continue to drive the incremental secular demand from the regulatory changes?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there hasn't been -- there's been a steady flow based in current administration and probably won't change much in the election, which could have some impact. But minimum wage, for example, right now, it's extremely confusing for our clients. Minimum-
componenttext: Yes, there hasn't been -- there's been a steady flow based in current administration and probably won't change much in the election, which could have some impact. But minimum wage, for example, right now, it's extremely confusing for our clients. Minimum-wage rules are different by state. The Fed's talk about changing minimum-wage they have for government, but in some of those that are tied into government. But states are different. Cities are different, and the really help a lot of our clients help -- we help them through our payroll service only or our HR outsourcing to stay up with minimum wage changes because not only are they -- they're not changing once. They're changing over a period of years, and you have to make sure that you stay current with those. And there's a lot of work on identifying like who's a -- the kind of immigration type thing. You got to know your customer. You got to know your employees. You got to make sure you got all of that well-documented. So the rules keep coming. I don't think that helps necessarily the business environment in general because of overregulation, but it certainly gives Paychex a lot of opportunities to go and talk to clients about their payroll need and their HR outsourcing need because small to midsized businesses just can't keep up with all of these changes. The other thing is that the enforcement and the penalties have increased as states and federal governments have looked for revenue sources. So not only is there an issue about whether you are a compliant, but if you're challenged on your compliance, we can provide a tremendous amount of help if you get a penalty in payroll, if you get a penalty for a time issue, a time and attendance issue, we're there to support you with expert documentation and background and relationships with federal state and local governments. And that's a big plus that we sell to clients that they don't realize sometimes until they're hit with an audit or enforcement penalty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one final follow-up. I think the last couple quarters, you've called out a dynamic in the client base that's been kind of interesting. I think overall, average employees for clients have been slightly trending down due to the strengt
componenttext: Got it. And then just one final follow-up. I think the last couple quarters, you've called out a dynamic in the client base that's been kind of interesting. I think overall, average employees for clients have been slightly trending down due to the strength in SurePayroll and just new business formation on the low end. But then at the same time, your mid-market offerings have been performing well. So almost like a barbell kind of effect. Are you continuing to see that sort of trend in the client base or anything else let like that you called out?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just provide a little more color on that. So if you look at average client size, it's down very, very slightly. That has an impact, but you're right. The difficulty is you can't see that completely in payroll. So if you look at our mid-market
componenttext: Yes, let me just provide a little more color on that. So if you look at average client size, it's down very, very slightly. That has an impact, but you're right. The difficulty is you can't see that completely in payroll. So if you look at our mid-market platform taken as a whole, including the modules that are typically sold with them, which are HR, online in time and attendance, you'd seem nice growth over the last 2 or 3 years. Payroll has done fine, too, but it has a little bit of that headwind because of slightly lower clients driven by some of the positive which is increasing client growth. So we've gone from growing the client base at 1% to growing between 2% and 3%. And hopefully, that continues to grow. The reason why we're not as concerned about that is that those clients eventually become larger and purchase more services. So we want to keep the final reasonably open at the top.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining us for our discussion of Paychex First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer.This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results fo
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining us for our discussion of Paychex First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me today is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer.
This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results for first quarter ended August 31, 2016. Our Form 10-Q will be filed with the SEC within the next few days, and you can access our earnings release and Form 10-Q on our Investor Relations web page as they become available. This teleconference is being broadcast over the Internet and will be archived and available on our website for approximately 1 month.
On today's call, I'll review highlights for the first quarter in relationship -- in relation to sales and ops and product management, development areas. Efrain will review first quarter financial results and discuss our full year guidance, and then we'll open it up your questions.
We are off to a solid start for Fiscal 2017 with positive results across all major product lines. The number of client worksite employees served by our human resource outsourcing services grew by double digits over -- on a year-over-year basis. Our cloud-based HCM services, including time and attendance and human resource management, continued to gain strong market acceptance in the quarter as well as last year.
Payroll service revenue grew 4% for the first quarter. HRS revenue increased 15% for the quarter, driven largely by growth in the client base across all major HCM categories. Total service revenue, up 9%. We acquired Advance Partners last December and are very pleased with their contribution to our results. Advance Partners contributed approximately 1.5% to the growth in the service revenue for the first quarter.
Client retention has remained strong, providing excellent customer service as our top priority. We've continued to invest in our operations and compliant services to support growth and ensure we maintain best-in-class client service.
One area of focus has been the expansion of our multiproduct service center, which primarily assists our mid-market clients who attach additional services with payroll. We have also invested in our insurance operations team to increase support for our Affordable Care Act service clients as we approach the 2016 calendar year filing. 
We usually announced the expansion of the AICPA Paychex partner program to include Human Resource Services in addition to payroll and retirement benefits. This program allows CPAs who refer to us to broaden their advisory role with clients by offering them a suite of best-in-class services and provides a strong referral channel for us. We are proud to be the preferred provider of payroll, retirement and now human resource outsourcing services for the AICPA, CPA.com and its CPA members.
The Department of Labor's final Overtime Rule has become effective -- will become effective December 1, which will expand over time for millions of workers. This new legislation makes accurate time and attendance tracking more important than ever, and we have found that many businesses remain unaware of the legislation and the impact on their business.
We recently announced enhancements to our time and attendance service portfolio with the addition of Paychex Flex Time Essentials, TrueShift time clock and an advanced scheduling feature within our Paychex Flex Time module. The investment in this technology demonstrates our continued commitment to providing industry-leading solutions that educate and assist our clients to comply with the new regulations and stay more connected to their employees and their businesses.
These new products enhance our commitment to supporting our clients through the entire employee journey, from the posting of a position, interviewing and job offer, onboarding the new employee and handling all the daily tasks and life events with a simple, integrated, SaaS software-as-a-solution platform combined with personalized and flexible service options. We're very proud of the support our employees provide small and midsized businesses with this broad and advanced product set in commitment to great service, particularly as we enter our 45th year in business.
Along with that, I'm very proud of some recent recognition our Paychex team has received. Our insurance agency ranked #23 on Business Insurance magazine's 2016 list of top 100 brokers of U.S. business. This is our sixth appearance on the list, and we once again ranked as one of the fastest-growing insurance agencies in the nation.
We've been named to Selling Power Magazine's 2016 list of 50 Best Companies to Sell For, landing at #7. This is the fourth consecutive year that Paychex has appeared in the list, moving up from the #9 spot last year. Very proud to be in the top 10 of best companies to sell for.
And Paychex was once again ranked as the largest 401(k) recordkeeper by total number of defined contribution plans according to the recent survey by PLANSPONSOR magazine, a national publication dedicated to the pension and retirement industry.
We also continue with our shareholder-friendly actions in the first quarter. In July, we increased our quarterly dividend by 10% or $0.04 per share to $0.46 per share. Our Board of Directors also approved an additional authorization to repurchase up to $350 million of our outstanding common stock, which expires now and [ph] May of 2019. We did not repurchase any shares in the first quarter but will continue to assess the opportunity to buy back shares during the year to offset dilution.
In summary, we are off to a great solid start. We're receiving very good recognition, and I'm very appreciative of the great work of our Paychex employee team, sales ops and all the support teams in the company.
I'll now turn the call over to Efrain Rivera, and Efrain will review our financial results in more detail. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call with certain forward-looking statements -- will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such involve some risks. Please refer to our ea
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call with certain forward-looking statements -- will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such involve some risks. Please refer to our earnings release that includes a discussion of forward-looking statements and related risk factors.
As discussed, first quarter financial results for fiscal 2017 represent a solid start to the year. Here are some of the key highlights for the quarter. I'll provide greater detail in certain areas and end with a review of our 2017 outlook.
Total service revenue grew 9% for the first quarter to $774 million. Interest on funds held for clients increased 11% for the first quarter to $12 million as a result of higher average interest rates earned. Expenses increased 8% for the first quarter, and Advance Partners contributed approximately 1% of this growth. Compensation-related expenses increased 6%, primarily due to higher wages resulting from growth in headcount in both operations and sales.
Our effective income tax rate was 33% for the first quarter compared to 29.7% to the prior year's first quarter. The effective income tax rates have been impacted by discrete tax items recognized in both of these periods, so last quarter -- last year's first quarter and this year's first quarter. In the first quarter of this fiscal year, we recorded a tax benefit resulting from the adoption of new accounting guidance, partially offset by the recognition of an additional provision related to a state tax matter.
These items increased diluted earnings per share by approximately $0.025 share to be precise. If you remember, last year in the first quarter, we recognized a net tax benefit on income from prior tax years related to customer-facing software we produced. This resulted in an increase in diluted earnings per share of approximately $0.06 per share for that period.
So now if I could just do an editorial. You'll see that when we talk about net income, we carefully say as reported net income. So we're going to give you guidance on as reported net income and net income excluding discrete items. The punchline to that is that there's been no change. We just need you to look at those 2 items down to discrete items, we'll talk about that in a second, and see that essentially, it doesn't change the guidance. I have seen some notes that seem to think it does. It doesn't. I'll come to that in a second.
I just mentioned adoption of new accounting guidance impacting the effective tax rate. We early adopted new accounting guidance related to employee share-based payment. As a result, we recognized a net tax benefit in the income statement. This was previously required to be recorded as additional paid in capital in equity.
On an as reported basis, net income increased 4% to $217 million, and diluted EPS increased 3% to $0.60 per share in the first quarter. Growth rates for net income and diluted earnings per share were impacted by approximately 5% and 6% as a result of the recognition of the discrete items in the respective periods. So I give you those numbers so you can reconcile back to what it would look like if you excluded those items.
Let's talk about payroll service revenue, increased 4% for the first quarter to $451 million. We benefited from increases in client base and revenue per check. Revenue per check grew as a result of price increases net of discounting. In addition, Advance Partners, which we acquired last year, contributed approximately 1% to the growth in payroll service revenue for the first quarter. Checks per payroll were not a contributing factor in the recorded payroll revenue growth, and we expect to continue to see that to be the case.
HRS revenue increased strongly to 15% in the first quarter, $323 million. The increase reflected strong growth in client base across all major HCM services, including our comprehensive outsourcing services, retirement services, time and attendance and HR administration. I take this point or pause to say that remember that part of what we report in HRS are the modules that we sell on the HCM system. So in order to understand clearly what we're doing, you need to look at both categories.
Within Paychex HR Services, we continue to see strong demand, which is reflected in the double-digit year-over-year growth in the number of client worksite employees served.
Insurance services benefited from continued growth in revenue from our full service Affordable Care Act product and growth in the number of health and benefit applicants. Our workers' comp insurance product benefited from higher average premiums and client base growth. Retirement services revenue benefited from the increase in asset fee revenue earned on the value of purchased [ph] funds as well as an increase in clients served. Last, Advance Partners contributed approximately 2% to the growth in HRS revenue for the first quarter.
Investments in income. Our goal is to predict principal and optimize liquidity. As you all know, on the short-term side, primary short-term investment vehicles are bank demand, deposit accounts and variable-rate demand notes in our longer-term portfolio. We invest primarily in high credit quality municipal bonds, corporate bonds and U.S. government securities.
Our long-term portfolio has an average yield of 1.7% and an average duration of 3.3 years. Combined portfolios are at an average of 1.2% for the first quarter, which is up from 1% last year. I'd just say one note on that. The Fed, it's very difficult to figure out what exactly is going on. Our guidance at this point does not include or anticipate any increases in the interest rate. As I look at consensus model, looked like some of you are modeling an increase in there. At this point, it's not in our guidance.
Average balances for interest on funds held for clients decreased by approximately 1% during the first quarter, primarily as a result of lower state unemployment rates, partially offset by growth in client base.
I'll now walk you through the highlights of our financial position. It remained strong with cash and total corporate investments of $944 million as of the end of the quarter. Funds held for clients as of August 31, were $3.4 billion compared to $4 billion as of May 2016. But as you know, funds held for clients vary widely on a day-to-day basis and they average $3.8 billion for the quarter.
Our total available-for-sale investments, including corporate investments and funds held for clients, reflected net unrealized gains of $63 million as of the end of the quarter, and this compares with net unrealized gains of $48 million as of the end of May 31.
Total stockholders' equity was $2 billion as of August 31, 2016, reflecting $166 million in dividends paid during the first quarter. Our return on equity for the past 12 months was a sterling 39%. Our cash flows from operations were $295 million for the first quarter, an increase of 6% over the prior year period. This change was primarily a result of higher net income, a slight increase in noncash adjustment and fluctuations in working capital.
Now guidance for the remainder of the year. So with the close of the first quarter, we're going to take the opportunity to fine-tune the guidance we've provided last quarter. We remind you that our outlook is based on our current view of economic and interest rate conditions continue with no significant changes.
Our guidance for the full year of fiscal 2017 is as follows: payroll service revenue growth is anticipated to be in the range of 3% to 4%. And if you recall, this is a change. We had said 4%. And from our perspective, it's fine-tuning. Let me give you some detail on the quarter so you know how we expect to get to that.
On a quarterly basis, if you look at the second and the fourth quarters -- second and fourth quarters, we expect it to be in this strange. In the third quarter, which is where we lose 1 day this year, we expect to be between 2% and 3%. So let me just reiterate that. Second and fourth quarters, comparable on a day basis to last year, we expect to be in that range of 3% to 4%. In the third quarter, we expect to be between 2% and 3%. We have 1 less day in the third quarter. HRS revenue growth is anticipated to remain the same, which is 12% to 14%.
Total service revenue continues to be in the range of 7% to 8% also. Consistent with prior guidance, income, excluding float as a percentage of total service revenue, is expected to be approximately 38%. As you know, first quarter has typically had a higher margin. And we expect that operating income, excluding float in the second quarter, won't be as high. We expect it to be between 38% and 39%.
Now as reported net income growth is anticipated to be approximately 7%. Some people took that and assumed it was a change in guidance. It's simply reflecting the fact that we now have discrete items in first quarter and discrete items in the prior year first quarter. We wanted to give you a number that you can anchor your model on to understand what it looks like before you subtract them.
So as reported, I repeat that again, net income growth is anticipated to be approximately 7%. This reflects the impact of the discrete tax items I just mentioned, which were recognized in both this quarter and the prior year first quarter. And it should be obvious that our previous guidance with -- adjusted for the discrete item in the first quarter of fiscal year 2016. Obviously, we did not know at the time we're going to record a discrete item in the first quarter, where we would have told you.
When you make the adjustments, and we exclude nonrecurring items, net income will be the same as our prior guidance. So there's no change to the guidance. It simply gives you another data point on which to anchor the model.
Our effective tax rate for the year is expected to be approximately 35%, which also reflects the impact of the discrete tax items. So you can see our tax rate in the first quarter was lower. Subsequent quarters will be higher to get us to approximately 35% for the year.
Other aspects of our guidance have remained unchanged from what we previously provided. So I hope that clarifies the guidance, and I will turn it now back to Marty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And operator, we'll now open up for any questions, please.
componenttext: Great. And operator, we'll now open up for any questions, please.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from David Togut from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from David Togut from Evercore ISI.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rayna Kumar for David Togut. Thanks for the clarification on the net income guidance. That was very helpful. Just one more on the guidance. I know you typically fine-tuned your payroll service revenue from 4% growth to now 3% to 4%. I guess, what
componenttext: This is Rayna Kumar for David Togut. Thanks for the clarification on the net income guidance. That was very helpful. Just one more on the guidance. I know you typically fine-tuned your payroll service revenue from 4% growth to now 3% to 4%. I guess, what are you seeing that, that may be different in the market that made you bring the guidance a notch down?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we said the guidance was approximately 4% when we released in -- or when we discussed it in fourth quarter. And it just simply reflects fine-tuning as we look through the remainder of the quarters and the year. So we don't think it represents a sign
componenttext: Well, we said the guidance was approximately 4% when we released in -- or when we discussed it in fourth quarter. And it just simply reflects fine-tuning as we look through the remainder of the quarters and the year. So we don't think it represents a significant change from where we were. And it's -- puts us pretty comparable to the growth rate we had last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So your largest competitor is seeing some client losses in the mid-market. Are you -- is Paychex benefiting from this?
componenttext: Got it. So your largest competitor is seeing some client losses in the mid-market. Are you -- is Paychex benefiting from this?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- this is Marty, yes. I think to some degree, yes, I mean, I don't think we've felt like the competitive environment has changed all that much. I do think that we're -- with our -- we're very proud of the product that we have now, very full suite
componenttext: I think -- this is Marty, yes. I think to some degree, yes, I mean, I don't think we've felt like the competitive environment has changed all that much. I do think that we're -- with our -- we're very proud of the product that we have now, very full suite of HCM total solution, including the latest time and attendance additions. And so I think we're competing very well with them. I think -- I don't think it's changed. We haven't seen a change dramatically, but we certainly continue to feel very positive about where we are.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And lastly, could you just quantify net price increases you've seen in both payroll and HR Services?
componenttext: That's very helpful. And lastly, could you just quantify net price increases you've seen in both payroll and HR Services?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So payroll is different from HR Services, but both are in the same range, in the range of 2% to 4%. On HRS, we don't uniformly apply price increases across all products. We really do that based on where we see the market, so -- but our price increases are
componenttext: So payroll is different from HR Services, but both are in the same range, in the range of 2% to 4%. On HRS, we don't uniformly apply price increases across all products. We really do that based on where we see the market, so -- but our price increases are in the 2% to 4% range.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg from Jefferies.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a follow-up on the core payroll outlook, and I understand that in terms of order of magnitude, it is fine-tuning from about 4% to 3% to 4%. But I think historically, it's somewhat unusual for Paychex to tweak its outlook really at all
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a follow-up on the core payroll outlook, and I understand that in terms of order of magnitude, it is fine-tuning from about 4% to 3% to 4%. But I think historically, it's somewhat unusual for Paychex to tweak its outlook really at all so early in the fiscal year. So just curious what led to the decision to kind of formally make that change even though it's not a big one, given that you've got 8 months left in the fiscal year. Was there anything kind of company specific? Or I think you said you're not really assuming any changes in the macro backdrop. So just on the margin, where -- was there a little bit of adjustment from your perspective?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, Jason, what -- I'd answer that this way. So when we look at the year, there are lots of things that can affect what we expect the growth rate to be, not the least of which is what's the composition of the days in a year. And so where we bega
componenttext: Yes. I guess, Jason, what -- I'd answer that this way. So when we look at the year, there are lots of things that can affect what we expect the growth rate to be, not the least of which is what's the composition of the days in a year. And so where we began and where we end has an impact as we go through the year and we look at what the run rate is on a particular day. That's one thing that influences it. The second thing is what is the actual impact about 1 less day in a given quarter? So in the third quarter, we have 1 less day. We quantified that impact as we go through the year and understand what we think it will be. And that basically was what was impacting our decision to fine-tune a bit.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, as you look beyond this year, I mean, is 3% to 4% kind of a new normal? I mean, you've got the U.S. economy that's basically running in the range of full employment. You still got, I think, a little bit of help from Advance on a full year ba
componenttext: Okay. I mean, as you look beyond this year, I mean, is 3% to 4% kind of a new normal? I mean, you've got the U.S. economy that's basically running in the range of full employment. You still got, I think, a little bit of help from Advance on a full year basis this year. So I just want to make sure our expectations are properly calibrated. I mean, eventually, unemployment will probably tick up. So I mean, is 3% to 4% a decent range? Or do you think you can really be mid-single digits in core payroll kind of over the medium to longer term?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 2 things I'd say, Jason. One is it's early. I think we need to go through the year and see. I would say this that we do not get the contribution from checks per payroll that we were getting 2 or 3 years ago and don't expect that, that will recur.
componenttext: Yes. So 2 things I'd say, Jason. One is it's early. I think we need to go through the year and see. I would say this that we do not get the contribution from checks per payroll that we were getting 2 or 3 years ago and don't expect that, that will recur. So you got to work a little bit harder. And then the third thing I'd say is that I want to be careful to say that payroll service revenue is core payroll. It is not. Payroll service revenue is core payroll plus the portions of the HCM bundle that are payroll. That number can vary, and it will depend on what -- how much of those packages somewhat in the mid-market been price in them payroll you have to look at both components of revenue in order to understand what the trends are. So subject to all of that, we'll update as we go through -- we'll update when we get to the end of the year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one more for me. I think you haven't bought back any shares in, I think, 3 of the past 4 quarters, but you did the new authorization over the summer. So is the lack of buybacks just because the current price is not viewed as attractive enough?
componenttext: Okay. Just one more for me. I think you haven't bought back any shares in, I think, 3 of the past 4 quarters, but you did the new authorization over the summer. So is the lack of buybacks just because the current price is not viewed as attractive enough? Or is the M&A pipeline becoming more robust? Or any other factors that you might highlight?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, appreciate it. I think it has something to do with the timing of the authorization and the other factors you mentioned, excluding the price of the shares that's really not part of what goes into our thinking.
componenttext: Yes, appreciate it. I think it has something to do with the timing of the authorization and the other factors you mentioned, excluding the price of the shares that's really not part of what goes into our thinking.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Danyal Hussain from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Danyal Hussain from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about the relative performance of payroll versus HRS. And I know, Efrain, there's one thing you've called out before and it's this revenue allocation process that maybe you can talk a little bit more about it. And specifically, you sa
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the relative performance of payroll versus HRS. And I know, Efrain, there's one thing you've called out before and it's this revenue allocation process that maybe you can talk a little bit more about it. And specifically, you said that clients are being given an explicitly higher discount on payroll upfront in exchange for adding more modules? Or do they only see a single bundled price? So just a little more color there would be helpful.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Danyal, to your point, there's no general answer I can give on that. But certainly, depending on the deal, you discount at what you think makes sense and is logical. So it could very well be that a bundle that has more modules in it is disc
componenttext: Well, I think, Danyal, to your point, there's no general answer I can give on that. But certainly, depending on the deal, you discount at what you think makes sense and is logical. So it could very well be that a bundle that has more modules in it is discounting more than a bundle that has fewer modules in it. So that's part of the equation. And -- but there's other elements to that, which is what's the composition and the size of the clients you're selling in a given quarter. So that can be variable. So as we go through the year, we'll see where we end up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the focus -- more and more, they do see a bundled price. So I think more and more, we tend to look at the total service revenue. There's the allocations between them. Because we're selling more and more bundles and the bundles are getting larg
componenttext: And I think the focus -- more and more, they do see a bundled price. So I think more and more, we tend to look at the total service revenue. There's the allocations between them. Because we're selling more and more bundles and the bundles are getting larger and more complex, I think we tend to more and more look at the total service revenue growth and where that growth is and how we target that. So yes, it gets a little bit harder here. As Efrain said, they keep kind of splitting this up and allocating it out and getting really fine-tuned on everything.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a question on the upcoming December 1 deadline. Could you just remind us what the current penetration is of the time and attendance product? And then you mentioned some of these newer, I guess, versions of it. Is there any revenue up
componenttext: Got it. And then just a question on the upcoming December 1 deadline. Could you just remind us what the current penetration is of the time and attendance product? And then you mentioned some of these newer, I guess, versions of it. Is there any revenue uplift associated with those?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly expect it to be. What we're doing is we fine-tune the full product, the Flex Time with more -- with better -- more -- I guess, I'd say more advanced scheduling modules. So there's a lot more flexibility to scheduling and how you do it. We've
componenttext: We certainly expect it to be. What we're doing is we fine-tune the full product, the Flex Time with more -- with better -- more -- I guess, I'd say more advanced scheduling modules. So there's a lot more flexibility to scheduling and how you do it. We've added a clock on the low end that gives you -- it's a wireless clock and that's the shift time and it makes it easier to have a clock in maybe some difficult locations. And it has a couple of other features with it as well. And then the Essentials is probably the biggest thing we've introduced. It's basically a scaled-down version of our web-based Flex Time, Paychex Flex Time offering, sort of make it easier for clients to get started and to have a product that doesn't have quite as many bells and whistles on it, but that they need it. So we do think there's going to be some uplift. We've seen high -- double-digit increases in the sales. I'd say the penetration is still pretty low. So it's definitely -- I would say where we are now, 10% or somewhere in there, a little bit more. But it will -- a lot of room to grow. And our biggest opportunity, I think, right now is we still see 50%, slightly over 50% of our clients, based on our surveys, are in businesses in general, small businesses that are impacted who are not even aware of the overtime regulation. So we think there's going to be some good sales, not only this quarter, next quarter, but I think it's going to continue as the compliance requirements and may be some pushback on enforcement makes businesses realize that they really got to get involved and make sure that they are recording and scheduling time appropriately.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim Schneider from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Schneider from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe comment one last time on kind of the pricing environment. And I think, Marty, you referenced the fact that at mid-market, you're seeing a little bit more mid-market pricing pressure. Can you maybe say whether that is at
componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe comment one last time on kind of the pricing environment. And I think, Marty, you referenced the fact that at mid-market, you're seeing a little bit more mid-market pricing pressure. Can you maybe say whether that is at all a contributor to the downtick in the core payroll guidance or whether it's just an artifact of the bundled pricing that you referenced earlier?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't -- on the mid-market, if I did, it might be misread. I didn't really feel -- I don't see too much different pricing pressure there. I feel the competitive environment is pretty much the same as it has been, same number of competitors. I think
componenttext: Yes, I don't -- on the mid-market, if I did, it might be misread. I didn't really feel -- I don't see too much different pricing pressure there. I feel the competitive environment is pretty much the same as it has been, same number of competitors. I think, if anything, we're feeling stronger about where we are from a mid-market product than we certainly did a year or 2 years ago with the complete bundled product that we offer and the additions that we're constantly making almost quarterly to the HCM bundle we have for Flex. So we're feeling good about it. The pricing is, as Efrain said, still in that 2% to 4% kind of increase range. I think we're holding price pretty well, particularly in that mid-market, and we're gaining more revenue per client based on the bundles. So we feel pretty good about it right now. I think the only thing that could -- that we see, I think, impacting that would be more of the economy in general. And we don't really see any major changes there, other than that businesses are getting closer to full employment and we're seeing the checks per client slow. But we expected that, frankly, for the last couple of years as people came back from the recession. So we feel pretty good about the mid-market, and we're fully staffed. In fact, we increased more reps there than any other division in the mid-market because of the product investments we've made and the opportunity we have between service and products. So feel pretty good about the mid-market right now and the opportunity, particularly for selling season.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand. And then maybe -- can you maybe comment on the bookings environment you've seen over the past few months, separately, on the HRS versus the PEO side and whether those have been running kind of ahead of plan given the fact that you've been pu
componenttext: I understand. And then maybe -- can you maybe comment on the bookings environment you've seen over the past few months, separately, on the HRS versus the PEO side and whether those have been running kind of ahead of plan given the fact that you've been putting up a little bit stronger HRS revenue growth in the current quarter than you guided to?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the human resource outsourcing in total, we're reaching nearly 1 million client employees now and -- between our product sets. And I think that need continues to grow. So we're feeling good about overall HR outsourcing solutions that we're providi
componenttext: I think the human resource outsourcing in total, we're reaching nearly 1 million client employees now and -- between our product sets. And I think that need continues to grow. So we're feeling good about overall HR outsourcing solutions that we're providing, and so I think that's going to continue. As the need -- as these rules keep getting more complex, whether it's time and attendance or minimum wage or ACA, even for this year, for many clients now starting to even pay attention that didn't last year, as the rules and deadlines are really sticking this year as opposed to being delayed last year, I think that need's going to continue to increase and we'll do well on that in that category.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one is just a quick follow-up on the question related to the time and attendance products. Can you just confirm that, that's an HRS piece of the -- how you reported, so if there's an update, it would be an HRS?
componenttext: The first one is just a quick follow-up on the question related to the time and attendance products. Can you just confirm that, that's an HRS piece of the -- how you reported, so if there's an update, it would be an HRS?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd confirm 2 things. One is yes, it is. And second, we did see an uptick.
componenttext: Yes, I'd confirm 2 things. One is yes, it is. And second, we did see an uptick.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Specifically from the time and attendance?
componenttext: Specifically from the time and attendance?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did.
componenttext: Yes, we did.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then the next question is just more of a sort of a philosophical one about service versus technology. With you guys having built out your technology platform and it's got the full functionality here and you're turning up the dial on some service inv
componenttext: Okay. Then the next question is just more of a sort of a philosophical one about service versus technology. With you guys having built out your technology platform and it's got the full functionality here and you're turning up the dial on some service investments, maybe if you could just talk a little bit about how you view service relative to technology and the competitive differentiation there? I know in the past, you've talked about how you think your service is a big strong differentiator. So just what -- how do you view that now? And what do you think the investments you're making are going to do to continue to deepen that?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've always been very much known as a service company, and our technology was really more internal than external for the client base. And beginning about 6 years ago, we really ramped up the investment in technology. And I think the technolo
componenttext: Yes. I think we've always been very much known as a service company, and our technology was really more internal than external for the client base. And beginning about 6 years ago, we really ramped up the investment in technology. And I think the technology becomes part of the service story. The clients want to do more themselves. They want to do it online, mobile. They want to do it how they want to do it, when and where they want. And I think that the investments have been very balanced in both technology and service. From a service perspective, the big investments, particularly the last few years, have been driving now multiproduct centers. So pulling our folks together to service multiple products in those bundles together, driving a little bit more self-service so clients can do more things and their employees can on the web or on mobile apps. I think it's always going to be about service. It's how you define service, and the service definition has become a lot more about technology and how easy it is for clients to use it if they want to use it and when and how they want to use it. So we feel very good about the balance of investments that we've made in technology and service and continue to make.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta from Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta from Northcoast Research.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marty, I wanted to ask you about -- you talked about ACA and that being a benefit. I'm wondering, as you look at the HRS business, how much of a benefit do you think that is? And can it continue into next year? Or does it -- do you start comping against t
componenttext: Marty, I wanted to ask you about -- you talked about ACA and that being a benefit. I'm wondering, as you look at the HRS business, how much of a benefit do you think that is? And can it continue into next year? Or does it -- do you start comping against that next year?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you do to some degree. Obviously, even last year, the big sales opportunity was that initial push for the majority of our existing clients to say, "Hey, you need this," and we sell it to them. We've done well there with the retention and the
componenttext: Well, I think you do to some degree. Obviously, even last year, the big sales opportunity was that initial push for the majority of our existing clients to say, "Hey, you need this," and we sell it to them. We've done well there with the retention and the sales last year. Now you're selling more to those clients that -- in our client base that either were not aware of it, it didn't apply to them or they just didn't bother to buy it and tried to get through it on their own and then new clients coming out, of course, that now needed more changing. So I think you'll see that has some impact this year because there's not as -- obviously as much opportunity as last year. But what then -- on the hand, we see time and attendance and the overtime regulations as the new opportunity. Not quite as big as the ACA opportunity, but I think yes, the comps will get tougher on that only -- but more to last year because you had that initial, "Hey, I can sell a lot of clients that my existing client base, that doesn't have it."

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Efrain, I know -- I apologize. I know I'm parsing words here. But I just want to make sure you talked about checks per client not helping. Was it a detractor or was it just neutral?
componenttext: And Efrain, I know -- I apologize. I know I'm parsing words here. But I just want to make sure you talked about checks per client not helping. Was it a detractor or was it just neutral?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It actually had a slight negative effect largely due to mix. But we've been -- that's been part of the equation over the last 3 or 4 quarters, certainly, the last 3 quarters.
componenttext: It actually had a slight negative effect largely due to mix. But we've been -- that's been part of the equation over the last 3 or 4 quarters, certainly, the last 3 quarters.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one last question, Marty. Advance Partners, it seems like that acquisition is going well. I just wanted to get your thoughts on your ability to maybe consolidate that industry more and make it a bigger part of Paychex. Is that a possibility
componenttext: And then just one last question, Marty. Advance Partners, it seems like that acquisition is going well. I just wanted to get your thoughts on your ability to maybe consolidate that industry more and make it a bigger part of Paychex. Is that a possibility now that you've owned it? And just your perspective on the industry and Paychex' ability to grow in that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kartik, I think it is. I think there's an opportunity there that -- we've seen the leadership team there and their results have been very positive and better than we expected. And as we've gotten to know that industry a little bit more from the leade
componenttext: Yes, Kartik, I think it is. I think there's an opportunity there that -- we've seen the leadership team there and their results have been very positive and better than we expected. And as we've gotten to know that industry a little bit more from the leadership team there and now getting to know the business even better, we do think there's an opportunity for more roll-up there with various smaller firms. There's a tremendous amount of companies that do this on a small basis. And our niche is kind of oriented, and I that think really benefits from a consolidation strategy there. So we're certainly looking at that and trying to be very opportunistic and see if the valuations are correct. And I do think we have the capacity to do that and the leadership team there has the capacity to do that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have a question from Tim McHugh from William Blair.
componenttext: Have a question from Tim McHugh from William Blair.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Stephen Sheldon in for Tim. First, now that Paychex flexes out in the market and most products are on the platform, I guess, where are you guiding kind of incremental investment spending at this point?
componenttext: It's Stephen Sheldon in for Tim. First, now that Paychex flexes out in the market and most products are on the platform, I guess, where are you guiding kind of incremental investment spending at this point?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's been -- continues to be into that product leg. When you think about -- I think now we're getting more probably fine-tuning. When you think about time and attendance, for example, we saw that the existing module was very good for mid-market and
componenttext: Well, it's been -- continues to be into that product leg. When you think about -- I think now we're getting more probably fine-tuning. When you think about time and attendance, for example, we saw that the existing module was very good for mid-market and more complex clients, but that we had a real opportunity. One of the difficulties with time and attendance is it's somewhat complex to get started and that kind of turns clients off sometimes. And so we scaled down and rolled out the flextime essentials now just this quarter. And so I think you'll see continued investments like that. The other thing is analytics. We're getting more into data analytics and using our reporting packages to guide to make them more flexible and easier to gain data out of the reporting packages to offer data analytics to our clients, frankly, of all sizes. And you'll see continued investment in analytics and reporting. And I would say as well, continued -- kind of adding more kind of bells and whistles. At the same time, we're building out a simpler interface through HTML5 for all of our products and mobile-first design. So everything is being designed now mobile first and -- so that it can be used very effectively on a mobile app as well as then expand to whatever device you're using. So more product kind of finding niches where the products like Flex Time Essentials can be used and the design itself making it easier to use.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then I think you touched on this a little bit before but just wanted to ask about uses of cash from this point and maybe an update on the M&A environment and the pipeline you're seeing?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then I think you touched on this a little bit before but just wanted to ask about uses of cash from this point and maybe an update on the M&A environment and the pipeline you're seeing?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think earlier I answered the question on -- Jason might have asked about share repurchase. So we'll do share repurchases to combat some dilution that we're seeing, so that will be part of it this year. And then the M&A pipeline is pretty robust.
componenttext: Yes, so I think earlier I answered the question on -- Jason might have asked about share repurchase. So we'll do share repurchases to combat some dilution that we're seeing, so that will be part of it this year. And then the M&A pipeline is pretty robust. So there are a number of opportunities that we see could use a part of that cash or all of it. So we are -- we continue to evaluate those, frequently get far down the road and then -- for whatever reason, doesn't -- it doesn't work out, because we're pretty choosy. But we think there's opportunities out there. And that's why, in part, that cash is there.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Grossman of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Grossman of Stifel.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up to one of the questions. I think Marty, you had mentioned in response to the Affordable Care Act that you thought you were pretty much comping against that strength already this year. I just want to make sure that I heard that, that
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up to one of the questions. I think Marty, you had mentioned in response to the Affordable Care Act that you thought you were pretty much comping against that strength already this year. I just want to make sure that I heard that, that right.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- well, what we're having against is, yes, that big first burst last year that we had been able to sell a lot to the existing client base that didn't have it. Basically, it went from no one having it to a large number of our clients having it. No
componenttext: I think -- well, what we're having against is, yes, that big first burst last year that we had been able to sell a lot to the existing client base that didn't have it. Basically, it went from no one having it to a large number of our clients having it. Now you're selling to those clients that now need it because their situation changed, there are new clients or they just didn't bother with it last year because they thought it didn't apply to them. So it does put a little bit of a push on us that we've got to sell pass the initial growth rate last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So stated differently, I think, clearly the other question was that going into fiscal '18, you wouldn't really expect much of a headwind from whatever thrust you got or incremental sales you got from the Affordable Care Act last year?
componenttext: All right. So stated differently, I think, clearly the other question was that going into fiscal '18, you wouldn't really expect much of a headwind from whatever thrust you got or incremental sales you got from the Affordable Care Act last year?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not in '18. Actually more of the pressure is this year because we're selling -- yes, yes.
componenttext: No, not in '18. Actually more of the pressure is this year because we're selling -- yes, yes.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. And then the second question I had is, this week, one of the ERP vendors mentioned that they were moving down market. And I think the way they characterized that was about 250 employees. And I know that's probably above your sweet spot. But I
componenttext: Right. Okay. And then the second question I had is, this week, one of the ERP vendors mentioned that they were moving down market. And I think the way they characterized that was about 250 employees. And I know that's probably above your sweet spot. But I'm just curious what your views are on that segment, given that it seems to be getting increasingly crowded? And then if you could tie that into your comment about the use of -- the increasing focus on technology and more interaction, if you will, with the end user?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I've heard -- we've -- I'm not sure exactly who's that because I haven't seen that. But there's a number of -- over the years, you know that there's been a number of large players who have said, "Hey, I'm going to come down into that below 500 market
componenttext: Yes, I've heard -- we've -- I'm not sure exactly who's that because I haven't seen that. But there's a number of -- over the years, you know that there's been a number of large players who have said, "Hey, I'm going to come down into that below 500 market and capture that." And the issue is, usually, they're very heavy in technology and complicated technology and have a hard time bringing it down to a business that has an HR department of 1 to 5 to 10 people and making it simple for them to use, affordable for them to use and then being able to service them and keep the margins that they're used to. They also tend to be much higher in software development typically and technology only than knowing how to service those kind of clients. I think we've had obviously a track record of moving up. And we do feel like in the mid-market, our sweet spot is certainly anywhere from 20 to 500 in that mid-market space. We used to think it was 50 plus, but it really has come down some with the need to the business. So it doesn't -- I don't -- we haven't seen much change in the competitive environment, and while I'm always concerned about changing competition, we don't see anybody right now new that's coming down that necessarily could be that successful. But hey, that's why we've got to keep our products and service great, so that we can certainly compete with anybody.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So can you give us a sense for just kind of how important the technology is versus a service as you migrate between these different breakpoints in terms of employee?
componenttext: Right. So can you give us a sense for just kind of how important the technology is versus a service as you migrate between these different breakpoints in terms of employee?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you -- I think the technology gets more important as a component of service when you get 100 plus, 200 plus, because we're also seeing clients move more toward pushing employees to be more self-service. But that's exactly where a number of our i
componenttext: Yes, when you -- I think the technology gets more important as a component of service when you get 100 plus, 200 plus, because we're also seeing clients move more toward pushing employees to be more self-service. But that's exactly where a number of our investments have been going, as being sure that whether it's on a mobile app for the employee of the client or for the client itself that they can do things, they can make changes, they can view. So they're taking heat off of the HR departments of these companies. And I think -- so when you get 100 plus, 200 plus, the technology is important, but you better have the service to back it up, because while it sounds great, when those employees go to do something self-service, you want to have some place for them to fall back on the call. And that's where I think we're very good at balancing both the technology investment and our service, particularly now when we've added web chat, 7-by-24 service, multiproduct centers, all those are appealing to that group that's looking for technology, but wants a fallback to personalized committed service.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Got it. That's actually very helpful. And just one last question, Efrain, for the silly headwind, when do we actually anniversary that on the balances?
componenttext: All right. Got it. That's actually very helpful. And just one last question, Efrain, for the silly headwind, when do we actually anniversary that on the balances?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I think we're going to battle it most throughout the year. I think probably, somewhere in third or fourth quarter. My guess is probably more fourth quarter.
componenttext: That's a good question. I think we're going to battle it most throughout the year. I think probably, somewhere in third or fourth quarter. My guess is probably more fourth quarter.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then it does not -- then it flattens out for fiscal '18?
componenttext: All right. And then it does not -- then it flattens out for fiscal '18?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You know what, David, yes, so I would expect that. And then every year, we go through another round of seeing what's happening with unemployment rates. So we could have some variability.
componenttext: Yes. You know what, David, yes, so I would expect that. And then every year, we go through another round of seeing what's happening with unemployment rates. So we could have some variability.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Ridley-Lane [indiscernible] in for Sara Gubins from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Ridley-Lane [indiscernible] in for Sara Gubins from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about the taste of service headcount additions to support the mid-market and the Affordable Care Act offerings. Are you currently at the planned staffing levels? Are you planning to continue to increase through the year?
componenttext: Wanted to ask about the taste of service headcount additions to support the mid-market and the Affordable Care Act offerings. Are you currently at the planned staffing levels? Are you planning to continue to increase through the year?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, at this point, we're at the planned levels. We're staffed up in all areas. And we've got full complement of what we need -- we feel, unless the sales tick up more than we thought, but we feel very good about where we are. We've also made some
componenttext: Yes, David, at this point, we're at the planned levels. We're staffed up in all areas. And we've got full complement of what we need -- we feel, unless the sales tick up more than we thought, but we feel very good about where we are. We've also made some technology changes to make it easier for clients to give us the information for us to file, because there won't be -- we don't expect any delay in the filing requirements this year. So we're fully staffed and ready to handle it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on the adoption of same-day ACH payments, would that have a potential negative impact on your client flow [ph] balances over time?
componenttext: Got it. And then on the adoption of same-day ACH payments, would that have a potential negative impact on your client flow [ph] balances over time?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've been asked that a couple of times, so same-day ACH, if it reached widespread adoption could impact short-term cash balances, probably not long term. It also has a benefit in that. You may be able to get additional fees for running very late payroll.
componenttext: I've been asked that a couple of times, so same-day ACH, if it reached widespread adoption could impact short-term cash balances, probably not long term. It also has a benefit in that. You may be able to get additional fees for running very late payroll. So it's too early to tell. I would say it's a very modest negative, but that would depend on it being adopted in a widespread way.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we really see it as it's a benefit to our clients that have a last-minute change or something. As Efrain said, there might be some revenue opportunity there. There's also a great service opportunity where someone -- a client makes an error, needs a l
componenttext: Yes, we really see it as it's a benefit to our clients that have a last-minute change or something. As Efrain said, there might be some revenue opportunity there. There's also a great service opportunity where someone -- a client makes an error, needs a last-minute change, we are now able to work that through the banking system with the ACH, and -- so we're not expecting it to be kind of like a basic payroll where that's the norm. It's more an additional service really that we can provide.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a quick number's question. Does the new $350 million buyback replace the old authorization?
componenttext: Got it. And then just a quick number's question. Does the new $350 million buyback replace the old authorization?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So basically, we canceled that out and start with $350 million.
componenttext: Yes, yes. So basically, we canceled that out and start with $350 million.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, does the new share-based payment accounting treatment, should we really think of that as a discrete impact on the quarter? Or is there going to be an ongoing impact of putting this? And if so, do you have a sense what you're expecting in t
componenttext: First question, does the new share-based payment accounting treatment, should we really think of that as a discrete impact on the quarter? Or is there going to be an ongoing impact of putting this? And if so, do you have a sense what you're expecting in the remainder of the fiscal year and moving forward?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so good question. So it is discrete, and it will remain discrete when we record it in a given quarter. It could have modest impacts in subsequent quarters. We'll call it out. We don't expect that it'll have the level of impact that it had this quarte
componenttext: Yes, so good question. So it is discrete, and it will remain discrete when we record it in a given quarter. It could have modest impacts in subsequent quarters. We'll call it out. We don't expect that it'll have the level of impact that it had this quarter. So I'll just leave it at that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And was there sort of a catch-up impact? Or was this just -- that there was, for some reason, a bigger tax benefit than normal from option this quarter and now that flows through the P&L versus historically it didn't?
componenttext: And was there sort of a catch-up impact? Or was this just -- that there was, for some reason, a bigger tax benefit than normal from option this quarter and now that flows through the P&L versus historically it didn't?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there wasn't a catch-up. It -- without getting into the leads on the mechanics of the computation, which are complex. Suffice it to say that the combination of an increase in share price, coupled with an increase in share exercises ended up creating
componenttext: Yes, there wasn't a catch-up. It -- without getting into the leads on the mechanics of the computation, which are complex. Suffice it to say that the combination of an increase in share price, coupled with an increase in share exercises ended up creating a situation where we had more benefit in the quarter. And it -- this will happen periodically throughout in the future, and we'll just call it out when it happened. It will -- you don't anticipate that it will be as sharp as it was this quarter.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then there's always a lot of questions about the payroll growth versus HR. And I guess, it seems to me that you've alluded a couple of times and maybe the distinction isn't as strong as it was in the past. But from that perspective, can y
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then there's always a lot of questions about the payroll growth versus HR. And I guess, it seems to me that you've alluded a couple of times and maybe the distinction isn't as strong as it was in the past. But from that perspective, can you just help us understand, how much of your selling efforts headcount, time in the field, however, you want to talk about it, is focused on up-selling more components to broader product set into a pretty sticky and large base versus people who are out there prospecting for new payroll customers? Has that changed? Is more of the focus selling more stuff into the base today than it was in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's changed. Well, obviously, there's a lot more opportunity, but I would say, if you took -- probably, if you thought about core payroll and that sales team and then the way MMS -- the mid-market team goes after it, probably, 40%, 50% is s
componenttext: I don't think it's changed. Well, obviously, there's a lot more opportunity, but I would say, if you took -- probably, if you thought about core payroll and that sales team and then the way MMS -- the mid-market team goes after it, probably, 40%, 50% is still on acquiring new clients and going after them and getting them on board and the other 50% is really -- because when you think about all of HRS really, they're selling into the base for the most part.
