And then a number of the core and MMS payroll teams are back selling more client, more products, but I'd say it's probably around 50:50, and I don't know if it's changed all that much. I think their focus though on selling the full package upfront is different. So while -- so it's a little bit different than the way I would probably you're thinking about it. We sell a lot more full package right upfront. Our old style would be, "Hey, I sell you payroll, you get used to us, you get happy with us." Six months later, I come back and see if a 401(k) is a value to you or workers' comp or health insurance. Now what we're finding is clients want the full value upfront. They want -- they have a full need in mind, and it's not just, "Yes, I want payroll for now, and then I'll [ph] come talk to me." So we're selling more what we call integrated sales approach where multiple teams will go and see a brand-new client and sell them -- it could be everything, including HR outsourcing because that's what they really were looking for and payroll was just coming along with it. So -- but I think if you say 50:50 roughly, that would be fine. It's just the focus is very different now for the sales teams, every from core right through.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you just give us an update on penetration of some of the key categories? And what's the gating factor to further penetrating, whether it's 401(k) or the fully outsourced and some of the other major product categories? Is it price? Is it just
componenttext: And then can you just give us an update on penetration of some of the key categories? And what's the gating factor to further penetrating, whether it's 401(k) or the fully outsourced and some of the other major product categories? Is it price? Is it just you getting out and telling the story? What can you do to drive that penetration higher?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's something, obviously, we're always looking at. I think the penetration rates are still pretty low, so lots of opportunity there for us. I think it's a combination of all of those. It's a combination of what is the client see the value in, lik
componenttext: Well, that's something, obviously, we're always looking at. I think the penetration rates are still pretty low, so lots of opportunity there for us. I think it's a combination of all of those. It's a combination of what is the client see the value in, like a 401(k), for example, and -- or do they feel the pressure from their employee base? We're feeling more clients come to us for products like insurance and 401(k) because, "Hey, there's -- it's harder with full employment." They're moving towards full employment, it's harder for them to capture new employees unless they have the benefit packages that they might not have needed 2 years ago in order to compete for their employees. So it's the need in the market, it's the value to the client and it's execution. Obviously, we spent a tremendous amount of time training, making sure the products are available, making sure that we have the training and all the sales force tools. We've added a tremendous amount of tools to the sales force, data analytics, what clients we have that are most likely to buy a 401(k), most likely to buy insurance, sales force, all of the tools, all help execution. So it's a number of things. I would say penetration rate still give us a tremendous amount of opportunity. We're moving them up, but there's still a lot of room to grow, and I think we're putting everything in place to be successful about it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The slides, just looking at the slides, it looks like on the cash with the long-term capital strategy page, you're talking about strategic accretive acquisitions. I'm curious, accretive, is that sort of 1-year sort of ambition? Or is it -- are you telling
componenttext: The slides, just looking at the slides, it looks like on the cash with the long-term capital strategy page, you're talking about strategic accretive acquisitions. I'm curious, accretive, is that sort of 1-year sort of ambition? Or is it -- are you telling us we shouldn't expect any dilutive deals from Paychex?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that's a long-term issue. And when I mentioned this, look at the technologies, right? And we think there's a strategic advantage in buying a company, for example, SurePayroll, that was not accretive, we'll do it. So every deal is not going to
componenttext: I would say that's a long-term issue. And when I mentioned this, look at the technologies, right? And we think there's a strategic advantage in buying a company, for example, SurePayroll, that was not accretive, we'll do it. So every deal is not going to be accretive right out of the gate. Some are. So we're pretty tough on the criteria of dilution in the first year, but if it makes sense, we'll look at it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. It's good to know. And then just on the overtime legislation. You said there was a little bit of uptick this quarter, but is there a time frame with which we might expect a more significant uptick [indiscernible] rates on time and attendance?
componenttext: Understood. It's good to know. And then just on the overtime legislation. You said there was a little bit of uptick this quarter, but is there a time frame with which we might expect a more significant uptick [indiscernible] rates on time and attendance?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we actually had a pretty good uptick, double-digit growth in this quarter. And I think it will -- by my expectation would be -- it will be in to the next couple of quarters that will continue to see sales do very well with time and attendanc
componenttext: Well, I think we actually had a pretty good uptick, double-digit growth in this quarter. And I think it will -- by my expectation would be -- it will be in to the next couple of quarters that will continue to see sales do very well with time and attendance. As we're getting closer to that December 1 time frame, this month, next couple of months should see probably the biggest benefit. But I think after that, I think clients are really just kind of making themselves aware of it. The other thing is there's a lot of discussion in the news about, will it be overturned, could it be pushed back through some court proceeding and -- but we don't see that happening at this point. But that could be making clients say, "Hey, I'm going to kind of wait and see how it happens." So it should be a good year overall certainly for time and attendance. But I think that this next quarter, this quarter and next quarter probably would be the best.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So going into and coming out of it, we could feel a little bit of a lift. That's good to know. And then just lastly, just there was a lot of questions around payroll and HRS, but just broadly speaking for the quarter, how did each of those lines c
componenttext: Got it. So going into and coming out of it, we could feel a little bit of a lift. That's good to know. And then just lastly, just there was a lot of questions around payroll and HRS, but just broadly speaking for the quarter, how did each of those lines come in versus your internal plan?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: They were within the range of expectation. So look, I think that's part of what we look at every quarter, try to understand what we think trends are and adjust based on what we're seeing. You can see, we didn't change our guidance on income, fine-tuned re
componenttext: They were within the range of expectation. So look, I think that's part of what we look at every quarter, try to understand what we think trends are and adjust based on what we're seeing. You can see, we didn't change our guidance on income, fine-tuned revenue, actually HR Services had a strong quarter. We'll see where we end up here, but overall, we think we're in the range of what we expected.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we feel good about how we're positioned. We've got fully staffed from a sales rep standpoint. We grew pretty much all the divisions, but in particular, the payroll divisions. And it's getting kind of these new reps, the newer reps to take it up to pro
componenttext: And we feel good about how we're positioned. We've got fully staffed from a sales rep standpoint. We grew pretty much all the divisions, but in particular, the payroll divisions. And it's getting kind of these new reps, the newer reps to take it up to production that we'd like to see -- and but we're fully staffed in that group, we're fully staffed in the service teams to handle ACA, which was a struggle last year just because there was just so much change going on there. And so we feel good that we're kind of on target for what we expected.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Marcon from R.W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Marcon from R.W. Baird.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the HRS services, could you just talk about like what are the 2 most penetrated solutions that you're currently offering? And what sort of penetration rate that has in order to give a perspective in terms of the opportunity for further cross-sales
componenttext: Just on the HRS services, could you just talk about like what are the 2 most penetrated solutions that you're currently offering? And what sort of penetration rate that has in order to give a perspective in terms of the opportunity for further cross-sales?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the 2 most penetrated were probably workers' comp and insurance and 401(k) and -- but the biggest opportunities are still 401(k) certainly. And I think we've talked about it. We've expanded the last -- roughly now 2 years into what we called
componenttext: Yes, I think the 2 most penetrated were probably workers' comp and insurance and 401(k) and -- but the biggest opportunities are still 401(k) certainly. And I think we've talked about it. We've expanded the last -- roughly now 2 years into what we called large market 401(k). So where we focused a lot on new plans for the first almost 18 years of having the product. The last couple of years, we added a full team, which has expended on conversion plan, so larger asset plans. And that group has been doing very well, particularly in first quarter, we had some nice growth there. So we're building relationships with brokers who refer us now. And as these rules get more complex for brokers, I think they're bringing our talented kind of tenured team on the large market into more deals, so that's very good. So lots of opportunity on 401(k) and a lot of opportunity in HR outsourcing would certainly be the next largest, meaning ACA -- I'm sorry, ASO, PEO and our HR essentials. So biggest opportunities because revenue basis and opportunities that grow I think are 401(k) and HR outsourcing by far.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what's the penetration rate currently?
componenttext: And what's the penetration rate currently?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On HR outsourcing, less than 10%. And if you look at client employees, I did say that we're approaching 1 million worksite employees, and we put out [indiscernible] 11 million, 12 million W2s. So we are a little less than 10% on the employees that we're s
componenttext: On HR outsourcing, less than 10%. And if you look at client employees, I did say that we're approaching 1 million worksite employees, and we put out [indiscernible] 11 million, 12 million W2s. So we are a little less than 10% on the employees that we're servicing. And not all of them will need it based on their size, but we think that, that penetration rate is less than 10% and can certainly have a lot of upside.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great color. And then with regards to -- there's clearly a greater emphasis with regards to selling more modules upfront when you first sign a client. Can you give us a little bit of a perspective in terms of over the last couple of years, how that
componenttext: That's great color. And then with regards to -- there's clearly a greater emphasis with regards to selling more modules upfront when you first sign a client. Can you give us a little bit of a perspective in terms of over the last couple of years, how that's changed in terms of like -- typically we used to sell maybe 3 modules with a brand-new client, and now we're up to 5, 6, et cetera. Like, what's -- what are you seeing on average with new clients above the smallest clients that might just be signing up for this payroll?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it's hard to look at it, because the way we bundle it, we don't think of it quite as modules. But I would say that, probably 25% of the clients to 30% of the clients are taking something -- maybe 20% to 30% are taking something more right now.
componenttext: I would say it's hard to look at it, because the way we bundle it, we don't think of it quite as modules. But I would say that, probably 25% of the clients to 30% of the clients are taking something -- maybe 20% to 30% are taking something more right now. This is relatively new approach to the way we're selling, because we've had so many years of selling payroll then coming back. I think if you are asking how many do we sell a larger bundle upfront, I'd say, it's closer -- it's more in the 20% to 30% range that we're selling a bundle versus payroll-only, and it has at least one additional service or module with it. I mean, we've seen the revenue per client has been -- we've been successful at driving up that revenue per client year after year, so -- frankly, in the last couple of years. So I hope that helps.

componenttext: We sell small. I mean, we absolutely compete very well. It's an interesting point, Mark. Particularly in the fourth quarter of last year, we had very good unit growth. So we continue to see unit growth. And there's a little bit of a trade-off between unit growth we've been seeing, which has been between 2% and 3% and size of client. So that impacts a little bit. It has a little bit of a drag on growth in the short term not in the long term.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the comments related to the Accountable Care Act. Kind of now that you're into the first quarter, I know there's been a lot of debate about whether this year is going to kind of continue to be strong in Obamacare as companies t
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the comments related to the Accountable Care Act. Kind of now that you're into the first quarter, I know there's been a lot of debate about whether this year is going to kind of continue to be strong in Obamacare as companies that didn't choose to comply last year due this year versus whether they're sort of a hangover effect or not. So how are you feeling about that now that you're a few months in?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're -- I think the point was, Lisa, that just that last year, it was kind of that first chance to go after the entire client base. Nobody basically have the product. There are a very few. And so we're able to sell a lot in the -- particularly in
componenttext: Yes, so we're -- I think the point was, Lisa, that just that last year, it was kind of that first chance to go after the entire client base. Nobody basically have the product. There are a very few. And so we're able to sell a lot in the -- particularly in the first few quarters of the year. And now when you anniversary that, we're still selling the product, but there's not as much opportunity there. So I think then the question was what does it look like for '18? '18 won't be much of an issue because I think we'll be very consistent with '17 to '18. But '16 to this year, '17, there is some impact that we're selling as much. On the other hand, we're selling more of the time and attendance solutions, but their revenue is not quite as much -- the opportunity is not quite as much there. And it's not as probably as far-reaching or as demanding or as creating as much angst with clients as the Affordable Care Act was because of the penalty situation. Now the overtime stuff could start to pick up if enforcement picks up as well. But I think that's just going to take a little bit longer. So again, it's having some impact versus last year, but it's not a huge thing but it's having some impact.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And are there other regulatory changes or rules on the horizon that you would call out like that you see sort of a study pipeline of these rules being considered either at the federal level or in certain states that would kind of continue to drive th
componenttext: Yes. And are there other regulatory changes or rules on the horizon that you would call out like that you see sort of a study pipeline of these rules being considered either at the federal level or in certain states that would kind of continue to drive the incremental secular demand from the regulatory changes?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there hasn't been -- there's been a steady flow based on current administration and probably won't change much in the election, which could have some impact. But minimum wage, for example, right now, it's extremely confusing for our clients. Minimum-
componenttext: Yes, there hasn't been -- there's been a steady flow based on current administration and probably won't change much in the election, which could have some impact. But minimum wage, for example, right now, it's extremely confusing for our clients. Minimum-wage rules are different by state. The Fed's talk about changing minimum-wage they have for government, but in some of those that they are in, they are tied into government. But states are different, cities are different and we really help a lot of our clients help -- we help them through our payroll service only or our HR outsourcing to stay up with minimum wage changes, because not only are they -- they're not changing once, they're changing over a period of years, and you have to make sure that you stay current with those. And there's a lot of work on identifying like who's a -- the kind of immigration-type things. You got to know your customer. You got to know your employees. You got to make sure you've got all of that well documented. So the rules keep coming. I don't think that helps necessarily the business environment in general because of overregulation, but it certainly gives Paychex a lot of opportunities to go in and talk to clients about their payroll need and their HR outsourcing need, because small to midsized businesses just can't keep up with all of these changes. The other thing is that the enforcement and the penalties have increased as states and federal governments have looked for revenue sources. So not only is there an issue about whether you are compliant, but if you're challenged on your compliance, we can provide a tremendous amount of help if you get a penalty in payroll, if you get a penalty for a time issue, a time and attendance issue, we're there to support you with expert documentation and background and relationships with federal state and local governments. And that's a big plus that we sell to clients that they don't realize sometimes until they're hit with an audit or an enforcement penalty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

I think overall, average employees per clients have been slightly trending down due to the strength in SurePayroll and just new business formation on the low end, but then at the same time, your mid-market offerings have been performing well. So almost like a barbell kind of effect. Are you continuing to see that sort of trend in the client base or anything else like that you called out?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just provide a little more color on that. So if you look at average client size, it's down very, very slightly. That has an impact, but you're right. The difficulty is you can't see that completely in payroll. So if you look at our mid-market
componenttext: Yes, let me just provide a little more color on that. So if you look at average client size, it's down very, very slightly. That has an impact, but you're right. The difficulty is you can't see that completely in payroll. So if you look at our mid-market platform taken as a whole, including the modules that are typically sold with them, which are HR, online in time and attendance, you'd seem nice growth over the last 2 or 3 years. Payroll has done fine, too, but it has a little bit of that headwind because of slightly lower clients, driven by some of it is positive which is increasing client growth. So we've gone from growing the client base at 1% to growing between 2% and 3%, and hopefully, that continues to grow. The reason why we're not as concerned about that is that those clients eventually become larger and purchase more services. So we want to keep the funnel reasonably open at the top.
