headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, does the new share-based payment accounting treatment, should we really think of that as a discrete impact on the quarter? Or is there going to be an ongoing impact of putting this in? And if so, do you have a sense what you're expecting i
componenttext: First question, does the new share-based payment accounting treatment, should we really think of that as a discrete impact on the quarter? Or is there going to be an ongoing impact of putting this in? And if so, do you have a sense what you're expecting in the remainder of the fiscal year and moving forward?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so good question. So it is discrete, and it will remain discrete when we record it in a given quarter. It could have modest impacts in subsequent quarters. We'll call it out. We don't expect that it'll have the level of impact that it had this quarte
componenttext: Yes, so good question. So it is discrete, and it will remain discrete when we record it in a given quarter. It could have modest impacts in subsequent quarters. We'll call it out. We don't expect that it'll have the level of impact that it had this quarter. So I'll just leave it at that.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And was there sort of a catch-up impact? Or was this just -- that there was, for some reason, a bigger tax benefit than normal from option this quarter and now that flows through the P&L versus historically it didn't?
componenttext: And was there sort of a catch-up impact? Or was this just -- that there was, for some reason, a bigger tax benefit than normal from option this quarter and now that flows through the P&L versus historically it didn't?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there wasn't a catch-up. It -- without getting into the weeds on the mechanics of the computation, which are complex. Suffice it to say that the combination of an increase in share price, coupled with an increase in share exercises ended up creating
componenttext: Yes, there wasn't a catch-up. It -- without getting into the weeds on the mechanics of the computation, which are complex. Suffice it to say that the combination of an increase in share price, coupled with an increase in share exercises ended up creating a situation where we had more benefit in the quarter. And it -- this will happen periodically throughout in the future, and we'll just call it out when it happened. It will -- you don't anticipate that it will be as sharp as it was this quarter.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then there's always a lot of questions about the payroll growth versus HR. And I guess, it seems to me that you've alluded a couple of times that maybe the distinction isn't as strong as it was in the past. But from that perspective, can
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then there's always a lot of questions about the payroll growth versus HR. And I guess, it seems to me that you've alluded a couple of times that maybe the distinction isn't as strong as it was in the past. But from that perspective, can you just help us understand, how much of your selling efforts headcount, time in the field, however, you want to talk about it, is focused on up-selling more components to broader product set into a pretty sticky and large base versus people who are out there prospecting for new payroll customers? Has that changed? Is more of the focus selling more stuff into the base today than it was in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's changed. Well, obviously, there's a lot more opportunity, but I would say, if you took -- probably, if you thought about core payroll and that sales team and then the way MMS -- the mid-market team goes after it, probably, 40%, 50% is s
componenttext: I don't think it's changed. Well, obviously, there's a lot more opportunity, but I would say, if you took -- probably, if you thought about core payroll and that sales team and then the way MMS -- the mid-market team goes after it, probably, 40%, 50% is still on acquiring new clients and going after them and getting them on board and the other 50% is really -- because when you think about all of HRS really, they're selling into the base for the most part. And then a number of the core and MMS payroll teams are back selling more client, more products, but I'd say it's probably around 50:50, and I don't know if it's changed all that much. I think their focus though on selling the full package upfront is different. So while -- so it's a little bit different than the way I would probably you're thinking about it. We sell a lot more full package right upfront. Our old style would be, "Hey, I sell you payroll, you get used to us, you get happy with us." Six months later, I come back and see if our 401(k) is a value to you or workers' comp or health insurance. Now what we're finding is clients want the full value upfront. They want -- they have a full need in mind, and it's not just, "Yes, I want payroll for now, and then I'll come talk to me." So we're selling more what we call integrated sales approach where multiple teams will go and see a brand-new client and sell them -- it could be everything, including HR outsourcing because that's what they really were looking for and payroll was just coming along with it. So -- but I think if you say 50:50 roughly, that would be fine. It's just the focus is very different now for the sales teams, every from core right through.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you just give us an update on penetration of some of the key categories? And what's the gating factor to further penetrating, whether it's 401(k) or the fully outsourced and some of the other major product categories? Is it price? Is it just
componenttext: And then can you just give us an update on penetration of some of the key categories? And what's the gating factor to further penetrating, whether it's 401(k) or the fully outsourced and some of the other major product categories? Is it price? Is it just you getting out and telling the story? What can you do to drive that penetration higher?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's something, obviously, we're always looking at. I think the penetration rates are still pretty low, so lots of opportunity there for us. I think it's a combination of all of those. It's a combination of what is the client see the value in, lik
componenttext: Well, that's something, obviously, we're always looking at. I think the penetration rates are still pretty low, so lots of opportunity there for us. I think it's a combination of all of those. It's a combination of what is the client see the value in, like a 401(k), for example, and -- or do they feel the pressure from their employee base? We're feeling more clients come to us for products like insurance and 401(k) because, "Hey, there's -- it's harder with full employment." They're moving towards full employment, it's harder for them to capture new employees unless they have the benefit packages that they might not have needed 2 years ago in order to compete for their employees. So it's the need in the market, it's the value to the client and it's execution. Obviously, we spent a tremendous amount of time training, making sure the products are available, making sure that we have the training in all the sales force tools. We've added a tremendous amount of tools to the sales force, data analytics, what clients we have that are most likely to buy a 401(k), most likely to buy insurance, sales force, all of the tools, all help execution. So it's a number of things. I would say penetration rate still give us a tremendous amount of opportunity. We're moving them up, but there's still a lot of room to grow, and I think we're putting everything in place to be successful about it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The slides, just looking at the slides, it looks like on the cash with the long-term capital strategy page, you're talking about strategic accretive acquisitions. I'm curious, accretive, is that sort of 1-year sort of ambition? Or is it -- are you telling
componenttext: The slides, just looking at the slides, it looks like on the cash with the long-term capital strategy page, you're talking about strategic accretive acquisitions. I'm curious, accretive, is that sort of 1-year sort of ambition? Or is it -- are you telling us we shouldn't expect any dilutive deals from Paychex?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that's a long-term issue. And when I mentioned this, look at the technologies, right? And we think there's a strategic advantage in buying a company, for example, SurePayroll, that was not accretive, we'll do it. So every deal is not going to
componenttext: I would say that's a long-term issue. And when I mentioned this, look at the technologies, right? And we think there's a strategic advantage in buying a company, for example, SurePayroll, that was not accretive, we'll do it. So every deal is not going to be accretive right out of the gate. Some aren't. So we're pretty tough on the criteria of dilution in the first year, but if it makes sense, we'll look at it.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. It's good to know. And then just on the overtime legislation. You said there was a little bit of uptick this quarter, but is there a time frame with which we might expect a more significant uptick in attach rates on time and attendance?
componenttext: Understood. It's good to know. And then just on the overtime legislation. You said there was a little bit of uptick this quarter, but is there a time frame with which we might expect a more significant uptick in attach rates on time and attendance?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we actually had a pretty good uptick, double-digit growth in this quarter. And I think it will -- by my expectation would be -- it will be in to the next couple of quarters that will continue to see sales do very well with time and attendanc
componenttext: Well, I think we actually had a pretty good uptick, double-digit growth in this quarter. And I think it will -- by my expectation would be -- it will be in to the next couple of quarters that will continue to see sales do very well with time and attendance. As we're getting closer to that December 1 time frame, this month, next couple of months should see probably the biggest benefit. But I think after that, I think clients are really just kind of making themselves aware of it. The other thing is there's a lot of discussion in the news about, will it be overturned, could it be pushed back through some court proceeding and -- but we don't see that happening at this point. But that could be making clients say, "Hey, I'm going to kind of wait and see how it happens." So it should be a good year overall certainly for time and attendance. But I think that this next quarter, this quarter and next quarter probably would be the best.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So going into and coming out of it, we could feel a little bit of a lift. That's good to know. And then just lastly, just there was a lot of questions around payroll and HRS, but just broadly speaking for the quarter, how did each of those lines c
componenttext: Got it. So going into and coming out of it, we could feel a little bit of a lift. That's good to know. And then just lastly, just there was a lot of questions around payroll and HRS, but just broadly speaking for the quarter, how did each of those lines come in versus your internal plan?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: They were within the range of expectation. So look, I think that's part of what we look at every quarter, try to understand what we think trends are and adjust based on what we're seeing. You can see, we didn't change our guidance on income, fine-tuned re
componenttext: They were within the range of expectation. So look, I think that's part of what we look at every quarter, try to understand what we think trends are and adjust based on what we're seeing. You can see, we didn't change our guidance on income, fine-tuned revenue, actually HR Services had a strong quarter. We'll see where we end up here, but overall, we think we're in the range of what we expected.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we feel good about how we're positioned. We've got fully staffed from a sales rep standpoint. We grew pretty much all the divisions, but in particular, the payroll divisions. And it's getting kind of these new reps, the newer reps to get up to product
componenttext: And we feel good about how we're positioned. We've got fully staffed from a sales rep standpoint. We grew pretty much all the divisions, but in particular, the payroll divisions. And it's getting kind of these new reps, the newer reps to get up to production that we'd like to see -- and but we're fully staffed in that group, we're fully staffed in the service teams to handle ACA, which was a struggle last year just because there was just so much change going on there. And so we feel good that we're kind of on target for what we expected.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the HRS services, could you just talk about like what are the 2 most penetrated solutions that you're currently offering? And what sort of penetration rate that has in order to give a perspective in terms of the opportunity for further cross-sales
componenttext: Just on the HRS services, could you just talk about like what are the 2 most penetrated solutions that you're currently offering? And what sort of penetration rate that has in order to give a perspective in terms of the opportunity for further cross-sales?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the 2 most penetrated were probably workers' comp and insurance and 401(k) and -- but the biggest opportunities are still 401(k) certainly. And I think we've talked about it. We've expanded the last -- roughly now 2 years into what we called
componenttext: Yes, I think the 2 most penetrated were probably workers' comp and insurance and 401(k) and -- but the biggest opportunities are still 401(k) certainly. And I think we've talked about it. We've expanded the last -- roughly now 2 years into what we called large market 401(k). So where we focused a lot on new plans for the first almost 18 years of having the product. The last couple of years, we added a whole team, which has expended on conversion plan, so larger asset plans. And that group has been doing very well, particularly in first quarter, we had some nice growth there. So we're building relationships with brokers who refer us now. And as these rules get more complex for brokers, I think they're bringing our talented kind of tenured team on the large market into more deals, so that's very good. So lots of opportunity on 401(k) and a lot of opportunity in HR outsourcing would certainly be the next largest, meaning ACA -- I'm sorry, ASO, PEO and our HR essentials. So biggest opportunities, as big as revenue basis and opportunities to grow I think are 401(k) and HR outsourcing by far.

componenttext: And what's the penetration rate currently?

componenttext: On HR outsourcing, less than 10%. And if you look at client employees, I did say that we're approaching 1 million worksite employees, and we put out what 11 million, 12 million W2s. So we are a little less than 10% on the employees that we're servicing. And not all of them will need it based on their size, but we think that, that penetration rate is less than 10% and can certainly have a lot of upside.

Like, what's -- what are you seeing on average with new clients above the smallest clients that might just be signing up for just payroll?

componenttext: I would say it's hard to look at it, because the way we bundle it, we don't think of it quite as modules. But I would say that, probably 25% of the clients to 30% of the clients are taking something -- maybe 20% to 30% are taking something more right now. This is relatively new approach to the way we're selling, because we've had so many years of selling payroll then coming back. I think if you are asking how many do we sell a larger bundle upfront, I'd say, it's closer -- it's more in the 20% to 30% range that we're selling a bundle versus payroll-only, and it has at least one additional service or module with it. I mean, we've seen the revenue per client has been -- we've been successful at driving up that revenue per client year after year, so -- frankly, in the last couple of years. So I hope that helps.

componenttext: We sell small. I mean, we absolutely compete very well. It's an interesting point, Mark. Particularly in the fourth quarter of last year, we had very good unit growth. So we continue to see unit growth. And there's a little bit of a trade-off between unit growth we've been seeing, which has been between 2% and 3% and size of client. So that impacts a little bit. It has a little bit of a drag on growth in the short term not in the long term.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the comments related to the Accountable Care Act. Kind of now that you're into the first quarter, I know there's been a lot of debate about whether this year is going to kind of continue to be strong in Obamacare as companies t
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the comments related to the Accountable Care Act. Kind of now that you're into the first quarter, I know there's been a lot of debate about whether this year is going to kind of continue to be strong in Obamacare as companies that didn't choose to comply last year do this year versus whether there is sort of a hangover effect or not. So how are you feeling about that now that you're a few months in?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're -- I think the point was, Lisa, that just that last year, it was kind of that first chance to go after the entire client base. Nobody basically have the product. There are a very few. And so we're able to sell a lot in the -- particularly in
componenttext: Yes, so we're -- I think the point was, Lisa, that just that last year, it was kind of that first chance to go after the entire client base. Nobody basically have the product. There are a very few. And so we're able to sell a lot in the -- particularly in the first few quarters of the year. And now when you anniversary that, we're still selling the product, but there's not as much opportunity there. So I think then the question was what does it look like for '18? '18 won't be much of an issue because I think we'll be very consistent with '17 to '18. But '16 to this year, '17, there is some impact that we're selling as much. On the other hand, we're selling more of the time and attendance solutions, but their revenue is not quite as much -- the opportunity is not quite as much there. And it's not as probably as far-reaching or as demanding or as creating as much angst with clients as the Affordable Care Act was because of the penalty situation. Now the overtime stuff could start to pick up if enforcement picks up as well. But I think that's just going to take a little bit longer. So again, it's having some impact versus last year, but it's not a huge thing but it's having some impact.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And are there other regulatory changes or rules on the horizon that you would call out like that you see sort of a steady pipeline of these rules being considered either at the federal level or in certain states that would kind of continue to drive t
componenttext: Yes. And are there other regulatory changes or rules on the horizon that you would call out like that you see sort of a steady pipeline of these rules being considered either at the federal level or in certain states that would kind of continue to drive the incremental secular demand from the regulatory changes?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there hasn't been -- there's been a steady flow based on current administration and probably won't change much in the election, which could have some impact. But minimum wage, for example, right now, it's extremely confusing for our clients. Minimum-
componenttext: Yes, there hasn't been -- there's been a steady flow based on current administration and probably won't change much in the election, which could have some impact. But minimum wage, for example, right now, it's extremely confusing for our clients. Minimum-wage rules are different by state. The Fed's talk about changing minimum-wage they have for government, but in some of those that they are in, they are tied into government. But states are different, cities are different and we really help a lot of our clients help -- we help them through our payroll service only or our HR outsourcing to stay up with minimum wage changes, because not only are they -- they're not changing once, they're changing over a period of years, and you have to make sure that you stay current with those. And there's a lot of work on identifying like who's a -- the kind of immigration-type things. You got to know your customer. You got to know your employees. You got to make sure you've got all of that well documented. So the rules keep coming. I don't think that helps necessarily the business environment in general because of overregulation, but it certainly gives Paychex a lot of opportunities to go in and talk to clients about their payroll need and their HR outsourcing need, because small to midsized businesses just can't keep up with all of these changes. The other thing is that the enforcement and the penalties have increased as states and federal governments have looked for revenue sources. So not only is there an issue about whether you are compliant, but if you're challenged on your compliance, we can provide a tremendous amount of help if you get a penalty in payroll, if you get a penalty for a time issue, a time and attendance issue, we're there to support you with expert documentation in background and relationships with federal state and local governments. And that's a big plus that we sell to clients that they don't realize sometimes until they're hit with an audit or an enforcement penalty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016

I think overall, average employees per clients have been slightly trending down due to the strength in SurePayroll and just new business formation on the low end, but then at the same time, your mid-market offerings have been performing well. So almost like a barbell kind of effect. Are you continuing to see that sort of trend in the client base or anything else like that you called out?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just provide a little more color on that. So if you look at average client size, it's down very, very slightly. That has an impact, but you're right. The difficulty is you can't see that completely in payroll. So if you look at our mid-market
componenttext: Yes, let me just provide a little more color on that. So if you look at average client size, it's down very, very slightly. That has an impact, but you're right. The difficulty is you can't see that completely in payroll. So if you look at our mid-market platform taken as a whole, including the modules that are typically sold with them, which are HR, online and time and attendance, you'd seem nice growth over the last 2 or 3 years. Payroll has done fine, too, but it has a little bit of that headwind because of slightly lower client size, driven by some of it is positive which is increasing client growth. So we've gone from growing the client base at 1% to growing between 2% and 3%, and hopefully, that continues to grow. The reason why we're not as concerned about that is that those clients eventually become larger and purchase more services. So we want to keep the funnel reasonably open at the top.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you and thank you for joining us on our discussion of Paychex Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results
componenttext:
All right. Thank you and thank you for joining us on our discussion of Paychex Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results for the second quarter ended November 30, 2016. Our Form 10-Q will be filed with the SEC within the next few days. You can access our earnings release and Form 10-Q on our Investor Relations web page. This teleconference is being broadcast over the Internet and will be archived and available on our website for approximately 1 month. 
On today's call, I will update you on the results of our business in the second quarter, and Efrain will review our financial results in more detail and discuss our full year guidance. After that, we'll open it up for your questions. 
Our results for the second quarter reflected good progress. We continue to see positive results across our major product lines. And service revenue for the second quarter grew by 7% year-over-year. We achieved a new milestone this quarter as we attained 1 million client worksite employees served by our Paychex HR Services. Paychex HR Services is our comprehensive outsourcing services product line, and that includes our ASO, or administrative services organization, and our PEO, or professional employer organization as well. Our cloud-based HCM services and, particularly, time and attendance, continued to show strong growth in the quarter. 
Tomorrow is the 1-year anniversary of the acquisition of Advance Partners. Advance has been an excellent addition to the Paychex family. We're very pleased with the leadership and the team's contribution to our financial results and the future opportunities for growth we see in that business particularly timely as the staffing business is picking up some expanded growth today. 
With the success of our HCM solutions, we have continued to invest in operations personnel as we've expanded our multiproduct service centers, including our time and attendance support and our ACA product compliance and service teams. Client retention remains at consistent high levels. We have also invested in our service and our sales organization over the last year, adding headcount across all sales teams. And we are well-positioned going into our third quarter. We will have a better idea of overall sales performance and the impact of the fiscal year next quarter after the end of our peak sales season. 
We continue to make it a priority to provide robust HCM solutions that meet the evolving needs of our client base. At the recent HR Technology Conference and Exposition in October, we showcased enhancements to Paychex Flex that address 2 of the biggest trends in the HR industry: mobile user experience and the HR analytics. Attendees at the conference were able to view a demo of Paychex Flex which included these enhancements. 
We also announced that we shifted to a mobile-first design of our HCM suite. This approach allows Paychex Flex users to have full functionality of all application components regardless of device or screen size. The growing trend for both HR leaders and employees is the use of a mobile device. Shifting to a mobile-first design demonstrates our commitment to putting the needs of our clients and their employees first so that they can accomplish their HR tasks where they want, when they want and on whatever device they want. 
We continue to receive positive recognition of our Flex platform. In November, we were honored to be recognized as a leader in the 2016 NelsonHall Payroll Outsourcing NEAT, a component of the firm's speed-to source initiative. NEAT stands for NelsonHall's Evaluation and Assessment Tool, and is a vendor evaluation report tool that can be utilized by managers to evaluate outsourcing vendors. 
This was the first time we participated in this initiative, and we were placed in the Leader quadrant for 3 areas: technology and user experience, analytics and reporting, and HR cloud integration. The client feedback that goes into this ranking makes this honor even more important to us and reinforces our commitment to delivering the best and most robust solutions in the market today with our Paychex Flex platform. 
This has been a transition period in the U.S. with the presidential election and the move to the Trump administration. We have been asked a few times how we anticipate the new administration will impact the economy overall and, more specifically, the payroll and human capital management outsourcing industry. In this transition time, many business owners could be hesitant to make longer-term decisions. We see this as being more likely to impact the mid to large-sized businesses, rather than small businesses. President-elect Trump has indicated that he intends to lower taxes and create less regulation. This would be a positive for small businesses. It would lower the cost and allow them to invest and hire more. Paychex would benefit as our clients expand and add employees and potentially see value in our HCM services.  
While complex regulations tend to drive companies to an outsourcing solution, we believe any change in regulation is good for Paychex. We remain informed about what is happening in the regulatory environment and are well positioned to continue to educate our clients and assist them with their compliance needs through our technology and service support. 
Over the last year, the Affordable Care Act has been a tailwind for Paychex outsourcing companies, including ourselves. Any rollback of Obamacare or Affordable Care Act or a reduction in compliance and administration requirements will impact the HCM outsourcing industry. Given our target market of small to medium-sized businesses, a large portion of our client base is not -- has not impact -- been impacted by ACA. In November, a federal court issued a preliminary injunction to temporarily block the Department of Labor's final Overtime Rule that would have become effective December 1. This rule would expand overtime for millions of workers. As a result of this injunction, employers did not have to be in compliance with the new rules as of December 1. The ruling is temporary but creates substantial uncertainty for businesses. The proposed rules created an enhanced awareness for the need for time and attendance solutions, particularly to those integrated within their -- with a clients' HCM product suite. This brought an increased demand for our products that we don't see diminishing with the delay in the rules. We will continue to monitor the status of these regulations and ensure our clients remain informed as to how any changes may affect them. 
Shifting the discussion from clients to shareholders. We continued with shareholder-friendly actions. During the second quarter we repurchased 2.9 million shares for a total of $166 million. And we will continue to maintain an industry-leading dividend yield of over 3% with a quarterly dividend of $0.46 per share. 
In summary, we have made solid progress and growth in our financial performance during the past quarter, and I appreciate the great work of our Paychex employees and management team. And I will now turn the call over to Efrain to review our financial results in more detail. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events. And as such, involve risk. Refer to the customary disclosures. As Marty indicated, second quarter financial results fo
componenttext:
Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events. And as such, involve risk. Refer to the customary disclosures. 
As Marty indicated, second quarter financial results for fiscal 2017 showed continued progress and growth. I'll cover some of the key highlights for the second quarter and the 6 months, provide greater detail on certain areas and wrap with a review of the 2017 outlook. 
Total service revenue grew 7% for the second quarter to $760 million and 8% for the 6 months to $1.5 billion. Interest on funds held for clients increased 2% for the second quarter and 6% for the 6 months to $11 million and $23 million, respectively. These changes were primarily driven by slightly higher average interest rates earned. The growth was tempered by a slight decrease in the average investment balances by approximately 1% for both periods. This is really a timing issue that we call out in the press release. 
Expenses increased 8% for both the second quarter and 6 months, with Advance Partners contributing approximately 1.5% to this growth for both periods. Expense growth was impacted by higher wages and related expenses due to growth in headcount in our operations area. 
Selling expenses have shown modest growth, reflecting strong sales performance in the year-ago quarter. Our operating margin was approximately 40.3% for the second quarter and 40.7% year-to-date comparable with the prior year periods. We continue to maintain industry-leading margins while investing in our operations. 
Our effective income tax rate was 35.2% for the second quarter and 34.1% for the 6 months, compared to 36% and 32.9% for the respective periods last year. As we discussed on our last quarterly call, we had several discrete items, tax items, in the first quarter of both years that have impacted the year-to-date effective income tax rates. In fiscal 2017, we implemented new accounting guidance related to employee stock-based compensation, which has resulted in discrete tax benefits now being recognized upon exercise or a lapse of stock-based awards. The impact with this in the second quarter was immaterial but had a larger impact in the first quarter. Last year, in the first quarter of fiscal 2016, we recognized a net tax benefit on income from prior tax years related to customer-facing software we produce. Because there have been ins and outs, refer to the press release and you'll see we provide a non-GAAP EBITDA comparison -- I should say, non-GAAP EPS comparison with and without these items. 
Net income increased 7% to $202 million for the second quarter and 5% to $420 million for the 6 months. Diluted earnings per share increased 8% to $0.56 per share for the second quarter and 5% to $1.16 per share for the 6 months. On a non-GAAP basis, as I mentioned just a second ago, adjusted net income increased 6% to $201 million for the second quarter and 7% to $405 million for the 6 months. Adjusted diluted earnings per share increased 8% to $0.56 per share for the second quarter and 8% to $1.12 per share for the 6 months. Note that these 2 non-GAAP measures exclude certain discrete tax items previously discussed. Refer to the table if you have any questions about that. 
Payroll service revenue increased 3% for the second quarter to $441 million and 4% to $892 million for the 6 months. Advance Partners contributed 1% to the growth in payroll service revenue for both the quarter and year-to-date periods. We benefited from increases in client-based and revenue per check. Revenue per check grew as a result of price increases net of discounting. 
Payroll client size impacted revenue as average client size trended modestly lower. We discussed that in the first quarter. We saw a continuation of that trend in the second quarter. 
While we continue to present payroll service revenue and HRS revenue, I want to emphasize one important point: With the evolving nature of our businesses to an HCM provider, we now offer more product bundles that are bundled with payroll. Revenue from these bundles is allocated among payroll and HRS. The payroll growth remains steady, but HRS growth reflects the sale of more services to clients and greater revenue per client. And I call out specifically that we had another strong quarter in time and attendance sales. 
HRS revenue increased 12% to $319 million for the second quarter, 14% to $642 million for the 6 months. This increase reflects continued growth across our client base and all HCM services, including our comprehensive HR outsourcing services, retirement services, time and attendance and HR administration. 
Within Paychex HR Services, we've continued to see strong demand, which is reflected in the double-digit year-over-year growth and the number of client worksite employees served. Insurance services benefited from continued growth in revenue from our ESR services as well as growth in the number of health and benefit applicants. Our workers' comp insurance product benefited from higher average premiums and client base growth. Retirement services revenue reflected an increase in asset fee revenue earned on the value of participant funds as well as an increase in the number of plans served. Last, Advance Partners contributed a little bit less than 2% to the growth in HRS revenue for both the second quarter and the 6 months. 
Investments and income. Turning to our portfolio. Our goal is, as you know, to protect principal and optimize liquidity. On the short-term side, primary short-term vehicles remain  bank demand deposit accounts and variable-rate demand notes. In our longer-term portfolio, we invest primarily in high credit-quality municipal bonds, some corporate bonds and U.S. government securities. Long-term portfolio has -- now has an average yield of 1.7% and average duration of 3.3 years. 
Our combined portfolios have earned an average rate of return of 1.2% for the second quarter and 6 months, up from 1.1% last [indiscernible]. Average investment balances for funds held for clients decreased by approximately 1% year-over-year as the impact from growth in client base was offset by timing of certain remittances to taxing authorities. We expect that in the second half of the year, that will change and we'll -- we expect client base -- client growth -- client funds growth, I should say, sorry, to grow about 1%. 
I'll now walk you through highlights of our financial position. It remains strong with cash and total corporate investments of $725 million as of the end of the quarter. Funds held for clients as of November 30 were $3.2 billion compared to $4 billion as of May 31. Funds held for clients vary widely, as you know, and may average $3.7 billion for both the quarter and the 6 months. 
Total available-for-sale investments, including corporate investments and funds held for clients, reflected net unrealized losses of $16 million as of November 30 compared with a net unrealized gain of $48 million as of May 31. Recently, interest rates for intermediate term investors -- investments, I should say, have rallied resulting in a decrease in the market value of our portfolio. 
Total stockholder's equity was $1.8 billion as of November 30, 2016, reflecting $331 million in dividends and $166 million of repurchases of Paychex common stock. Our return on equity for the past 12 months was 40%. 
Cash flows from operations were $413 million for the first 6 months, a decrease of 2% from the prior year. This decrease was a result of fluctuations in working capital offset by higher net income and noncash adjustments. 
Now let me turn to guidance. We remind you that the outlook is based in our current view of economic and interest rate conditions. And what I mean by that is we do factor in the recent Fed rate raise, but we don't factor in any continuing raises beyond that. We'll update as we see those. We obviously expect that there will be some, but they're not baked into this guidance. 
Payroll service revenue growth is anticipated to be in the range of 3% to 4%. We anticipate payroll revenue growth in the third quarter will be below the range of full year guidance. As we discussed on last quarter's call, we now expect that it will be approximately 2%. Remember that the third quarter is impacted by 1 less processing day. 
HRS revenue growth is anticipated to remain in the range of 12% to 14%. Total service revenue is anticipated to remain in the range of 7% to 8%. Interest on funds held for clients is anticipated to grow in the upper single digits. The impact of the recent increase in short-term rates will be modest but would be more accretive as we enter into 2018. 
Operating margins are anticipated to be consistent with the guidance previously provided. Effective tax rate for the year is expected to be approximately 35%. GAAP basis, net income growth is expected to be approximately 7%. We said that last quarter. Adjusted net income, which is a non-GAAP measure that excludes certain discrete tax items, is anticipated to grow approximately 8%, consistent with the guidance that we gave in June. 
Turn it back to Marty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
