componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first one is from Mr. Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to start with a question on the core payroll segment. I'm just trying to do the math here on the back of the more precise outlook on Q3 at the 2% level. I mean, I guess, to get to the midpoint of the full year at 3% to 4% range, it seems like
componenttext: I just want to start with a question on the core payroll segment. I'm just trying to do the math here on the back of the more precise outlook on Q3 at the 2% level. I mean, I guess, to get to the midpoint of the full year at 3% to 4% range, it seems like you'd have to be about 4.5% growth in Q4. So just so we've got our models aligned properly, I mean, should we be thinking about the lower end, 3% to 4% more particularly? Or are there some real accelerators in Q4? I know you're not going to have the benefit of Advance anymore, but I don't think you're disadvantaged in terms of processing days either there.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason. I think to call it precisely is a little bit tough because we need to get through selling. But I think at this point, we'd anticipate we're towards the lower end of that range.
componenttext: Yes, Jason. I think to call it precisely is a little bit tough because we need to get through selling. But I think at this point, we'd anticipate we're towards the lower end of that range.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. Understood. And then just wanted to check on pricing as well. That's an area of continued -- always get questions on. I know you talked about there being some lift from pricing. If it is still in that historical 2% to 4% range, I guess th
componenttext: Okay, all right. Understood. And then just wanted to check on pricing as well. That's an area of continued -- always get questions on. I know you talked about there being some lift from pricing. If it is still in that historical 2% to 4% range, I guess that would imply that on an organic basis, that volumes in core payroll were kind of flat to down. Are we thinking about that right? Is 2% to 4% still the right range that you're seeing on price?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me talk about that. So yes, it is 2% to 4%. This year, it's probably closer to the lower end. We've been trending somewhere between the low and the mid part of that range. So we still are getting price. We still are getting volume. So our clie
componenttext: Yes, so let me talk about that. So yes, it is 2% to 4%. This year, it's probably closer to the lower end. We've been trending somewhere between the low and the mid part of that range. So we still are getting price. We still are getting volume. So our client base is up over last year, and we've said we'd be between 1% to 3%. Last year, we were 2%. We're in that range. So what accounts for the difference? It is accounted for by the fact that our client -- average client size is a little bit smaller. So to put this in context, if you go back 10 years, go back to 2007, our average client size is 17. But some years, it's 17.1. Last year we ended at 16.73. And at this point, we are trending slightly down from that number. And so that the effect of that mix is basically taking payroll service revenue down. This happens from time to time. It happens more when 2 things are present: The first is that we start to see a flattening in checks per payroll, which is what we've been seeing over the last 3 to 4 quarters. Actually, this quarter, our checks per payroll went negative. So what that means is that -- and by the way, that's on a same-store basis, so I want to clarify that. What that means is that, particularly our clients in the under 50 space, simply aren't adding a lot of employees at this stage. Will that continue? We'll see. It's been bouncing around quarter-to-quarter. And if you look at our index that we publish each month, you'll see that reflected in the numbers. But that's part a. And then part b is that as we sell clients that are a little bit lower than those that we lose, we have this drag effect. In most years, that basically is offset by some client checks per payroll growth. This is a year where we're not seeing that. So we're monitoring that and saw some of it in Q1, and we'll see if it continues into Q2. It can bounce around. I would just caution not to assume that that's exactly what you're going to see through the balance of the year. But we're assuming at this point some drag in checks per payroll as we go through the year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not -- just to add to that a little bit. We're not -- when you look at last year, second quarter, there was kind of a push because of the Affordable Care Act, particularly in the mid-market clients. And to get in and buy those services and ther
componenttext: Yes, we're not -- just to add to that a little bit. We're not -- when you look at last year, second quarter, there was kind of a push because of the Affordable Care Act, particularly in the mid-market clients. And to get in and buy those services and therefore, it got you in the door a lot more for sales and that kind of ticked up the size of the average client because we sold a little bit more in the mid market. So it's an interesting time with the election to see how much the Affordable Care Act last year versus this year had an impact. And because we sold those clients pretty much who needed it. Now the retention has been very strong on that product even with the uncertainty. But that was higher last year. It got you in the door a lot more in the mid market because they were interested in not only the Affordable Care Act but how you integrated with the payroll services. And so that may have been an impact. And then as Efrain mentioned, on our Small Business Index, we've seen a flattening out of hiring in the small business sector, the under 50 employees sector, and for a couple of months now. And that could be around the election or not. So it's kind of an interesting quarter because of the election and the possible changes coming up as well.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and -- that's helpful. Just one last one for me. I think in the quarter, you bought back more than twice as many shares as you had bought all of last fiscal year. So wanted to get a sense of whether that's indicative of any change in the M&A pipelin
componenttext: Okay, and -- that's helpful. Just one last one for me. I think in the quarter, you bought back more than twice as many shares as you had bought all of last fiscal year. So wanted to get a sense of whether that's indicative of any change in the M&A pipeline in terms of the prospects there, either in terms of size of the prospects or potential timing on the prospects.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the short answer is no. The share repurchase itself was really simply an attempt to get back down to average share count. And if you look at it, we actually are still a bit high compared to where we were last year. So we'll do a little bit of -- o
componenttext: Yes. So the short answer is no. The share repurchase itself was really simply an attempt to get back down to average share count. And if you look at it, we actually are still a bit high compared to where we were last year. So we'll do a little bit of -- on a year-to-date basis, we'll do a little bit more buying just to get back to flat. Now actually, Marty can talk a little bit more about the M&A pipeline. But it's pretty robust.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, still pretty active. Not always finding exactly what we want, but it's -- I don't think it's ever been probably more active from a pipeline standpoint. It's just whether you get to the final deal or not based on the value and what we find in diligenc
componenttext: Yes, still pretty active. Not always finding exactly what we want, but it's -- I don't think it's ever been probably more active from a pipeline standpoint. It's just whether you get to the final deal or not based on the value and what we find in diligence. But been very active on that front and hasn't slowed down at all.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from James Berkley with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from James Berkley with Barclays.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to get a better handle on how to think about revenue growth for '17. I know you touched on a little bit on the payroll side just now. But through the first half of the year, you're near the high end of your guided ranges on payroll and HRS gro
componenttext: Just wanted to get a better handle on how to think about revenue growth for '17. I know you touched on a little bit on the payroll side just now. But through the first half of the year, you're near the high end of your guided ranges on payroll and HRS growth. But this quarter, did see the low end of those ranges. You've got Advance Partners lapping 1 less day in fiscal third quarter. Questions around the Affordable Care Act and time and attendance given the delay with the Department of Labor. Just how do we think about all those moving parts in the back half of the year in particular? And what are you thinking about the ACA and time and attendance, the aspect -- that aspect post Trump versus previously?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, wow, that's [indiscernible] compound question. So I'd say, let me just say broadly and then I'll come back to ACA and other regulatory changes. Marty, obviously, will have some thoughts on that. But our guidance contemplates all of those issues obvi
componenttext: Okay, wow, that's [indiscernible] compound question. So I'd say, let me just say broadly and then I'll come back to ACA and other regulatory changes. Marty, obviously, will have some thoughts on that. But our guidance contemplates all of those issues obviously. We just answered a question on payroll services, revenue growth. HRS has remained unchanged. So from that standpoint, we feel comfortable with where we are for the remainder of the year. And for the full year, we don't focus necessarily on quarters unless there's something unusual in the quarter that we want to call out like Q3, which has one less day. Feel comfortable about where we are in terms of margins and expenses. So that outlook that we're providing basically encompasses what we understand the environment to be. Don't anticipate it will change significantly. Now with respect to ACA and with respect to other changes in regulation, it's a little bit early to call those. The Overtime Rules change, at this point, don't see a lot of impact on the balance of the year. It could impact next year. And then on what exactly happens with ACA, that's a question to be answered at this point. What I would say is, if we were to see some sort of significant movement to repeal starting sometime in late spring, our anticipation of -- if that were to roll out over a, let's say, call it a 2- to 3-year period, is that we'd see about an impact of 1% on EPS per year. If it was more accelerated, it might be more. But we're still waiting -- that, by the way, is more of a worst-case scenario, 1% to 1.5% EPS. We think we have other options to replace that revenue. But at this point, we'd frame sort of the risk if the ACA got repealed in an orderly fashion. If it got replaced and repealed immediately, that would be a different conversation. We'll have to wait and see where we end up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the expectation, at least at this point, would be it's going to take some time. It's pretty complicated, as you know, and -- to change it. So -- and we're seeing very solid retention. Of course, clients are looking for us to file in March now
componenttext: Yes, I think the expectation, at least at this point, would be it's going to take some time. It's pretty complicated, as you know, and -- to change it. So -- and we're seeing very solid retention. Of course, clients are looking for us to file in March now for them and I don't think you're going to see much movement, at least through that filing period. And I think it's going to be a longer thing, which as Efrain mentioned, we're looking at, depending on what happens, a number of products. My guess is clients are still going to have to do something, and they're going to need some support for that. So we feel pretty good that we will be able to adapt to that. Might not make up all the revenue, but it certainly has some opportunity there. From a time and attendance, it's been interesting that we've had very strong sales of our time and attendance solutions. And we've introduced a new one, that is Flex Essentials [ph]. That is a no-clock, all-web or mobile punch, much simpler to set up, and we've seen an acceleration there. So I think the whole Overtime Rule issue, even though it's now been delayed and may end up never being enacted, who knows, has driven a lot of interest in time and attendance. And so that's driven sales that I don't think somebody's going to necessarily get rid of that product. And in fact, it may keep kind of a heightened demand now. So I think that's how we feel about it, as pretty good at this point and see what happens next.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That make a lot of sense. And thanks for the color on the ACA there. Those numbers are really helpful. Just one more quick follow-up here, more of a high-level question. Just correct me if I'm wrong, I believe about 10% of your company's revenue is
componenttext: Right. That make a lot of sense. And thanks for the color on the ACA there. Those numbers are really helpful. Just one more quick follow-up here, more of a high-level question. Just correct me if I'm wrong, I believe about 10% of your company's revenue is driven by the PEO business and another 10% from the ASO side. I think you got PEO growing more quickly over the last few years. Just curious if you could talk about how fast each is growing, the trends that you're seeing, whether there's been an acceleration recently versus past quarters or past years and just going into more detail in each of those and what's driving the gap between the 2 growth rates?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I -- what we've said about the HR Outsourcing business is that it's about half of HRS revenue. And within that half, about half is PEO and half is ASO. So that's what we said and we update that yearly. Our PEO has been growing more quickly than AS
componenttext: Yes. So I -- what we've said about the HR Outsourcing business is that it's about half of HRS revenue. And within that half, about half is PEO and half is ASO. So that's what we said and we update that yearly. Our PEO has been growing more quickly than ASO but both have been growing double digits. I guess that's what we'd say. The only other thing I would add to that is that because the PEO, we report healthcare attachment as part of the revenues of the PEO. When we get better healthcare attachment in the quarter, then you have better PEO growth. That really doesn't have much of an impact on the margins in this quarter. We did not have as significant healthcare attachments we had in the quarter before, but that bounces around every single quarter. So Q3, we'll see where we end up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we feel pretty good. Obviously reaching the new milestone of over 1 million worksite employees that we are servicing between our service -- between the ASO and PEO. We feel good, we are very well-positioned. There's been a lot of demand for t
componenttext: Yes, I think we feel pretty good. Obviously reaching the new milestone of over 1 million worksite employees that we are servicing between our service -- between the ASO and PEO. We feel good, we are very well-positioned. There's been a lot of demand for the HR support. And I think PEO, while it's been strong in certain states and we sell it across pretty much all states, it is starting to continue -- it's continuing to pick up more demand and we feel good about the future of it. As Efrain said, the attachment of the health can swing from kind of quarter-to-quarter even month-to-month. But -- and again, I think it's going to be interesting to see kind of what comes out of it. Now you have a quarter where a lot of discussion about health care and you may have a number of clients deciding to kind of hold and wait and see what's going to happen. But we see good growth. We've been doing well in both PEO and ASO, well-positioned to have both products. So if you want co-employment, if you have it. If you don't, we have the insurance agency that's a top agency and plenty of plans to offer. So feel good about both products right now.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from David [indiscernible] with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: The next question is from David [indiscernible] with Evercore ISI.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] for David Tobit. In the first quarter, you really highlighted the strength in the mid-market and that seems to have slowed down a bit in the second quarter. I guess what's change there? And maybe if you can just highlight your expe
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] for David Tobit. In the first quarter, you really highlighted the strength in the mid-market and that seems to have slowed down a bit in the second quarter. I guess what's change there? And maybe if you can just highlight your expectations for the remainder of the year in the mid-market?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in the second quarter, we had a very, very strong quarter a year ago and compares were tougher. We expect that -- we're expecting a good quarter in the third quarter. And I think Marty pointed out something that's important. Last year, there
componenttext: Yes, I think in the second quarter, we had a very, very strong quarter a year ago and compares were tougher. We expect that -- we're expecting a good quarter in the third quarter. And I think Marty pointed out something that's important. Last year, there was a drive by many mid-market companies to find integrated solutions that included an ACA compliant solution. A lot of those clients have now selected their solution and the game now is a bit more of a competitive takeaway as opposed to selling them on a new solution. There obviously was some of that going on. So we are going in the third quarter assuming that we'll pick up from where we were in Q2.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly feel great about the product and ever-expanding functionality of the product. And I think, as Efrain said, last year was kind of a heightened [indiscernible] second quarter with the Affordable Care Act sales and this year, it's almost a lit
componenttext: Yes. Certainly feel great about the product and ever-expanding functionality of the product. And I think, as Efrain said, last year was kind of a heightened [indiscernible] second quarter with the Affordable Care Act sales and this year, it's almost a little bit of the reverse, I think people are being a little bit careful to make any changes until they see what the rules come out, how it changes and they're probably concerned about their filing and making a change and not getting anything filed. So we saw a little bit, probably unexpected -- a little bit slower there. And we expect that once we get past the filing date. So expect a good selling season here. But it may still continue to be a little bit slow through the third quarter until we get past the filing date. We'll have to see kind of how that shakes out. But we feel certainly good about the product, the competitiveness and going head-to-head with any of the competitors in the market.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess besides the client behavior, are you seeing any change in the competitive landscape at all?
componenttext: I guess besides the client behavior, are you seeing any change in the competitive landscape at all?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. No, there's no real new competitors there. We haven't seen a lot of change in their approach or product. And I think we've -- as I mentioned, we've continued to add new options to our product and more self-service, more analytics. We talke
componenttext: No, not really. No, there's no real new competitors there. We haven't seen a lot of change in their approach or product. And I think we've -- as I mentioned, we've continued to add new options to our product and more self-service, more analytics. We talked about HR Analytics and providing more there. Mobile-first design, so an increased use of mobile. So we're feeling very good, very competitive. Have not really seen any change from a competitive marketplace.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As many -- as I'm sure you saw the NIFB put up some small business confidence indicators for the month of November, which were substantially stronger after the election than before, I guess it sounds like from your overall kind of qualitative client comme
componenttext: As many -- as I'm sure you saw the NIFB put up some small business confidence indicators for the month of November, which were substantially stronger after the election than before, I guess it sounds like from your overall kind of qualitative client commentary that people are still cautious, pending any changes in the regulation. Can you give us any kind of additional color on what you have been [indiscernible] from clients over the last month or 1.5 months in terms of their optimism on overall business levels and how that kind of matches with your commentary on the rest of the business?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's exactly -- I think it's optimism pending action. So I think it's a lot of optimism on pay lower corporate tax rates to drive a lot of less expense and more to what they could invest and more employees and so forth. Affordable Care Act lo
componenttext: Yes, I think it's exactly -- I think it's optimism pending action. So I think it's a lot of optimism on pay lower corporate tax rates to drive a lot of less expense and more to what they could invest and more employees and so forth. Affordable Care Act looks like those costs could come down for a lot of companies and not forcing them to have the product but we'll see. Time and attendance rules, though it's a little bit separate, but less regulation. I think overall, it's a very optimistic attitude from the clients but not necessarily turning that into action yet because they got to see it. So they're feeling good about the fact that it looks like there's going to be a better business environment. Consumer confidence is also up. NIFB was one of the biggest increases we've seen in over the 42-year average, for the 1 of the 3 times I think in the last almost 10 years. So there's a lot of optimism but I don't think again they're turning that into action, hiring and so forth, at least yet until they see kind of what the first few months of the new administration brings. That's what -- we're kind of getting great optimism but the small business index, at least for November, our last one, would show still not a big uptick in hiring kind of at the same growth rate it was last year for at least small business. So very positive, but kind of waiting to see what happens.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then maybe as a follow up, I think last quarter you cited the traction you're seeing in the 100 and 200 plus kind of segment and the new increment sale spend you've been putting against that. Can you talk about, first of all, whether t
componenttext: That's helpful. And then maybe as a follow up, I think last quarter you cited the traction you're seeing in the 100 and 200 plus kind of segment and the new increment sale spend you've been putting against that. Can you talk about, first of all, whether there's any change in that traction? Whether you see continued momentum there? And whether you think the incremental sales spend you put against that is actually adequate at this point, such that you don't have to increase it more in the coming quarters?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think -- I think we're adequate, we're fully staffed and we feel very good about being fully staffed and out there. I think the only surprise in the quarter, we've kind of already mentioned, which is a little bit more inactivity to make a cha
componenttext: Yes, I don't think -- I think we're adequate, we're fully staffed and we feel very good about being fully staffed and out there. I think the only surprise in the quarter, we've kind of already mentioned, which is a little bit more inactivity to make a change than we saw last year at this time. And I think that would be the only difference. And I think that's kind of more of a macro kind of issue. And so I think that will be the only change. Certainly feel good about, as I mentioned, the competitiveness. No change really in the competitive environment. And we're fully staffed and gaining more and more experience on the newer reps that we added at the beginning of the fiscal year. So we'll be able to talk more about it after the selling season. The only real difference from first quarter, I would say, is with the election, which really changed quite rapidly, at least a view of the election and who won, I think that just put people in a little bit more cautious period for switching anything or making buying decisions in the second quarter.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And just a quick clarification, if I could. In the quarter itself, relative to the plan you had heading into the quarter, when you say that the DOL lack of bookings or the ACA shortfall was kind of the bigger contributor there?
componenttext: That's fair. And just a quick clarification, if I could. In the quarter itself, relative to the plan you had heading into the quarter, when you say that the DOL lack of bookings or the ACA shortfall was kind of the bigger contributor there?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't -- I think the ACA -- I think just the election, if I'm getting your question, right, Jim, I think the question or the -- what happened was, with the changes in ACA, with the president -- with Trump getting in and probably a little bit more
componenttext: Well, I don't -- I think the ACA -- I think just the election, if I'm getting your question, right, Jim, I think the question or the -- what happened was, with the changes in ACA, with the president -- with Trump getting in and probably a little bit more unexpected until second quarter, as it got closer to the election, I think people know changes are going to happen. And so they're a little bit less -- they're a little bit more reluctant to make a change until they see kind of what happened. They're optimistic but they're not sure what's going to happen yet. And so if that answers your question. Now the DOL, you're talking about the Overtime Rules. I think that was very helpful from an over -- from a selling of our Flex Time and Flex Essentials in our time clocks. And I think that's ticking. So the good thing there is it brought a lot of attention to you ought to be tracking time, look at the options that are out there now from a technology standpoint, punching in and out on a mobile phone, things that have not been available, generally, until the last year or so. And I think that's going to stick. So if that actually help drive some sales that are recorded in our HRS services revenue and I think that's going to continue and it's going to stick no matter what happens with Overtime Rules.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mr. Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's quite a bit of debate about how much you'll actually benefit in the short-term for the float. So I want to ask a two-part question just help frame that. The first one, do you -- as you think about the float, how you manage the float, is there stil
componenttext: There's quite a bit of debate about how much you'll actually benefit in the short-term for the float. So I want to ask a two-part question just help frame that. The first one, do you -- as you think about the float, how you manage the float, is there still right -- I know there's a seasonality, but to think that roughly half of the float balance is short-term stuff, whether it's money market, the variable demand rate notes et cetera and you're targeting about half in intermediate term bonds. And the second, the second question, if we look at that bond portfolio, I think you said 3.3 year duration, is the stuff that's maturing in the next 12 months, are the interest rates that you would likely reinvest at in today above the rates of the stuff that's maturing or is that still a negative at this point? Thank you.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, hey, good question. So yes, you're right, its -- short-term is about 45%. It can be sometimes 50%. But we keep it between 45% and 50%. So that reprices immediately or very quickly, I shouldn't say -- should say. Let me just be careful, that's an ove
componenttext: Okay, hey, good question. So yes, you're right, its -- short-term is about 45%. It can be sometimes 50%. But we keep it between 45% and 50%. So that reprices immediately or very quickly, I shouldn't say -- should say. Let me just be careful, that's an overstatement. It doesn't reprice immediately, it typically reprices in somewhere between 45 and 60 days. So the answer to your first question, portfolio composition is yes, that's correct. And then the second is yes, also. Yes, the bonds that we would invest in going forward currently have yields that are significantly higher than the ones that are rolling off. So if I were to call it today and I am not doing that, but if I were to call it today, and I assume no more Fed increases other than what we have gotten at this point, the portfolio would be about $8 million higher in value than it is today. I'll just caution anyone from taking that to the bank because we'll have much more granular information once we get through the next couple of quarters and see what the fate -- what the Fed actually does. And the reason why I say that is we look at and we could give you a big forecast based on yield curves. I'm distrust [ph] that approach. I'd rather tell you what we think our portfolios will do based on what I know at the time I'm saying it. But you can do some math and the numbers start to get pretty significant if the Fed does what it says it's going to do. And the final qualification I'd add to that is the steepness of the yield curve also impacts how we invest. So right now, they do nothing, I'd call that at about $8 million next year that's annualized and we'll see where we go through the remainder of the year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify that, that's very helpful, by the way. So the $8 million, that is annualizing and getting the full benefit from the Fed funds rate increase recently and also the benefit from reinvesting bonds at what the current yield curve is, is tha
componenttext: And just to clarify that, that's very helpful, by the way. So the $8 million, that is annualizing and getting the full benefit from the Fed funds rate increase recently and also the benefit from reinvesting bonds at what the current yield curve is, is that correct?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct.
componenttext: Yes, correct.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question. The -- maybe this is just getting too nitpicky on my end but the buyback was pretty significant and no increase in the guidance for earnings. It feels like there's a couple of pennies there. Is that just conservatis
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question. The -- maybe this is just getting too nitpicky on my end but the buyback was pretty significant and no increase in the guidance for earnings. It feels like there's a couple of pennies there. Is that just conservatism? Or is there some other thing we should think about with that? Thank you.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess I'd say, Gary, there's always pluses and minuses. So you have to look at what you think are some potential upsides with some potential downsides. I think it's realistic, I wouldn't call it aggressive and I wouldn't call it conservative.
componenttext: Yes. I guess I'd say, Gary, there's always pluses and minuses. So you have to look at what you think are some potential upsides with some potential downsides. I think it's realistic, I wouldn't call it aggressive and I wouldn't call it conservative.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just actually one other one. Have you done the analysis and maybe it's just we don't know enough but about what kind of risks you might face in terms of potential declines in the float portfolio balances based on some of the personal income
componenttext: Okay. And then just actually one other one. Have you done the analysis and maybe it's just we don't know enough but about what kind of risks you might face in terms of potential declines in the float portfolio balances based on some of the personal income tax changes that Trump and the Republican Congress have been floating? Should we think of that as a potential offset as some of this is the withholding might be less for a significant portion of your customers? Thank you.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't started doing modeling at this point. Because at that point, the benefit -- okay, so that's coupled with a more -- a bigger discussion about whether corporate tax rates go down. If that happens, then even if we face some drag from personal
componenttext: No, we haven't started doing modeling at this point. Because at that point, the benefit -- okay, so that's coupled with a more -- a bigger discussion about whether corporate tax rates go down. If that happens, then even if we face some drag from personal income taxes, the corporate tax impact simply dwarfs everything else, so that we'd look at both. So if a tax reform occurs, it's pretty obvious that we would be a pretty significant beneficiary. By significant, I mean very significant. So we're waiting to hear, like everyone else is waiting to hear. So that's a partial answer to your question.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mr. Bryan Keane with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Bryan Keane with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to -- a couple of clarifications just on HR Services. I think The Street was looking for [ph] more like 14% revenue growth. I know the guide is 12% to 14%. And it came in a little bit towards the lower end. Was there -- I just want to make sure
componenttext: Just want to -- a couple of clarifications just on HR Services. I think The Street was looking for [ph] more like 14% revenue growth. I know the guide is 12% to 14%. And it came in a little bit towards the lower end. Was there -- I just want to make sure the puts and takes there. Here's what I'm thinking about. Obviously, Advance Partners acquisition is anniversary-ing and that contributed 2 points to growth so then I'm thinking about the back half of the year with that coming off, do we have enough in the pipe and in sales to actually increase that growth rate for the back half?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Bryan, our guidance, obviously included Advance. We came out of the first quarter, I think we're at 15% growth. I think I called out attach rates on health care in the PEO, we're a little bit lower than we had projected. That can reverse very, ver
componenttext: Yes. So Bryan, our guidance, obviously included Advance. We came out of the first quarter, I think we're at 15% growth. I think I called out attach rates on health care in the PEO, we're a little bit lower than we had projected. That can reverse very, very quickly quarter-to-quarter. So we'll see where we are in Q3. But in terms of where we expect the year to be, we're not really far off from what we expected. So I see where people might get to 14%. I don't think our internal plan suggests that we would be at 14%. And so we should be solidly in the year in the range of the guidance that we provided. And obviously, as you pointed out, the selling season will have an impact on where HRS growth ends up for the year. But we feel comfortable with the ranges we've given.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in the back half, since Advance will now be in the numbers, it won't probably push that growth rate. Should we think about more towards the lower end then in that range of 12% to 14% for the back half is that the result of Advance anniversa
componenttext: Okay. And then in the back half, since Advance will now be in the numbers, it won't probably push that growth rate. Should we think about more towards the lower end then in that range of 12% to 14% for the back half is that the result of Advance anniversary-ing?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say yes, subject to whatever we see in terms of sales in the Q -- I'm sorry, in the third quarter which is where the bulk of the selling season comes in. I would say that, although I didn't call out where we end up in Q4, our guidance is for the y
componenttext: I would say yes, subject to whatever we see in terms of sales in the Q -- I'm sorry, in the third quarter which is where the bulk of the selling season comes in. I would say that, although I didn't call out where we end up in Q4, our guidance is for the year as a whole and we feel comfortable for the year as a whole, that may not mean -- or that may mean that in some quarters, they aren't exactly in the range of that guidance. So if it's significant, we'll call it out.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, helpful. And then just time and attendance. How big is that? And how fast is that growing? I know it's been one of the catalysts that you guys have called out. Just how big is that as a percentage of revenue? And maybe the growth rates that you guys
componenttext: Okay, helpful. And then just time and attendance. How big is that? And how fast is that growing? I know it's been one of the catalysts that you guys have called out. Just how big is that as a percentage of revenue? And maybe the growth rates that you guys have been seeing there?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the last time we updated it, it's about -- it was about, last year, about 10%. I should say online services, which includes HR administration which is also part of the equation. Back up a second, so it's clear. The fundamental parts of the HCM platform
componenttext: So the last time we updated it, it's about -- it was about, last year, about 10%. I should say online services, which includes HR administration which is also part of the equation. Back up a second, so it's clear. The fundamental parts of the HCM platform include an HR administration module and time and attendance module and obviously, payroll engine module. So about 10% of HRS revenue growth -- for revenue is online services. We don't break it out more than that. That's been growing at multiples with what payroll has been growing at.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Kartik Mehta with North coast research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Kartik Mehta with North coast research.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Efrain, I just want to make sure I understood something you said about the float portfolio. I think you said obviously the rate is kind of -- the Fed [indiscernible] will be about $8 million. I think I remember I thought in the Q you said that 25 basis po
componenttext: Efrain, I just want to make sure I understood something you said about the float portfolio. I think you said obviously the rate is kind of -- the Fed [indiscernible] will be about $8 million. I think I remember I thought in the Q you said that 25 basis point would mean after-tax net income of $2.5 million to $4 million. And so that $8 million, is there some tax impact to that that will be different? Or did I -- am I missing something that you might have said or misinterpreted?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, you're just missing some information which I didn't provide in my estimate. So our disclosure is that a 25 basis point rise impacts the portfolio immediately on an annualized basis to the tune of about $3.5 million, $3.7 million, I believe it
componenttext: No, no, no, you're just missing some information which I didn't provide in my estimate. So our disclosure is that a 25 basis point rise impacts the portfolio immediately on an annualized basis to the tune of about $3.5 million, $3.7 million, I believe it is. But that doesn't end the conversation. But then the question you have to ask youself is what does it do to long-term rates? If in the end, your investment for long-term rates stays the same, it's done nothing, you've got the benefit on the short-term portion of the portfolio but very little else. The benefit we are getting right now, and I -- the reason why I caution about, including any interest rate benefit in models yet, is that the securities that we invest in intermediate term municipals have gone up pretty significantly since the elections. So our reinvestment rate is higher than it is right now. So if all we got was a 3.5 basis point -- I'm sorry, a 25 basis point increase in the Fed funds rate, you can expect that we've got, roughly, what we say we got. But we're also getting a bit of a benefit on the long-term portion of the portfolio. And what I don't know now and I'll have a better sense is that the Fed keeps raising interest rates. What's happening to the shape of that yield curve as I go out over the maturities that we have to reinvest. So right now, if everything held by be about, on an annualized basis, about $8 million higher. What it will end up being, I don't know until I get to the spring and I can digest the other Fed rate increases.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that does makes sense. I guess, Efrain, will you invest a little bit differently considering that Fed might do a couple of more rate increases? So will the philosophy change at all? Or will you still continue to manage the portfolio like you have?
componenttext: Okay, that does makes sense. I guess, Efrain, will you invest a little bit differently considering that Fed might do a couple of more rate increases? So will the philosophy change at all? Or will you still continue to manage the portfolio like you have?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a discussion that we're going to have as we get into the spring. Because if the shape of the yield curve is steeper on the long end, then maybe I have less short-term cash than I have more long. I haven't made that decision, or we haven't had that
componenttext: That is a discussion that we're going to have as we get into the spring. Because if the shape of the yield curve is steeper on the long end, then maybe I have less short-term cash than I have more long. I haven't made that decision, or we haven't had that discussion yet. We've had some preliminary conversations about how we would do that. But obviously, that would be one way to get higher yield even when I talking about on the portfolio, those are decisions that we need to look at when we get into the spring. Obviously, competitors leverage 100%. We've never -- we've chosen not to do that. But between where we are and where other people in the market are, there's room to move if we choose to do so.

componenttext: Yes, up 2% or 3% from a headcount perspective and fully staffed. And I think, just getting out those reps up to speed, but we're up about 2% or 3% which is fairly normal for us and it's kind of across both small and mid-market.

componenttext: And where do you stand in terms of salespeople and attrition today compared to what it has been in the past?

componenttext: Yes, very consistent. It's -- some are better than others. Actually, some of the mid-market tends to be a little bit better than it has been historically, even. And core payroll tends to be very consistent with where it's been. No big uptick in turnover or anything.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last question, Marty. Have you moved over to Flex and obviously the transition seems to be going well. Have you seen an impact on cross sales because of the customers moving to Flex even with more or less in terms of product sales?
componenttext: Okay. And just one last question, Marty. Have you moved over to Flex and obviously the transition seems to be going well. Have you seen an impact on cross sales because of the customers moving to Flex even with more or less in terms of product sales?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, obviously, from a Flex standpoint, you've got a better integration there and we built everything to integrate into that and then continued to roll things out with Flex or certainly seemed better pick up from a penetration. I wouldn't say it's h
componenttext: Yes, well, obviously, from a Flex standpoint, you've got a better integration there and we built everything to integrate into that and then continued to roll things out with Flex or certainly seemed better pick up from a penetration. I wouldn't say it's huge. But it certainly is a bigger pick up in penetration when you're selling the Flex platform because everything is built around that. So -- and we still have a lot of room to grow there. So when you think of the HR Analytics that we just rolled out kind of in HR Tech and some of the other products like this rolling out Flex Essentials which is that kind of lower end time and attendance solution without clocks, all of that is around Flex. So we expect to have better penetration growth because of the Flex platform and the more when we roll it out to clients.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mr. Tim McHugh with William Blair.
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Tim McHugh with William Blair.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to ask, digging back onto the comment about seeing, I guess, a trend towards a smaller average client size. You've talked a little bit about various parts of this. But just to be clear, are you seeing, I guess, slower growth in the middle market
componenttext: Just want to ask, digging back onto the comment about seeing, I guess, a trend towards a smaller average client size. You've talked a little bit about various parts of this. But just to be clear, are you seeing, I guess, slower growth in the middle market and that's why the average is skewing down or faster growth in small? Or I guess, can you peel back for us why the average is trending smaller than it was in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say this, Tim, that right now, the relative growth between small is tipping a little bit more toward small versus mid. And last year, it was tending a little bit more -- trending a little bit more mid-than small. So I think that's what it is. Look, I
componenttext: I'd say this, Tim, that right now, the relative growth between small is tipping a little bit more toward small versus mid. And last year, it was tending a little bit more -- trending a little bit more mid-than small. So I think that's what it is. Look, I could also talk about losses and sales. But when you net it all out, that's basically what you're seeing. And by the way, I just want to make it clear. Our average client size has been 17 for the last 10 years. It's not a dramatic difference. By the 10th year, 15 basis points there does make a difference.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, not a huge change. But as Efrain said, it makes a difference. But I think at that point we made earlier, both Efrain and I, I think, last quarter, Tim, what we saw was there was more movement in the mid-market because of Affordable Care Act and the n
componenttext: Yes, not a huge change. But as Efrain said, it makes a difference. But I think at that point we made earlier, both Efrain and I, I think, last quarter, Tim, what we saw was there was more movement in the mid-market because of Affordable Care Act and the need, that got people to change and sell more. This one has been, compared to last quarter, that need has kind of been satisfied by those who have it. And while we're holding certainly the clients we have with Affordable Care Act products, we're not seeing the interest in saying, okay, I want to change because I had to have something in place. So we saw a little bit of a shift second quarter over second quarter. And again, it's not a huge number but it did drop the average size a little bit.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay, so it's fair. It seems that middle market comp issue probably isn't growing as fast? Is small necessarily growing faster? Or is it just it's growing at the same rate and you're not seeing quite as much growth in mid-market and saw that averages -- that brings the average down?

componenttext: It is growing faster [indiscernible] middle market. I would say it's quite comparable to where we were a year or so ago.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, our federal tax rate is about 33%. And we obviously pay pretty close to the statutory rate. A -- it depends on whose estimate you're looking at. If you're down 20% -- to a 20% corporate tax rate, we are significant beneficiary. But even a 5 to 10 point decrease would create significant benefits for us.

componenttext: Just a few clarifications on previous commentary. But maybe Marty, going back to the sales activity, sort of honing in on your comment a little bit more inactivity or less slower [indiscernible] buying decisions and switching. Is that kind of how you're contemplating the upcoming obviously key selling season? Meaning that the factor is that the new administration, we're not going to know what the new rules are and whatever they may do is not going to be known really until the end of the selling season. So are you sort of preparing for a difficult selling season?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't say it is difficult. I will just say this was compared really to last year, we saw more activity. So we're -- I mean, we're expecting a pretty good selling season. But it was certainly a little bit slower in Q2 than it was last year. Even
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't say it is difficult. I will just say this was compared really to last year, we saw more activity. So we're -- I mean, we're expecting a pretty good selling season. But it was certainly a little bit slower in Q2 than it was last year. Even those things are known, I think it's just -- it's -- last year, we had a lot of sales. We had more mid-market sales in the second quarter because they had to get -- they had to make some change to get the Affordable Care Act product. By this point, they had -- most of those had bought it in November when you think about last year because they had to get in and actually, many of us stopped selling it after November because we had to get them taking [indiscernible] for the calendar year. So I wouldn't say we're expecting a difficult sales season. But there may be a little bit more inactivity than we saw last year. But I would expect most of that was in Q2 of last year.

componenttext: And Efrain, on the buyback, I think it's pretty clear, but the uptick in the buyback, the 2.9 million shares this quarter, we shouldn't be thinking any change in your buyback mentality, that's for sure, more just to get the share count closer to where it was a year ago is kind of what I was hearing?

componenttext: Yes, that's my point. That's where we're at.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And then just the next one, Marty, you did mention about the regulatory changes, how you do see those is a benefit for the business overall. I guess if you can just talk about the components of your business and where you saw the most, from client
componenttext: Thanks. And then just the next one, Marty, you did mention about the regulatory changes, how you do see those is a benefit for the business overall. I guess if you can just talk about the components of your business and where you saw the most, from client perspective, where did more on the regulatory driven work. I mean, did it drive more people to do PEO or ASO? Did it drive more bundles? Was there any sort of split within the business on sort of the regulatory pressure? And what it drove your clients to do? Thank you.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I think first, I think I'd say over time, the Overtime Rules that have now, of course, been postponed at least temporarily, that drove certainly a lot more interest from clients in time and attendance solution. So that's been helpful to get in
componenttext: Yes, sure. I think first, I think I'd say over time, the Overtime Rules that have now, of course, been postponed at least temporarily, that drove certainly a lot more interest from clients in time and attendance solution. So that's been helpful to get in front of clients and offer them. A great timing for us in the product suite that we have. So that drove a lot of interest and, frankly, still is, I think, it kind of geared up a lot of interest that whether the Overtime Rule is going to affect or not, I think it's going to be a plus for us. From -- when you start talking about Overtime Rules, that also drags in HR. So whether it was ASO or PEO, that brought a lot of interest in HR support. So companies that would have said, hey, going to continue  to try to deal with the HR myself internally, now said, jeez, I think with all these Overtime Rules, who's exempt, who isn't? A lot more discussion about moving people to exempt or not based on the Overtime Rules brought in some HR sales as well, both in the ASO and PEO platform. And then I think a little bit probably of a drag might have been the fact that, okay, now the Affordable Care Act, as we've said, is up in the air, but what's going to happen? Maybe I don't rush the buy as much from an insurance or a PEO side do I need it or not. So I think those were kind of the major changes. I think right now, what we expect is less regulation based on the platforms of the Trump administration. But I think there's still going to be enough change that those things will still help us. And in fact, just a level of change makes people worry about can they keep up with everything, if the tax rates change, if the rules change on maybe when to file, if overtime is in or out, then all drives people to say, I can't keep up with that, I'm going to turn it over to an outsourcer like Paychex who has over 200 people who just track compliance and realize what has to happen and so forth. I think those have been the plusses and the minuses.

componenttext: No, because -- the first part of the statement, David, is correct. So no, in the back half of the year, you see, if you -- our financials, the margin actually goes down and that's typical of our pattern.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. First of all, with regards to, just the general environment that you're seeing in the small business arena. What are you seeing in terms of new business startups in terms of trickling up from the field, source of new clients?
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. First of all, with regards to, just the general environment that you're seeing in the small business arena. What are you seeing in terms of new business startups in terms of trickling up from the field, source of new clients? And then what are you seeing in terms of bankruptcies? And how that seems to be trending?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On new business starts, I think, they've kind of reached back to that level that they were kind of pre-recession, we've seen that now for probably a year. And I think they've kind of held everything that we've seen we said. They're not growing tremendousl
componenttext: On new business starts, I think, they've kind of reached back to that level that they were kind of pre-recession, we've seen that now for probably a year. And I think they've kind of held everything that we've seen we said. They're not growing tremendously more than that but they're kind of right in that place where they were. Bankruptcies, generally pretty consistent with where they've been, maybe up a little. At least what we've seen, what we see is from our losses, to [ph] bankruptcies and out of business. And that's ticked up slightly. But again, our overall retention is very consistent with where it's been at pretty record high levels, pretty consistent in that range. So no big change there. But a little bit tick up in the bankruptcies, which is interesting, it doesn't seem like that should happen. But we've seen a few more losses because of that, nothing that would change our overall number.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with regards to -- you've had great improvement with regards to the Flex as it relates to the smaller end of the market. From a technology perspective, can you lay out any additional improvements that we should expect out of the 50 to 1,000
componenttext: Okay. And then with regards to -- you've had great improvement with regards to the Flex as it relates to the smaller end of the market. From a technology perspective, can you lay out any additional improvements that we should expect out of the 50 to 1,000 range in terms of what you're offering there?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, for the 50 to 1,000. Well, I think you'll continue to see that level of integration and I think you will see continued pressure on a few things. One is the analytics piece that we just talked about at HR Tech, much more on the analytics both on kind
componenttext: Okay, for the 50 to 1,000. Well, I think you'll continue to see that level of integration and I think you will see continued pressure on a few things. One is the analytics piece that we just talked about at HR Tech, much more on the analytics both on kind of in the way we report the data and in the flexibility that the client has. The other will be continue to be a mobile-first design and we're seeing a good uptick in mobile usage. As I mentioned before, not only decline. But from the employee standpoint. So we're spending a lot of time kind of adjusting our language in our display much more now, pretty much 99% -- over 99% of the display is HTML5. So it's a much cleaner and easier use for the client, much more flexible for the client and the employees on mobile use. But we've still got long ways to go on mobile adoption. So getting the client and our employees to download the app and use it. It is growing fast but we still got a long ways to go. And I think that's going to be a big part of assisting in the value of our products and services. The full suite is there and we're constantly adding to it, like affect the new Flex Essentials, Flex Time Essentials and you'll see a lot more paperless. So everything pretty much can be paperless today, right, even PEO onboarding now is all paperless function. So I think you'll continue to see us add to the functionality. And even in time and attendance, we are adding new modules all the time. So a budgeting module, we just where you'll be able to track your time to your budget and so forth. So you're going to continue to see, not only the products expand, but the modules within each kind of distinct products.

componenttext: That's great. I mean, is there going to be a step function, Marty, in terms of -- by the end of calendar '17, we should see -- we did have some staff functions on the smaller side that were some real benchmarks that we ended up hitting. Do we see something similar to that coming up?

componenttext: Yes, I think so. Although it is much more gradual now. We -- a number of the clients are on Flex. I think, we certainly have internal goals as to where we want that penetration to be including mobile adoption so you'll see more marketing push, mobile adoption as you will see more direct, i.e. trying to get the employees of the clients and more marketing from that standpoint. So we don't really disclose it but we certainly internally have our steps that we want to get to our different goals by year for penetration of those products. And I think right now, we're on track, I think even ahead on time and attendance because of the overtime rules.

componenttext: I think so. Yes, I think we've seen that pretty consistent growth from a PEO standpoint and I think we feel very good about the carrier plans we are offering now and the work with the carriers. And so yes, I don't think that we'll necessarily slowdown. We've just seen that kind of inactivity a little bit of a slowness in making a change in some clients who already have it. But I think you'll see -- and even with more certification of things that are going on in that industry, I think you could see a pick up there. And there's no real change in competition. We haven't really seen any real change from the competitors from a PEO standpoint. If you had good place, great HR service and support and good carrier plans, insurance plans, we should continue to see good double-digit growth there.
