componenttext: I know it's late, just have a quick one. Efrain, you mentioned that if corporate tax rates go down, you think you'd be -- I think you used the words significant beneficiary. Can you just remind us right now roughly what your federal tax rate is?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our federal tax rate is about 33%. And we obviously pay pretty close to the statutory rate. A -- it depends on whose estimate you're looking at. If you're down in 20% -- to a 20% corporate tax rate, we are significant beneficiary. But even a 5- to 10
componenttext: Yes. Our federal tax rate is about 33%. And we obviously pay pretty close to the statutory rate. A -- it depends on whose estimate you're looking at. If you're down in 20% -- to a 20% corporate tax rate, we are significant beneficiary. But even a 5- to 10-point decrease would create significant benefits for us.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few clarifications on previous commentary. But maybe, Marty, going back to the sales activity, sort of just honing in on your comment a little bit more inactivity or less -- slower because it makes buying decisions and switching. Is that kind of ho
componenttext: Just a few clarifications on previous commentary. But maybe, Marty, going back to the sales activity, sort of just honing in on your comment a little bit more inactivity or less -- slower because it makes buying decisions and switching. Is that kind of how you're contemplating the upcoming, obviously, key selling season? Meaning the sector is -- that the new administration, we're not going to know what the new rules are and whatever they may do is not going to be known really until the end of the selling season? So are you sort of preparing for a difficult sales season?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't say it's difficult. I'll just say this was compared really to last year, so we saw more activity. So we're -- I mean, we're expecting a pretty good selling season. But it was certainly a little bit slower in Q2 than it was last year. Even
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't say it's difficult. I'll just say this was compared really to last year, so we saw more activity. So we're -- I mean, we're expecting a pretty good selling season. But it was certainly a little bit slower in Q2 than it was last year. Even though things are known, I think it's just -- it's -- last year, we had a lot of sales. We had more mid-market sales in the second quarter because they had to get -- they had to make some change to get the Affordable Care Act product. By this point, they had -- most of those had bought it by November when you think about last year because they had to get in. And actually, many of us stopped selling it after November because we had to get them taken care of for the calendar year. So I wouldn't say we're expecting a difficult sales season. But there may be a little bit more inactivity than we saw last year. But I would expect most of that was in Q2 of last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Efrain, on the buyback, I think it's pretty clear, but the uptick in the buyback, the 2.9 million shares this quarter, we shouldn't be thinking any change in your buyback mentality, that's for sure, more just to get the share count closer to where it
componenttext: And Efrain, on the buyback, I think it's pretty clear, but the uptick in the buyback, the 2.9 million shares this quarter, we shouldn't be thinking any change in your buyback mentality, that's for sure, more just to get the share count closer to where it was a year ago is kind of what I was hearing.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, Glenn. That's where we're at.
componenttext: Yes, that's right, Glenn. That's where we're at.

componenttext: And then just to clarify, on the ACA, obviously, a risk. And you sort of identified what the risk could be. But what's the order of magnitude? What percentage of revenue ACA is right now?

componenttext: So I think I was asked this last year. So I'm going to call it direct ACA revenue is in a little bit above 1% -- between 1% and 1.5% of revenue.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one clarifier from the release and your comments. I mentioned -- I noticed you didn't mention anything about the operating income excluding float. Have you changed how you're thinking about operating margin and operating income here?
componenttext: Just a quick one clarifier from the release and your comments. I mentioned -- I noticed you didn't mention anything about the operating income excluding float. Have you changed how you're thinking about operating margin and operating income here?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. I mean, I think you can basically do much of the math yourselves. And because float is no longer a drag, it's probably more useful to just look at it in totality.
componenttext: Not really. I mean, I think you can basically do much of the math yourselves. And because float is no longer a drag, it's probably more useful to just look at it in totality.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just the next one, Marty, you did mention about the regulatory changes, how you do see that it would benefit for the business overall. I guess, if you could just talk about the components of your business and where you saw the most -- from client
componenttext: And then just the next one, Marty, you did mention about the regulatory changes, how you do see that it would benefit for the business overall. I guess, if you could just talk about the components of your business and where you saw the most -- from client perspective, where they did more on the regulatory driven work. I mean, did it drive more people to do PEO or ASO? Did it drive more bundles? Was there any sort of split within the business on sort of the regulatory pressure and what it drove clients to do?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I think, first, and I think I'd say overtime -- the overtime rules that have now, of course, been postponed, at least temporarily, that drove certainly a lot more interest from clients in time and attendance solution. So that's been helpful to
componenttext: Yes, sure. I think, first, and I think I'd say overtime -- the overtime rules that have now, of course, been postponed, at least temporarily, that drove certainly a lot more interest from clients in time and attendance solution. So that's been helpful to get in front of clients and offer them great timing for us in the product suite that we have. So that drove a lot of interest and frankly, still is. I think it kind of geared up a lot of interest that whether the overtime rules go into effect or not, I think it's going to be a plus for us. From -- when you start talking about overtime rules, that also drags in HR. So whether it was ASO or PEO, that brought a lot of interest in HR support. So companies that would have said, "Hey, I'm going to continue to try to deal with the HR myself internally," now said, "Jeez, I think with all these overtime rules, who is exempt, who isn't?" A lot more discussion about moving people to exempt or not based on the overtime rules brought in some HR sales as well, both in the ASO and PEO platform. And then I think a little bit probably of a drag might have been the fact that, "Okay, now the Affordable Care Act, as we've said, is up in the air, but what's going to happen? Maybe I don't rush to buy as much from an insurance or a PEO side? Do I need it or not?" So I think those were kind of the major changes. I think right now, what we expect is less regulation based on the platforms of the Trump administration. But I think there's still going to be enough change that those things will still help us. And in fact, just the level of change makes people worry about -- can they keep up with everything? If the tax rates change, if the rules change on maybe when to file, if overtime is in or out, that all drives people to say, "Okay, I can't keep up with that. I'm going to turn it over to an outsourcer like Paychex who has over 200 people who just track compliance and realize what has to happen and so forth." So I think those have been the pluses and minuses.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: SurePayroll is part of the equation. It's been part of the equation for the last 5 years, they continue to do well. So that's part of the mix of what we sell. So we sell through SurePayroll. We sell through, obviously, through our Paychex outsource service and we also sell mid-market. So that's part of the mix.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. On new business startups, I think they've kind of reached back to that level and -- that they were kind of pre-recession. We've seen that now for probably a year. But again, our overall retention is very consistent with where it's been at pretty record high levels, pretty consistent in that range. So no big change there. But a little bit tick up in the bankruptcies, which is interesting. It doesn't seem like that should happen. componenttext: Oh, okay. For the 50 to -- I think -- well, I think you'll continue to see that level of integration and you'll see a big continued push on a few things. One is the analytics piece that we just talked about at HR Tech, much more on the analytics, both kind of in the way we report the data and in the flexibility the client has. The other will be continue to be a mobile-first design, and we're seeing a good uptick in mobile usage, as I have mentioned before, not only the client, but from the employee standpoint. So we're spending a lot of time kind of adjusting our language in our display much more now. Pretty much 99% -- over 99% of the display is HTML5, so it's a much cleaner and easier use for the client, much more flexible for the client and the employees on mobile use. But we've still got a long ways to go on mobile adoption. So getting the client and our employees to download the app and use it, it's growing fast, but we still got a long ways to go. And I think that's going to be a big part of assisting in the value of our products and services. The full suite is there and we're constantly adding to it, like the new Flex Essentials, Flex Time Essentials, and you'll see a lot more paperless. So everything pretty much can be paperless today, right? Even PEO onboarding now is all paperless function. So I think you'll continue to see us add to the functionality. And even in time and attendance, we're adding new modules all the time. So a budgeting module, we just added where you'll be able to track your time to your budget and so forth. So you're going to continue to see not only the products expand, but the modules within each kind of distinct product.
