headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you and thank you for joining us on our discussion of Paychex Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results
componenttext:
All right. Thank you and thank you for joining us on our discussion of Paychex Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Release. Joining me is Efrain Rivera, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, before the market opened, we released our financial results for the second quarter ended November 30, 2016. Our Form 10-Q will be filed with the SEC within the next few days. You can access our earnings release and Form 10-Q on our Investor Relations web page. This teleconference is being broadcast over the Internet and will be archived and available on our website for approximately 1 month. 
On today's call, I will update you on the results of our business in the second quarter, and Efrain will review our financial results in more detail and discuss our full year guidance. After that, we'll open it up for your questions. 
Our results for the second quarter reflected good progress. We continue to see positive results across our major product lines. And service revenue for the second quarter grew by 7% year-over-year. We achieved a new milestone this quarter as we attained 1 million client worksite employees served by our Paychex HR Services. Paychex HR Services is our comprehensive outsourcing services product line, and that includes our ASO, or administrative services organization, and our PEO, or professional employer organization as well. Our cloud-based HCM services, in particular, time and attendance, continued to show strong growth in the quarter. 
Tomorrow is the 1-year anniversary of the acquisition of Advance Partners. Advance has been an excellent addition to the Paychex family. We're very pleased with the leadership and the team's contribution to our financial results and the future opportunities for growth we see in that business, particularly timely as the staffing business is picking up some expanded growth today. 
With the success of our HCM solutions, we have continued to invest in operations personnel as we've expanded our multiproduct service centers, including our time and attendance support and our ACA product compliance and service teams. Client retention remains at consistent high levels. We have also invested in our service and our sales organization over the last year, adding headcount across all sales teams. And we are well-positioned going into our third quarter. We will have a better idea of overall sales performance and the impact of the fiscal year next quarter after the end of our peak sales season. 
We continue to make it a priority to provide robust HCM solutions that meet the evolving needs of our client base. At the recent HR Technology Conference and Exposition in October, we showcased enhancements to Paychex Flex that address 2 of the biggest trends in the HR industry: mobile user experience and the HR analytics. Attendees at the conference were able to view a demo of Paychex Flex which included these enhancements. 
We also announced that we shifted to a mobile-first design of our HCM suite. This approach allows Paychex Flex users to have full functionality of all application components regardless of device or screen size. The growing trend for both HR leaders and employees is the use of a mobile device. Shifting to a mobile-first design demonstrates our commitment to putting the needs of our clients and their employees first so that they can accomplish their HR tasks where they want, when they want and on whatever device they want. 
We continue to receive positive recognition of our Flex platform. In November, we were honored to be recognized as a leader in the 2016 NelsonHall Payroll Outsourcing NEAT, a component of the firm's speed-to source initiative. NEAT stands for NelsonHall's Evaluation and Assessment Tool, and is a vendor evaluation report tool that can be utilized by managers to evaluate outsourcing vendors. 
This was the first time we had participated in this initiative, and we were placed in the Leader quadrant for 3 areas: technology and user experience, analytics and reporting, and HR cloud integration. The client feedback that goes into this ranking makes our center even more important to us and reinforces our commitment to delivering the best and most robust solutions in the market today with our Paychex Flex platform. 
This has been a transition period in the U.S. with the presidential election and the move to the Trump administration. We have been asked a few times how we anticipate the new administration will impact the economy overall and, more specifically, the payroll and human capital management outsourcing industry. In this transition time, many business owners could be hesitant to make longer-term decisions. We see this as being more likely to impact the mid to large-sized businesses, rather than small businesses. President-elect Trump has indicated that he intends to lower taxes and create less regulation. This would be a positive for small businesses. It would lower the cost and allow them to invest and hire more. Paychex would benefit as our clients expand and add employees and potentially see value in our HCM services. 
While complex regulations tend to drive companies to an outsourcing solution, we believe any change in regulation is good for Paychex. We remain informed about what is happening in the regulatory environment and are well positioned to continue to educate our clients and assist them with their compliance needs through our technology and service support. 
Over the last year, the Affordable Care Act has been a tailwind for payroll outsourcing companies, including ourselves. Any rollback of Obamacare or Affordable Care Act or reduction in compliance and administration requirements will impact the HCM outsourcing industry. Given our target market of small to medium-sized businesses, a large portion of our client base is not -- has not impact -- been impacted by ACA. In November, a federal court issued a preliminary injunction to temporarily block the Department of Labor's final Overtime Rule that would have become effective December 1. This rule would expand overtime for millions of workers. As a result of this injunction, employers did not have to be in compliance with the new rules as of December 1. The ruling is temporary but creates substantial uncertainty for businesses. The proposed rules created an enhanced awareness for the need for time and attendance solutions, particularly to those integrated within their -- with the clients' HCM product suite. This brought an increased demand for our products that we don't see diminishing with the delay in the rules. We will continue to monitor the status of these regulations and ensure our clients remain informed as to how any changes may affect them. 
Shifting the discussion from clients to shareholders. We continued with shareholder-friendly actions. During the second quarter, we repurchased 2.9 million shares for a total of $166 million. And we will continue to maintain an industry-leading dividend yield of over 3% with a quarterly dividend of $0.46 per share. 
In summary, we have made solid progress and growth in our financial performance during the past quarter, and I appreciate the great work of our Paychex employees and management team. And I will now turn the call over to Efrain to review our financial results in more detail. Efrain?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events. And as such, involve risk. Refer to the customary disclosures. As Marty indicated, second quarter financial resul
componenttext:
Good morning. I'd like to remind everyone that today's conference call will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events. And as such, involve risk. Refer to the customary disclosures. 
As Marty indicated, second quarter financial results for fiscal 2017 showed continued progress and growth. I'll cover some of the key highlights for the second quarter and the 6 months, provide greater detail on certain areas and wrap with a review of the 2017 outlook. 
Total service revenue grew 7% for the second quarter to $760 million and 8% for the 6 months to $1.5 billion. Interest on funds held for clients increased 2% for the second quarter and 6% for the 6 months to $11 million and $23 million, respectively. These changes were primarily driven by slightly higher average interest rates earned. The growth was tempered by a slight decrease in the average investment balances by approximately 1% for both periods. This is really a timing issue that we call out in the press release. 
Expenses increased 8% for both the second quarter and 6 months, with Advance Partners contributing approximately 1.5% to this growth for both periods. Expense growth was impacted by higher wages and related expenses due to growth in headcount in our operations area. 
Selling expenses have shown modest growth, reflecting strong sales performance in the year-ago quarter. Our operating margin was approximately 40.3% for the second quarter and 40.7% year-to-date comparable with the prior year periods. We continue to maintain industry-leading margins while investing in our operations. 
Our effective income tax rate was 35.2% for the second quarter and 34.1% for the 6 months, compared to 36% and 32.9% for the respective periods last year. As we discussed on our last quarterly call, we had several discrete items, tax items, in the first quarter of both years that have impacted the year-to-date effective income tax rates. In fiscal 2017, we implemented new accounting guidance related to employee stock-based compensation, which has resulted in discrete tax benefits now being recognized upon exercise or lapse of stock-based awards. The impact with this in the second quarter was immaterial but had a larger impact in the first quarter. Last year, in the first quarter of fiscal 2016, we recognized a net tax benefit on income from prior tax years related to customer-facing software we produce. Because there have been ins and outs, refer to the press release and you'll see we provide a non-GAAP EBITDA comparison -- I should say, non-GAAP EPS comparison with and without these items. 
Net income increased 7% to $202 million for the second quarter and 5% to $420 million for the 6 months. Diluted earnings per share increased 8% to $0.56 per share for the second quarter and 5% to $1.16 per share for the 6 months. On a non-GAAP basis, as I mentioned just a second ago, adjusted net income increased 6% to $201 million for the second quarter and 7% to $405 million for the 6 months. Adjusted diluted earnings per share increased 8% to $0.56 per share for the second quarter and 8% to $1.12 per share for the 6 months. Note that these 2 non-GAAP measures exclude certain discrete tax items previously discussed. Refer to the table if you have any questions about that. 
Payroll service revenue increased 3% for the second quarter to $441 million and 4% to $892 million for the 6 months. Advance Partners contributed 1% to the growth in payroll service revenue for both the quarter and year-to-date periods. We benefited from increases in client-based and revenue per check. Revenue per check grew as a result of price increases net of discounting. 
Payroll client size impacted revenue as average client size trended modestly lower. We discussed that in the first quarter. We saw a continuation of that trend in the second quarter. 
While we continue to present payroll service revenue and HRS revenue, I want to emphasize one important point: With the evolving nature of our businesses to an HCM provider, we now offer more product bundles that are bundled with payroll. Revenue from these bundles is allocated among payroll and HRS. The payroll growth remains steady, but HRS growth reflects the sale of more services to clients and greater revenue per client. And I call out specifically that we had another strong quarter in time and attendance sales. 
HRS revenue increased 12% to $319 million for the second quarter, 14% to $642 million for the 6 months. This increase reflects continued growth across our client base and all HCM services, including our comprehensive HR outsourcing services, retirement services, time and attendance and HR administration. 
Within Paychex HR Services, we've continued to see strong demand, which is reflected in the double-digit year-over-year growth and the number of client worksite employees served. Insurance services benefited from continued growth in revenue from our ESR services as well as growth in the number of health and benefit applicants. Our workers' comp insurance product benefited from higher average premiums and client base growth. Retirement services revenue reflected an increase in asset fee revenue earned on the value of participant funds as well as an increase in the number of plans served. Last, Advance Partners contributed a little bit less than 2% to the growth in HRS revenue for both the second quarter and the 6 months. 
Investments and income. Turning to our portfolio. Our goal is, as you know, to protect principal and optimize liquidity. On the short-term side, primary short-term vehicles remain bank demand deposit accounts and variable-rate demand notes. In our longer-term portfolio, we invest primarily in high credit-quality municipal bonds, some corporate bonds and U.S. government securities. Long-term portfolio has -- now has an average yield of 1.7% and average duration of 3.3 years. 
Our combined portfolios have earned an average rate of return of 1.2% for the second quarter and 6 months, up from 1.1% last year. Average investment balances for funds held for clients decreased by approximately 1% year-over-year as the impact from growth in client base was offset by timing of certain remittances to taxing authorities. We expect that in the second half of the year, that will change and we'll -- we expect client base -- client growth -- client funds growth, I should say, sorry, to grow about 1%. 
I'll now walk you through highlights of our financial position. It remains strong with cash and total corporate investments of $725 million as of the end of the quarter. Funds held for clients as of November 30 were $3.2 billion compared to $4 billion as of May 31. Funds held for clients vary widely, as you know, and may average $3.7 billion for both the quarter and the 6 months. 
Total available-for-sale investments, including corporate investments and funds held for clients, reflected net unrealized losses of $16 million as of November 30 compared with a net unrealized gain of $48 million as of May 31. Recently, interest rates for intermediate term investors -- investments, I should say, have rallied, resulting in a decrease in the market value of our portfolio. 
Total stockholder's equity was $1.8 billion as of November 30, 2016, reflecting $331 million in dividends and $166 million of repurchases of Paychex common stock. Our return on equity for the past 12 months was 40%. 
Cash flows from operations were $413 million for the first 6 months, a decrease of 2% from the prior year. This decrease was a result of fluctuations in working capital offset by higher net income and noncash adjustments. 
Now let me turn to guidance. We remind you that the outlook is based in our current view of economic and interest rate conditions. And what I mean by that is we do factor in the recent Fed rate raise, but we don't factor in any continuing raises beyond that. We'll update as we see those. We obviously expect that there will be some, but they're not baked into this guidance. 
Payroll service revenue growth is anticipated to be in the range of 3% to 4%. We anticipate payroll revenue growth in the third quarter will be below the range of full year guidance. As we discussed on last quarter's call, we now expect that it will be approximately 2%. Remember that the third quarter is impacted by 1 less processing day. 
HRS revenue growth is anticipated to remain in the range of 12% to 14%. Total service revenue is anticipated to remain in the range of 7% to 8%. Interest on funds held for clients is anticipated to grow in the upper single digits. The impact of the recent increase in short-term rates will be modest but would be more accretive as we enter into 2018. 
Operating margins are anticipated to be consistent with the guidance previously provided. Effective tax rate for the year is expected to be approximately 35%. GAAP basis, net income growth is expected to be approximately 7%. We said that last quarter. Adjusted net income, which is a non-GAAP measure that excludes certain discrete tax items, is anticipated to grow approximately 8%, consistent with the guidance that we gave in June. 
Turn it back to Marty.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Efrain. We'll now open the call to questions. Operator?
componenttext: Thank you, Efrain. We'll now open the call to questions. Operator?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first one is from Mr. Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first one is from Mr. Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to start with a question on the core payroll segment. I'm just trying to do the math here on the back of the more precise outlook on Q3 at the 2% level. I mean, I guess, to get to the midpoint of the full year at 3% to 4% range, it seems like
componenttext: I just want to start with a question on the core payroll segment. I'm just trying to do the math here on the back of the more precise outlook on Q3 at the 2% level. I mean, I guess, to get to the midpoint of the full year at 3% to 4% range, it seems like you'd have to be about 4.5% growth in Q4. So just so we've got our models aligned properly, I mean, should we be thinking about the lower end, 3% to 4% more particularly? Or are there some real accelerators in Q4? I know you're not going to have the benefit of Advance anymore, but I don't think you're disadvantaged in terms of processing days either there.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason. I think to call it precisely is a little bit tough because we need to get through selling. But I think at this point, we'd anticipate we're towards the lower end of that range.
componenttext: Yes, Jason. I think to call it precisely is a little bit tough because we need to get through selling. But I think at this point, we'd anticipate we're towards the lower end of that range.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. Understood. And then just wanted to check on pricing as well. That's an area of continued -- always get questions on. I know you talked about there being some lift from pricing. If it is still in that historical 2% to 4% range, I guess th
componenttext: Okay, all right. Understood. And then just wanted to check on pricing as well. That's an area of continued -- always get questions on. I know you talked about there being some lift from pricing. If it is still in that historical 2% to 4% range, I guess that would imply that on an organic basis, that volumes in core payroll were kind of flat to down. Are we thinking about that right? Is 2% to 4% still the right range that you're seeing on price?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me talk about that. So yes, it is 2% to 4%. This year, it's probably closer to the lower end. We've been trending somewhere between the low and the mid part of that range. So we still are getting price. We still are getting volume. So our clie
componenttext: Yes, so let me talk about that. So yes, it is 2% to 4%. This year, it's probably closer to the lower end. We've been trending somewhere between the low and the mid part of that range. So we still are getting price. We still are getting volume. So our client base is up over last year, and we've said we'd be between 1% to 3%. Last year, we were at 2%. We're in that range. So what accounts for the difference? It is accounted for by the fact that our client -- average client size is a little bit smaller. So to put this in context, if you go back 10 years, go back to 2007, our average client size is 17. But some years, it's 17.1. Last year we ended at 16.73. And at this point, we are trending slightly down from that number. And so that the effect of that mix is basically taking payroll service revenue down. This happens from time to time. It happens more when 2 things are present: The first is that we start to see a flattening in checks per payroll, which is what we've been seeing over the last 3 to 4 quarters. Actually, this quarter, our checks per payroll went negative. So what that means is that -- and by the way, that's on a same-store basis, so I want to clarify that. What that means is that, particularly our clients in the under-50 space simply aren't adding a lot of employees at this stage. Will that continue? We'll see. It's been bouncing around quarter-to-quarter. And if you look at our index that we publish each month, you'll see that reflected in the numbers. But that's part a. And then part b is that as we sell clients that are a little bit lower than those that we lose, we have this drag effect. In most years, that basically is offset by some client checks per payroll growth. This is a year where we're not seeing that. So we're monitoring that and saw some of it in Q1, and we'll see if it continues into Q2. It can bounce around. I would just caution not to assume that that's exactly what you're going to see through the balance of the year. But we're assuming at this point some drag in checks per payroll as we go through the year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not -- just to add to that a little bit. We're not -- when you look at last year, second quarter, there was kind of a push because of the Affordable Care Act, particularly in the mid-market clients. And to get in and buy those services and ther
componenttext: Yes, we're not -- just to add to that a little bit. We're not -- when you look at last year, second quarter, there was kind of a push because of the Affordable Care Act, particularly in the mid-market clients. And to get in and buy those services and therefore, it got you in the door a lot more for sales and that kind of ticked up the size of the average client because we sold a little bit more in the mid-market. So it's an interesting time with the election to see how much the Affordable Care Act last year versus this year had an impact. And because we sold those clients pretty much who needed it. Now the retention has been very strong on that product even with the uncertainty. But that was higher last year. It got you in the door a lot more in the mid-market because they were interested in not only the Affordable Care Act but how you integrated with the payroll services. And so that may have been an impact. And then as Efrain mentioned, on our Small Business Index, we've seen a flattening out of hiring in the small business sector, the under-50 employees sector, and for a couple of months now. And that could be around the election or not. So it's kind of an interesting quarter because of the election and the possible changes coming up as well.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and -- that's helpful. Just one last one for me. I think in the quarter, you bought back more than twice as many shares as you had bought all of last fiscal year. So wanted to get a sense of whether that's indicative of any change in the M&A pipelin
componenttext: Okay, and -- that's helpful. Just one last one for me. I think in the quarter, you bought back more than twice as many shares as you had bought all of last fiscal year. So wanted to get a sense of whether that's indicative of any change in the M&A pipeline in terms of the prospects there, either in terms of size of the prospects or potential timing on the prospects.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the short answer is no. The share repurchase itself was really simply an attempt to get back down to average share count. And if you look at it, we actually are still a bit high compared to where we were last year. So we'll do a little bit of -- o
componenttext: Yes. So the short answer is no. The share repurchase itself was really simply an attempt to get back down to average share count. And if you look at it, we actually are still a bit high compared to where we were last year. So we'll do a little bit of -- on a year-to-date basis, we'll do a little bit more buying just to get back to flat. Now actually, Marty can talk a little bit more about the M&A pipeline. But it's pretty robust.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, still pretty active. Not always finding exactly what we want, but it's -- I don't think it's ever been probably more active from a pipeline standpoint. It's just whether you get to the final deal or not based on the value and what we find in diligenc
componenttext: Yes, still pretty active. Not always finding exactly what we want, but it's -- I don't think it's ever been probably more active from a pipeline standpoint. It's just whether you get to the final deal or not based on the value and what we find in diligence. But been very active on that front and hasn't slowed down at all.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from James Berkley with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from James Berkley with Barclays.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to get a better handle on how to think about revenue growth for '17. I know you touched on a little bit on the payroll side just now. But through the first half of the year, you're near the high end of your guided ranges on payroll and HRS growt
componenttext: Just want to get a better handle on how to think about revenue growth for '17. I know you touched on a little bit on the payroll side just now. But through the first half of the year, you're near the high end of your guided ranges on payroll and HRS growth. But this quarter, did see the low end of those ranges. You've got Advance Partners lapping 1 less day in fiscal third quarter. Questions around the Affordable Care Act and time and attendance given the delay with the Department of Labor. Just how do we think about all those moving parts in the back half of the year in particular? And what are you thinking about the ACA and time and attendance, the aspect -- that aspect post Trump versus previously?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Wow, that's a really compound question. So I'd say, let me just say broadly and then I'll come back to ACA and other regulatory changes. Marty, obviously, will have some thoughts on that. But our guidance contemplates all of those issues obviously.
componenttext: Okay. Wow, that's a really compound question. So I'd say, let me just say broadly and then I'll come back to ACA and other regulatory changes. Marty, obviously, will have some thoughts on that. But our guidance contemplates all of those issues obviously. We just answered a question on payroll services, revenue growth. HRS has remained unchanged. So from that standpoint, we feel comfortable with where we are for the remainder of the year. And for the full year, we don't focus necessarily on quarters unless there's something unusual in the quarter that we want to call out like Q3, which has one less day. Feel comfortable about where we are in terms of margins and expenses. So that outlook that we're providing basically encompasses what we understand the environment to be. Don't anticipate it will change significantly. Now with respect to ACA and with respect to other changes in regulation, it's a little bit early to call those. The Overtime Rules change, at this point, don't see a lot of impact on the balance of the year. It could impact next year. And then on what exactly happens with ACA, that's a question to be answered at this point. What I would say is, if we were to see some sort of significant movement to repeal starting sometime in late spring, our anticipation of -- if that were to roll out over a, let's say, call it a 2- to 3-year period, is that we'd see about an impact of 1% on EPS per year. If it was more accelerated, it might be more. But we're still waiting -- that, by the way, is more of a worst-case scenario, 1% to 1.5% EPS. We think we have other options to replace that revenue. But at this point, we'd frame sort of the risk if the ACA got repealed in an orderly fashion. If it got replaced and repealed immediately, that would be a different conversation. We'll have to wait and see where we end up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the expectation, at least at this point, would be it's going to take some time. It's pretty complicated, as you know, and -- to change it. So -- and we're seeing very solid retention. Of course, clients are looking for us to file in March now
componenttext: Yes, I think the expectation, at least at this point, would be it's going to take some time. It's pretty complicated, as you know, and -- to change it. So -- and we're seeing very solid retention. Of course, clients are looking for us to file in March now for them and I don't think you're going to see much movement, at least through that filing period. And I think it's going to be a longer thing, which as Efrain mentioned, we're looking at, depending on what happens, a number of products. My guess is clients are still going to have to do something, and they're going to need some support for that. So we feel pretty good that we will be able to adapt to that. Might not make up all the revenue, but it certainly has some opportunity there. From a time and attendance, it's been interesting that we've had very strong sales of our time and attendance solutions. And we've introduced a new one, that is Flex Essentials. That is a no-clock, all-web or mobile punch, much simpler to set up, and we've seen an acceleration there. So I think the whole Overtime Rule issue, even though it's now been delayed and may end up never being enacted, who knows, has driven a lot of interest in time and attendance. And so that's driven sales that I don't think somebody's going to necessarily get rid of that product. And in fact, it may keep kind of a heightened demand now. So I think that's how we feel about it, as pretty good at this point and see what happens next.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That make a lot of sense. And thanks for the color on the ACA there. Those numbers are really helpful. Just one more quick follow-up here, more of a high-level question. Just correct me if I'm wrong. I believe about 10% of your company's revenue is
componenttext: Right. That make a lot of sense. And thanks for the color on the ACA there. Those numbers are really helpful. Just one more quick follow-up here, more of a high-level question. Just correct me if I'm wrong. I believe about 10% of your company's revenue is driven by the PEO business and another 10% from the ASO side. I think you got PEO growing more quickly over the last few years. Just curious if you could talk about how fast each is growing, the trends that you're seeing, or whether there's been an acceleration recently versus past quarters or past years and just going into more detail in each of those. And what's driving the gap between the 2 growth rates?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I -- what we've said about the HR outsourcing business is that it's about half of HRS revenue. And within that half, about half is PEO and half is ASO. So that's what we said, and we update that yearly. PEO's been growing more quickly than ASO, bu
componenttext: Yes. So I -- what we've said about the HR outsourcing business is that it's about half of HRS revenue. And within that half, about half is PEO and half is ASO. So that's what we said, and we update that yearly. PEO's been growing more quickly than ASO, but both have been growing double digits. I guess that's what we'd say. The only other thing I would add to that is that because the PEO -- we report health care attachment as part of the revenues of the PEO. When we get better health care attachment in the quarter, then you have better PEO growth. That really doesn't have much of an impact on margins in this quarter. We did not have as significant health care attachments we had in the quarter before, but that bounces around every single quarter. So Q3, we'll see where we end up.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we feel pretty good. Obviously reaching the new -- the milestone of over 1 million worksite employees that we're servicing between our service -- between the ASO and PEO. We feel good. We're very well positioned. There's been a lot of demand
componenttext: Yes, I think we feel pretty good. Obviously reaching the new -- the milestone of over 1 million worksite employees that we're servicing between our service -- between the ASO and PEO. We feel good. We're very well positioned. There's been a lot of demand for the HR support. And I think PEO, while it's been strong in certain states, and we sell it across pretty much all states, it is starting to -- it's continuing to pick up more demand, and we feel good about the future of it. As Efrain said, the attachment of the health can swing from kind of quarter-to-quarter or even month-to-month. But -- and again, I think it's going to be interesting to see kind of what comes out of it. Now you had a quarter where a lot of discussion about health care and you may have a number of clients deciding to kind of hold and wait and see what's going to happen. But we see good growth. We've been doing well in both PEO and ASO, well-positioned to have both products. So if you want co-employment, you have it. If you don't, we have the insurance agency that's a top agency and plenty of plans to offer. So feel good about both products right now.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from David Togut with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: The next question is from David Togut with Evercore ISI.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rayna Kumar for David Togut. In the first quarter, you really highlighted the strength in the mid-market, and that seems to have slowed down a bit in the second quarter. I guess what's changed there? And maybe if you can just highlight your expect
componenttext: This is Rayna Kumar for David Togut. In the first quarter, you really highlighted the strength in the mid-market, and that seems to have slowed down a bit in the second quarter. I guess what's changed there? And maybe if you can just highlight your expectations for the remainder of the year in the mid-market.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in the second quarter, we had a very, very strong quarter a year ago, and compares were tougher. We expect that -- we're expecting a good quarter in the third quarter. And I think Marty pointed out something that's important. Last year, there
componenttext: Yes, I think in the second quarter, we had a very, very strong quarter a year ago, and compares were tougher. We expect that -- we're expecting a good quarter in the third quarter. And I think Marty pointed out something that's important. Last year, there was a drive by many mid-market companies to find integrated solutions that included an ACA-compliant solution. A lot of those clients have now selected their solution, and the game now is a bit more a competitive takeaway as opposed to selling them on a new solution. There obviously was some of that going on. So we go into third quarter then assuming that we'll pick up from where we were in Q2.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly feel great about the product and ever-expanding functionality of the product. And I think, as Efrain said, last year was kind of a heightened second quarter with the Affordable Care Act sales. And this year, it's almost a little bit of the
componenttext: Yes. Certainly feel great about the product and ever-expanding functionality of the product. And I think, as Efrain said, last year was kind of a heightened second quarter with the Affordable Care Act sales. And this year, it's almost a little bit of the reverse. I think people are being a little careful to make any changes until they see what the rules come out -- how it changes. And they're probably concerned about their filing and making a change and not getting everything filed. So we saw a little bit -- probably unexpected -- a little bit slower there, and we expect though -- once we get past the filing date, so expect a good selling season here. But it may still continue to be a little bit slow through the third quarter until we get past the filing date. We'll have to see kind of how that shakes out. But we feel certainly good about the product, the competitiveness and going head-to-head with any of the competitors in the market.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess besides client behavior, are you seeing any change in the competitive landscape at all?
componenttext: I guess besides client behavior, are you seeing any change in the competitive landscape at all?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. No, there's no real new competitors there. We haven't seen a lot of change in their approach or product. And I think we've -- as I mentioned, we've continued to add new options to our product and more self-service, more analytics. We talke
componenttext: No, not really. No, there's no real new competitors there. We haven't seen a lot of change in their approach or product. And I think we've -- as I mentioned, we've continued to add new options to our product and more self-service, more analytics. We talked about HR Analytics and providing more there. Mobile-first design, so an increased use of mobile. So we're feeling very good and very competitive. Have not really seen any change from a competitive marketplace.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As many of -- as I'm sure you saw, the NFIB put up some small business confidence indicators for the month of November, which were substantially stronger after the election than before. I guess it sounds like from your overall kind of qualitative client c
componenttext: As many of -- as I'm sure you saw, the NFIB put up some small business confidence indicators for the month of November, which were substantially stronger after the election than before. I guess it sounds like from your overall kind of qualitative client commentary that people are still cautious, pending any changes in the regulation. Can you give us any kind of additional color on what you've been hearing from clients over the last month or 1.5 months in terms of their optimism on overall business levels and how that kind of matches with your commentary on the rest of the business?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's exactly -- I think it's optimism pending action. So I think it's a lot of optimism on, hey, lower corporate tax rates could drive a lot of less expense and more to what they could invest and more employees and so forth. Affordable Care A
componenttext: Yes, I think it's exactly -- I think it's optimism pending action. So I think it's a lot of optimism on, hey, lower corporate tax rates could drive a lot of less expense and more to what they could invest and more employees and so forth. Affordable Care Act, looks like those costs could come down for a lot of companies and not forcing them to have the product. But we'll see. Time and attendance rules, although it's a little bit separate, but less regulation. I think overall, it's a very optimistic attitude from the clients, but not necessarily turning that into action yet because they got to see it. So they're feeling good about the fact that it looks like there's going to be a better business environment. Consumer confidence is also up. NFIB was one of the biggest increases we've seen in over the 42-year average for the -- 1 of the 3 times I think in the last almost 10 years. So there's a lot of optimism, but I don't think, again, they're turning that into action, hiring and so forth, at least yet until they see kind of what the first few months of the new administration brings. That's what -- we're kind of getting great optimism, but the small business index, at least for November, our last one, would show still not a big uptick in hiring, kind of at the same growth rate it was last year for at least small business. So very positive, but kind of waiting to see what happens.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then maybe as a follow-up, I think last quarter you cited the traction you're seeing in the 100- and 200-plus kind of segment and the new increment sale spend you've been putting against that. Can you talk about, first of all, whether
componenttext: That's helpful. And then maybe as a follow-up, I think last quarter you cited the traction you're seeing in the 100- and 200-plus kind of segment and the new increment sale spend you've been putting against that. Can you talk about, first of all, whether there's any change or -- in that traction? Whether you're seeing continued momentum there? And whether you think the incremental sales spend you put against that is actually adequate at this point, such that you don't have to increase it more in the coming quarters?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think -- I think we're adequate. We're fully staffed and feel very good about being fully staffed and out there. I think the only surprise in the quarter, we've kind of already mentioned, which is a little bit more inactivity to make a change
componenttext: Yes, I don't think -- I think we're adequate. We're fully staffed and feel very good about being fully staffed and out there. I think the only surprise in the quarter, we've kind of already mentioned, which is a little bit more inactivity to make a change than we saw last year at this time. And I think that would be the only difference. And I think that's kind of more of a macro kind of issue. And so I think that would be the only change. Certainly feel good about, as I mentioned, the competitiveness. No change really in the competitive environment. And we're fully staffed and gaining more and more experience on the newer reps that we added at the beginning of the fiscal year. So we'll be able to talk more about it after the selling season. The only real difference from first quarter, I would say, is with the election, which really changed quite rapidly, at least the view of the election and who won. I think that just put people in a little bit more cautious period for switching anything or making buying decisions in the second quarter.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And just a quick clarification, if I could. In the quarter itself, relative to the plan you had heading into the quarter, wouldn't you say that the DOL lack of bookings or the ACA shortfall was kind of the bigger contributor there?
componenttext: That's fair. And just a quick clarification, if I could. In the quarter itself, relative to the plan you had heading into the quarter, wouldn't you say that the DOL lack of bookings or the ACA shortfall was kind of the bigger contributor there?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't -- I think the -- I think just the election, if I'm getting your question right, Jim, I think the question or the -- what happened was, with the changes in ACA, with the president -- with Trump getting in and probably a little bit more unexp
componenttext: Well, I don't -- I think the -- I think just the election, if I'm getting your question right, Jim, I think the question or the -- what happened was, with the changes in ACA, with the president -- with Trump getting in and probably a little bit more unexpected until second quarter as it got closer to the election, I think people know changes are going to happen. And so they're a little bit less -- they're a little bit more reluctant to make a change until they see kind of what happened. They're optimistic, but they're not sure what's going to happen yet. And so if that answers your question. Now the DOL -- if you're talking about the Overtime Rules, I think that was very helpful from an over -- from a selling of our Flex Time and Flex Essentials and our time clocks, and I think that's sticking. So the good thing there is, it brought a lot of attention to, you ought to be tracking time. Look at the options that are out there now from a technology standpoint, punching in and out on a mobile phone, things that have not been available, generally, until the last year or so. And I think that's going to stick. So that actually helped drive some sales that are recorded in our HRS services revenue. And I think that's going to continue, and it's going to stick no matter what happens with Overtime Rules.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mr. Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's quite a bit of debate about how much you'll actually benefit in the short term for the float. So I wanted to ask a two-part question just to help frame that. The first one, do you -- as you think about the float, how you manage the float, is there
componenttext: There's quite a bit of debate about how much you'll actually benefit in the short term for the float. So I wanted to ask a two-part question just to help frame that. The first one, do you -- as you think about the float, how you manage the float, is there still right -- I know there's some seasonality, but to think that roughly half of the float balance is short-term stuff, whether it's money market, the variable demand rate notes, et cetera, and you targeting about half in intermediate-term bonds. And the second question, if we look at that bond portfolio, I think you said 3.3-year duration, is the stuff that's maturing in the next 12 months, are the interest rates that you would likely reinvest at in today above the rates of the stuff that's maturing? Or is that still a negative at this point?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, hey, good question. So yes, you're right, it's -- short term's about 45%. It can be sometimes 50%. But we keep it between 45% and 50%. So that reprices immediately or very quickly, I shouldn't say -- should say. Let me just be careful. That's an ove
componenttext: Okay, hey, good question. So yes, you're right, it's -- short term's about 45%. It can be sometimes 50%. But we keep it between 45% and 50%. So that reprices immediately or very quickly, I shouldn't say -- should say. Let me just be careful. That's an overstatement. It doesn't reprice immediately. It typically reprices in somewhere between 45 to 60 days. So the answer to the first question, portfolio composition is, yes, that's correct. And then the second is, yes, also. Yes, the bonds that we would invest in going forward currently have yields that are significantly higher than the ones that are rolling off. So if I were to call it today, and I am not doing that, but if I were to call it today, and I assume no more Fed increases other than what we have gotten at this point, the portfolio would be about $8 million higher in value than it is today. I'd just caution anyone from taking that to the bank because we'll have much more granular information once we get through the next couple of quarters and see what the fate -- what the Fed actually does. And the reason why I say that is, we look at and we could give you a big forecast based on yield curves. I'm -- distrust that approach. I'd rather tell you what we think our portfolios will do based on what I know at the time I'm saying it. But you can do some math, and the numbers start to get pretty significant if the Fed does what it says it's going to do. And the final qualification I'd add to that is the steepness of a yield curve also impacts how we invest. So right now, they do nothing, I'd call that at about $8 million next year that's annualized, and we'll see where we go through the remainder of the year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify that -- that's very helpful, by the way. So the $8 million, that is annualizing and getting the full benefit from the Fed funds rate increase recently and also the benefit from reinvesting bonds at what the current yield curve is. Is t
componenttext: And just to clarify that -- that's very helpful, by the way. So the $8 million, that is annualizing and getting the full benefit from the Fed funds rate increase recently and also the benefit from reinvesting bonds at what the current yield curve is. Is that correct?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct.
componenttext: Yes, correct.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question. The -- maybe this is just getting too nitpicky on my end, but the buyback was pretty significant. No increase in the guidance for earnings. It feels like there's a couple of pennies there. Is that just conservatism?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question. The -- maybe this is just getting too nitpicky on my end, but the buyback was pretty significant. No increase in the guidance for earnings. It feels like there's a couple of pennies there. Is that just conservatism? Or is there some other thing we should think about with that?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess I'd say this, Gary. There's always pluses and minuses. So you have to look at what you think are some potential upsides with some potential downsides. And I think it's realistic. I wouldn't call it aggressive, and I wouldn't call it conservat
componenttext: Yes. I guess I'd say this, Gary. There's always pluses and minuses. So you have to look at what you think are some potential upsides with some potential downsides. And I think it's realistic. I wouldn't call it aggressive, and I wouldn't call it conservative.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just actually one other one. Have you done the analysis, and maybe it's just we don't know enough. But about what kind of risks you might face in terms of potential declines in the float portfolio balances based on some of the personal inco
componenttext: Okay. And then just actually one other one. Have you done the analysis, and maybe it's just we don't know enough. But about what kind of risks you might face in terms of potential declines in the float portfolio balances based on some of the personal income tax changes that Trump and the Republican congress have been floating? Should we think of that as a potential offset to some of this is the withholding might be less for a significant portion of your customers?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't started doing modeling at this point. Because at that point, the benefit -- okay, so that's coupled with a more -- a bigger discussion about whether corporate tax rates go down. If that happens, then even if we face some drag from personal
componenttext: No, we haven't started doing modeling at this point. Because at that point, the benefit -- okay, so that's coupled with a more -- a bigger discussion about whether corporate tax rates go down. If that happens, then even if we face some drag from personal income taxes, the corporate tax impact simply dwarfs everything else. So that we'd look at both. So if tax reform occurs, it's pretty obvious that we would be a pretty significant beneficiary. By significant, I mean very significant. So we're waiting to hear, like everyone else is waiting to hear. So that's a partial answer to your question.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mr. Bryan Keane with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Bryan Keane with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to -- a couple of clarifications just on HR services. I think The Street was looking at 4 more -- like 14% revenue growth. I know the guide is 12% to 14%. And it came in a little bit towards the lower end. Was there -- I just want to make sure o
componenttext: Just want to -- a couple of clarifications just on HR services. I think The Street was looking at 4 more -- like 14% revenue growth. I know the guide is 12% to 14%. And it came in a little bit towards the lower end. Was there -- I just want to make sure of the puts and takes there. Because what I'm thinking about, obviously, is Advance Partners acquisition is anniversary-ing and that contributed 2 points to growth, so then I'm thinking about the back half of the year with that coming off. Do we have enough in the pipe and in sales to actually increase that growth rate for the back half?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Bryan, our guidance obviously included Advance. We came out of the first quarter, I think we were at 15% growth. I think I called out attach rates on health care in the PEO, we're a little bit lower than we had projected. That can reverse very, ve
componenttext: Yes. So Bryan, our guidance obviously included Advance. We came out of the first quarter, I think we were at 15% growth. I think I called out attach rates on health care in the PEO, we're a little bit lower than we had projected. That can reverse very, very quickly quarter-to-quarter, so we'll see where we are in Q3. But in terms of where we expect the year to be, we're not really far off from what we expected. So I see where people might get to 14%. I don't think our internal plan suggests that we be at 14%. And so we should be solidly in the year in the range of the guidance that we provided. And obviously, as you pointed out, the selling season will have an impact on where HRS growth ends up for the year. But we feel comfortable with the ranges we've given.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in the back half then, since Advance will now be in the numbers, it won't probably push that growth rate. Should we think about more towards the lower end then in that range of 12% to 14% for the back half as a result of Advance anniversary
componenttext: Okay. And then in the back half then, since Advance will now be in the numbers, it won't probably push that growth rate. Should we think about more towards the lower end then in that range of 12% to 14% for the back half as a result of Advance anniversary-ing?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say yes, subject to whatever we see in terms of sales in Q -- I'm sorry, in the third quarter, which is where the bulk of the selling season comes in. I would say that -- although I didn't call out where we end up in Q4, our guidance is for the ye
componenttext: I would say yes, subject to whatever we see in terms of sales in Q -- I'm sorry, in the third quarter, which is where the bulk of the selling season comes in. I would say that -- although I didn't call out where we end up in Q4, our guidance is for the year as a whole, and we feel comfortable for the year as a whole. That may not mean that -- or that may mean that some quarters aren't exactly in the range of that guidance. So if it's significant, we'll call it out.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, helpful. And then just time and attendance, how big is that? And how fast has that been growing? I know it's been one of the catalysts that you guys have called out. Just how big is that as a percentage of revenue? And maybe the growth rates that yo
componenttext: Okay, helpful. And then just time and attendance, how big is that? And how fast has that been growing? I know it's been one of the catalysts that you guys have called out. Just how big is that as a percentage of revenue? And maybe the growth rates that you guys have been seeing there.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So last time we updated it, it's -- it was about last year, about 10%. I should say online services, which includes HR administration, which is also part of the equation. Back up a second, so it's clear. The fundamental parts of the HCM platform include a
componenttext: So last time we updated it, it's -- it was about last year, about 10%. I should say online services, which includes HR administration, which is also part of the equation. Back up a second, so it's clear. The fundamental parts of the HCM platform include an HR administration module, a time and attendance module and obviously, a payroll engine module. So about 10% of HRS revenue growth -- revenue is online services. We don't break it out more than that. That's been growing at multiples with what payroll's been growing at.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Kartik Mehta with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Kartik Mehta with Northcoast Research.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Efrain, I just want to make sure I understood something you said about the float portfolio. I think you said if, obviously, the rate is kind of -- if the Fed did nothing, it would be about $8 million. I seem to remember I thought in the Q, you said at 25
componenttext: Efrain, I just want to make sure I understood something you said about the float portfolio. I think you said if, obviously, the rate is kind of -- if the Fed did nothing, it would be about $8 million. I seem to remember I thought in the Q, you said at 25 basis point, it would mean after-tax net income of $3.5 million to $4 million. And so that $8 million, is there some tax impact to that, that would be different? Or did I -- am I missing something that you might have said or misinterpreted?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, you're just missing some information, so -- which I didn't provide in my estimate. So our disclosure is that a 25-basis-point rise impacts the portfolio immediately on an annualized basis to the tune of about $3.5 million, $3.7 million, I beli
componenttext: No, no, no, you're just missing some information, so -- which I didn't provide in my estimate. So our disclosure is that a 25-basis-point rise impacts the portfolio immediately on an annualized basis to the tune of about $3.5 million, $3.7 million, I believe it is. But that doesn't end the conversation. Because then the question you have to ask yourself is what does it do to long-term rates? If, in the end, your reinvestment for long-term rates stays the same, it's done nothing. You've gotten a benefit on the short-term portion of the portfolio but very little else. The benefit we are getting right now, and I -- the reason why I caution about including any interest rate benefit in models yet, is that the securities that we invest in intermediate term municipals have gone up pretty significantly since the elections. So our reinvestment rate is higher than it is right now. So if all we got was a 3.5-basis-point -- I'm sorry, a 25-basis-point increase in the Fed funds rate, you could expect that we've got roughly what we say we get. But we're also getting a bit of a benefit on the long-term portion of the portfolio. And what I don't know now and I'll have a better sense is as the Fed keeps raising interest rates, what's happening to the shape of that yield curve as I go out over the maturities that we have to reinvest. So right now, if everything held, I'd be about, on an annualized basis, about $8 million higher. What it will end up being, I don't know until I get to the spring and I can digest the other Fed rate increases.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that does make sense. So I guess, Efrain, will you invest a little bit differently considering the Fed might do a couple of more rate increases? So will the philosophy change at all? Or will you still continue to manage the portfolio like you have?
componenttext: Okay, that does make sense. So I guess, Efrain, will you invest a little bit differently considering the Fed might do a couple of more rate increases? So will the philosophy change at all? Or will you still continue to manage the portfolio like you have?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a discussion that we're going to have as we get into the spring. Because if the shape of the yield curve is steeper on the long end, then maybe I have less short-term cash than I have more long. I haven't made that decision or we haven't had that
componenttext: That is a discussion that we're going to have as we get into the spring. Because if the shape of the yield curve is steeper on the long end, then maybe I have less short-term cash than I have more long. I haven't made that decision or we haven't had that discussion yet. We've had some preliminary conversations about how we would do that. But obviously, that would be one way to get higher yield even than what I'm talking about on the portfolio. Those are decisions that we need to look at when we get into the spring. Obviously, competitors leverage 100%. We've never -- we've chosen not to do that. But between where we are and where other people in the market are, there's room to move if we chose to do so.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Marty, as you're going into the selling season, how many payroll salespeople do you have compared to last year? Is it same, less or more than you've had last year at this time?
componenttext: And Marty, as you're going into the selling season, how many payroll salespeople do you have compared to last year? Is it same, less or more than you've had last year at this time?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, up 2% or 3% from a headcount perspective and fully staffed. And I think, just getting all those reps up to speed, but we're up about 2% or 3%, which is fairly normal for us and it's kind of across both small and mid-market.
componenttext: Yes, up 2% or 3% from a headcount perspective and fully staffed. And I think, just getting all those reps up to speed, but we're up about 2% or 3%, which is fairly normal for us and it's kind of across both small and mid-market.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And where do you stand in terms of salespeople attrition today compared to what it has been in the past?
componenttext: And where do you stand in terms of salespeople attrition today compared to what it has been in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very consistent. It's -- some are better than others. Actually, some of the mid-market, I think, tends to be a little bit better than it has been historically even, and core payroll tends to be very consistent with where it's been. No big uptick in t
componenttext: Yes, very consistent. It's -- some are better than others. Actually, some of the mid-market, I think, tends to be a little bit better than it has been historically even, and core payroll tends to be very consistent with where it's been. No big uptick in turnover or anything.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last question, Marty. You've moved over to Flex and obviously, the transition seems to be going well. Have you seen an impact on cross sales because of customers moving to Flex even with more or less in terms of product sales?
componenttext: Okay. And just one last question, Marty. You've moved over to Flex and obviously, the transition seems to be going well. Have you seen an impact on cross sales because of customers moving to Flex even with more or less in terms of product sales?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, obviously, from the Flex standpoint, you've got a better integration there, and we've built everything to integrate into that and then continued to roll things out with Flex. So we're certainly seeing better pickup from a penetration. I wouldn'
componenttext: Yes. Well, obviously, from the Flex standpoint, you've got a better integration there, and we've built everything to integrate into that and then continued to roll things out with Flex. So we're certainly seeing better pickup from a penetration. I wouldn't say it's huge, but it certainly is a bigger pickup in penetration when you're selling the Flex platform because everything is built around that. So -- and we still have a lot of room to grow there. So when you think of the HR analytics that we just rolled out kind of at HR Tech and some of the other products like -- just rolling out Flex Essentials, which is that kind of lower end time and attendance solution without clocks, all of that is around Flex. So we expect to have better penetration growth because of the Flex platform and the more we roll it out to clients.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mr. Tim McHugh with William Blair.
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Tim McHugh with William Blair.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to ask, digging back onto the comment about seeing, I guess, a trend towards a smaller average client size. You've talked a little bit about various parts of this. But just to be clear, are you seeing, I guess, slower growth in the middle market
componenttext: Just want to ask, digging back onto the comment about seeing, I guess, a trend towards a smaller average client size. You've talked a little bit about various parts of this. But just to be clear, are you seeing, I guess, slower growth in the middle market, and that's why the average is skewing down or faster growth in small? Or I guess, you can peel                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       back for us why the average is trending smaller than it was in the past.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say this, Tim, that right now, the relative growth between small is tilting a little bit more towards small versus mid. And last year, it was tending a little bit more -- trending a little bit more mid than small. So I think that's what it is. Look, I
componenttext: I'd say this, Tim, that right now, the relative growth between small is tilting a little bit more towards small versus mid. And last year, it was tending a little bit more -- trending a little bit more mid than small. So I think that's what it is. Look, I could also talk about losses and sales. But when you net it all out, that's basically what you're seeing. And by the way, I just want to make it clear, our average client size has been 17 for the last 10 years. It's not a dramatic difference. By the 10th year, 15 basis points there does make a difference.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, not a huge change. But as Efrain said, it makes a difference. But I think that point we made earlier, both Efrain and I, I think, last quarter, Tim, what we saw was there was more movement in the mid-market because of Affordable Care Act and the need
componenttext: Yes, not a huge change. But as Efrain said, it makes a difference. But I think that point we made earlier, both Efrain and I, I think, last quarter, Tim, what we saw was there was more movement in the mid-market because of Affordable Care Act and the need. That got people to change and sell more. This one has been -- compared to last quarter, that need has kind of been satisfied by those who have it. And while we're holding certainly the clients we have with Affordable Care Act products, we're not seeing the interest in saying, "Okay, I want to change because I have to have something in place." So we saw a little bit of a shift quarter -- second quarter over second quarter. And again, it's not a huge number, but it did drop the average size a little bit.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's fair. It seems like middle market -- because that comp issue isn't -- probably isn't growing as fast. Is small necessarily growing faster? Or is it just -- it's growing at the same rate and you're not seeing quite as much growth in mid-marke
componenttext: Okay. So it's fair. It seems like middle market -- because that comp issue isn't -- probably isn't growing as fast. Is small necessarily growing faster? Or is it just -- it's growing at the same rate and you're not seeing quite as much growth in mid-market and so that average is -- that brings the average down?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Small is growing faster.
componenttext: Small is growing faster.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faster than it was before?
componenttext: Faster than it was before?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's growing faster.
componenttext: It's growing faster.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Because when you say faster, sir, just to -- faster than middle market? Or are you saying faster than in the past?
componenttext: Okay. Because when you say faster, sir, just to -- faster than middle market? Or are you saying faster than in the past?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is growing faster than the middle market. I would say it's quite comparable to where we were a year or so ago.
componenttext: It is growing faster than the middle market. I would say it's quite comparable to where we were a year or so ago.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that time -- okay. What was the last -- can you give us -- remind us of the split between middle market and small, I guess, in that payroll part of it?
componenttext: Okay. And that time -- okay. What was the last -- can you give us -- remind us of the split between middle market and small, I guess, in that payroll part of it?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We don't give the actual payroll dollars associated with it. It's complicated. And the reason we don't do that is a lot of ancillaries are primarily mid-market clients. Our client base in the mid-market is about a little bit over 6% of our total clie
componenttext: Yes. We don't give the actual payroll dollars associated with it. It's complicated. And the reason we don't do that is a lot of ancillaries are primarily mid-market clients. Our client base in the mid-market is about a little bit over 6% of our total clients, and you can assume that the -- from a revenue standpoint, that's 3x to 4x what our client base is, if that helps.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know it's late, just have a quick one. Efrain, you mentioned that if corporate tax rates go down, you think you'd be -- I think you used the words significant beneficiary. Can you just remind us right now roughly what your federal tax rate is?
componenttext: I know it's late, just have a quick one. Efrain, you mentioned that if corporate tax rates go down, you think you'd be -- I think you used the words significant beneficiary. Can you just remind us right now roughly what your federal tax rate is?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our federal tax rate is about 33%. And we obviously pay pretty close to the statutory rate. A -- it depends on whose estimate you're looking at. If you're down in 20% -- to a 20% corporate tax rate, we are significant beneficiary. But even a 5- to 10
componenttext: Yes. Our federal tax rate is about 33%. And we obviously pay pretty close to the statutory rate. A -- it depends on whose estimate you're looking at. If you're down in 20% -- to a 20% corporate tax rate, we are significant beneficiary. But even a 5- to 10-point decrease would create significant benefits for us.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few clarifications on previous commentary. But maybe, Marty, going back to the sales activity, sort of just honing in on your comment a little bit more inactivity or less -- slower because it makes buying decisions and switching. Is that kind of ho
componenttext: Just a few clarifications on previous commentary. But maybe, Marty, going back to the sales activity, sort of just honing in on your comment a little bit more inactivity or less -- slower because it makes buying decisions and switching. Is that kind of how you're contemplating the upcoming, obviously, key selling season? Meaning the sector is -- that the new administration, we're not going to know what the new rules are and whatever they may do is not going to be known really until the end of the selling season? So are you sort of preparing for a difficult sales season?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't say it's difficult. I'll just say this was compared really to last year, so we saw more activity. So we're -- I mean, we're expecting a pretty good selling season. But it was certainly a little bit slower in Q2 than it was last year. Even
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't say it's difficult. I'll just say this was compared really to last year, so we saw more activity. So we're -- I mean, we're expecting a pretty good selling season. But it was certainly a little bit slower in Q2 than it was last year. Even though things are known, I think it's just -- it's -- last year, we had a lot of sales. We had more mid-market sales in the second quarter because they had to get -- they had to make some change to get the Affordable Care Act product. By this point, they had -- most of those had bought it by November when you think about last year because they had to get in. And actually, many of us stopped selling it after November because we had to get them taken care of for the calendar year. So I wouldn't say we're expecting a difficult sales season. But there may be a little bit more inactivity than we saw last year. But I would expect most of that was in Q2 of last year.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Efrain, on the buyback, I think it's pretty clear, but the uptick in the buyback, the 2.9 million shares this quarter, we shouldn't be thinking any change in your buyback mentality, that's for sure, more just to get the share count closer to where it
componenttext: And Efrain, on the buyback, I think it's pretty clear, but the uptick in the buyback, the 2.9 million shares this quarter, we shouldn't be thinking any change in your buyback mentality, that's for sure, more just to get the share count closer to where it was a year ago is kind of what I was hearing.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, Glenn. That's where we're at.
componenttext: Yes, that's right, Glenn. That's where we're at.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to clarify, on the ACA, obviously, a risk. And you sort of identified what the risk could be. But what's the order of magnitude? What percentage of revenue ACA is right now?
componenttext: And then just to clarify, on the ACA, obviously, a risk. And you sort of identified what the risk could be. But what's the order of magnitude? What percentage of revenue ACA is right now?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think I was asked this last year. So I'm going to call it direct ACA revenue is in a little bit above 1% -- between 1% and 1.5% of revenue.
componenttext: So I think I was asked this last year. So I'm going to call it direct ACA revenue is in a little bit above 1% -- between 1% and 1.5% of revenue.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
