componenttext: Just a quick one clarifier from the release and your comments. I mentioned -- I noticed you didn't mention anything about the operating income excluding float. Have you changed how you're thinking about operating margin and operating income here?

componenttext: Not really. I mean, I think you can basically do much of the math yourselves. And because float is no longer a drag, it's probably more useful to just look at it in totality.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just the next one, Marty, you did mention about the regulatory changes, how you do see that it would benefit for the business overall. I guess, if you could just talk about the components of your business and where you saw the most -- from client
componenttext: And then just the next one, Marty, you did mention about the regulatory changes, how you do see that it would benefit for the business overall. I guess, if you could just talk about the components of your business and where you saw the most -- from client perspective, where they did more on the regulatory driven work. I mean, did it drive more people to do PEO or ASO? Did it drive more bundles? Was there any sort of split within the business on sort of the regulatory pressure and what it drove clients to do?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I think, first, and I think I'd say overtime -- the overtime rules that have now, of course, been postponed, at least temporarily, that drove certainly a lot more interest from clients in time and attendance solution. So that's been helpful to
componenttext: Yes, sure. I think, first, and I think I'd say overtime -- the overtime rules that have now, of course, been postponed, at least temporarily, that drove certainly a lot more interest from clients in time and attendance solution. So that's been helpful to get in front of clients and offer them great timing for us in the product suite that we have. So that drove a lot of interest and frankly, still is. I think it kind of geared up a lot of interest that whether the overtime rules go into effect or not, I think it's going to be a plus for us. From -- when you start talking about overtime rules, that also drags in HR. So whether it was ASO or PEO, that brought a lot of interest in HR support. So companies that would have said, "Hey, I'm going to continue to try to deal with the HR myself internally," now said, "Jeez, I think with all these overtime rules, who is exempt, who isn't?" A lot more discussion about moving people to exempt or not based on the overtime rules brought in some HR sales as well, both in the ASO and PEO platform. And then I think a little bit probably of a drag might have been the fact that, "Okay, now the Affordable Care Act, as we've said, is up in the air, but what's going to happen? Maybe I don't rush to buy as much from an insurance or a PEO side? Do I need it or not?" So I think those were kind of the major changes. I think right now, what we expect is less regulation based on the platforms of the Trump administration. But I think there's still going to be enough change that those things will still help us. And in fact, just the level of change makes people worry about -- can they keep up with everything? If the tax rates change, if the rules change on maybe when to file, if overtime is in or out, that all drives people to say, "Okay, I can't keep up with that. I'm going to turn it over to an outsourcer like Paychex who has over 200 people who just track compliance and realize what has to happen and so forth." So I think those have been the pluses and minuses.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: No, because -- the first part of the statement, David, is correct. So we are fully staffed and operations expenses year-over-year were up pretty significantly in the quarter. We called out some reasons for that. That compare gets a little bit easier as we go through the remainder of the year. But remember that expenses in Q3 and in Q4, but Q3 particularly, increased because of the volume of operations activity that we have and also the volume of sales activity that we have. So no, in the back half of the year, you see, if -- our financials, the margin actually goes down and that's typical of our pattern.

componenttext: We feel comfortable with the guidance. And obviously, we're actually running a little bit ahead of it in the first half but comfortable where we are in terms of margins at this point.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. First of all, with regards to, just the general environment that you're seeing in the small business arena, what are you seeing in terms of new business startups in terms of trickling up from the field, source of new clients?
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. First of all, with regards to, just the general environment that you're seeing in the small business arena, what are you seeing in terms of new business startups in terms of trickling up from the field, source of new clients? And then what are you seeing in terms of bankruptcies and how that seems to be trending?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On new business startups, I think they've kind of reached back to that level and -- that they were kind of pre-recession. We've seen that now for probably a year. And I think they've kind of held everything that we've seen, would [ph] say. They're no
componenttext: Yes. On new business startups, I think they've kind of reached back to that level and -- that they were kind of pre-recession. We've seen that now for probably a year. And I think they've kind of held everything that we've seen, would [ph] say. They're not growing tremendously more than that, but they're kind of right in that place where they were. Bankruptcies, generally pretty consistent where they've been, maybe up a little. At least what we've seen -- what we see is from -- our loss is 2 bankruptcies and out of business, and that's picked up slightly. But again, our overall retention is very consistent with where it's been at pretty record high levels, pretty consistent in that range. So no big change there. But a little bit tick up in the bankruptcies, which is interesting. It doesn't seem like that should happen. But we've seen a few more losses because of that, nothing that would change our overall number.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with regards to -- you've had great improvement with regards to the Flex as it relates to the smaller end of the market. From a technology perspective, can you lay out any additional improvements that we should expect out of the 50 to 1,000
componenttext: Okay. And then with regards to -- you've had great improvement with regards to the Flex as it relates to the smaller end of the market. From a technology perspective, can you lay out any additional improvements that we should expect out of the 50 to 1,000 range in terms of what you're offering there?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, okay. For the 50 to -- I think -- well, I think you'll continue to see that level of integration and you'll see a big continued push on a few things. One is the analytics piece that we just talked about at HR Tech, much more on the analytics, both kin
componenttext: Oh, okay. For the 50 to -- I think -- well, I think you'll continue to see that level of integration and you'll see a big continued push on a few things. One is the analytics piece that we just talked about at HR Tech, much more on the analytics, both kind of in the way we report the data and in the flexibility the client has. The other will be continue to be a mobile-first design, and we're seeing a good uptick in mobile usage, as I have mentioned before, not only the client, but from the employee standpoint. So we're spending a lot of time kind of adjusting our language in our display much more now. Pretty much 99% -- over 99% of the display is HTML5, so it's a much cleaner and easier use for the client, much more flexible for the client and the employees on mobile use. But we've still got a long ways to go on mobile adoption. So getting the client and our employees to download the app and use it, it's growing fast, but we still got a long ways to go. And I think that's going to be a big part of assisting in the value of our products and services. The full suite is there and we're constantly adding to it, like the new Flex Essentials, Flex Time Essentials, and you'll see a lot more paperless. So everything pretty much can be paperless today, right? Even PEO onboarding now is all paperless function. So I think you'll continue to see us add to the functionality. And even in time and attendance, we're adding new modules all the time. So a budgeting module, we just added where you'll be able to track your time to your budget and so forth. So you're going to continue to see not only the products expand, but the modules within each kind of distinct product.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: That's great. I mean, is there going to be a step function, Marty, in terms of -- by the end of calendar '17, we should see -- we did have some step functions on the smaller side that were some real benchmarks that we ended up hitting. Do we see something similar to that coming up?

componenttext: You mean a benchmark from a penetration standpoint?

componenttext: Right.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think so, although it's much more gradual now. Like we -- a number of the clients are on Flex. I think we certainly have internal goals as to where we want that penetration to be, including mobile adoption, so you'll see more marketing push, mobile adoption. You'll see more direct, i.e. trying to get the employees of the clients and more marketing from that standpoint. So we don't really disclose it, but we certainly internally have our steps that we want to get to our different goals by year for penetration of those products. And I think right now, we're on track, I think even a little ahead on time and attendance because of the overtime rules.

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then on the PEO, you basically mentioned that, that's growing a little bit faster than the ASO, and it sounded like the momentum will continue to be very good. And at the same time, we have this -- a bit of a pause with regards to the regulatory uncertainty because of the administration change. But it didn't sound like your commentary would suggest that you would expect any sort of slowdown on the -- just the core PEO. Did I interpret that correctly?

headline: Paychex, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. Yes, I think we've seen that pretty consistent growth in -- from the PEO standpoint, and I think we feel very good about the carrier plans we're offering now and the work with the carriers. And so yes, I don't think that will necessarily slow
componenttext: I think so. Yes, I think we've seen that pretty consistent growth in -- from the PEO standpoint, and I think we feel very good about the carrier plans we're offering now and the work with the carriers. And so yes, I don't think that will necessarily slow down. We've just seen that kind of inactivity, a little bit of a slowness in making a change in some clients who already have it. But I think you'll see -- and even with more certification in things that are going on in that industry, I think you could see a pickup there, and there's no real change in competition. We haven't really seen any real change from any of the competitors from the PEO standpoint. So if you have good plans, great HR service and support and good carrier plans, insurance plans, we should continue to see good double-digit growth there.

componenttext: Yes, I guess some. I wouldn't say any major thing. We certainly have seen where people might jump to a competitor. We've seen a few of those come back. And I think -- so there wasn't any major exodus for anybody to come back. So some come back, but not too many.

componenttext: I would say a little bit of both, but probably less product these days and more expansion of what we have. Obviously, that's been very good acquisition for us, good team there and there's some opportunities there as well in that industry. And so I'd say across the board, probably a little bit less product, but there's some product things we still want to do, but we've pretty much build those, the majority of those tuck-in type opportunities, mostly what we're looking for now, and different geographies, obviously, as well. We're always looking particularly in Western Europe for opportunities as well. And so I'd say it's a little bit across the board.
